Human nature provides the most amusing of comedies. A recent study revealed that job titles are a major source of envy and tension at work. A survey by a top recruitment consultancy found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees admit that titles create divisions among colleagues. Surprisingly, the survey showed that 70% of office workers would prefer a more 'motivational' or 'professional' job title over a pay raise. If our vanity is so strong that it surpasses even basic greed, we are indeed in trouble. In the early twenty-first century, no one wants to be seen as subordinate. The titles being discussed emphasize ability (like specialist or coordinator) but are often just euphemisms.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. Photography was not just my job; it was a part of my life. I was always fascinated by how light fell on surfaces and how a single picture could capture the essence of a moment, a place, or a person. I was always searching for that perfect photograph, ready to capture it as long as I had film in my camera. This had been my approach for a long time. I once captured a photo of a smoke plume from a burning oil well that became famous worldwide. It was a moment of luck, but they say you make your own luck, both good and bad. After that, I went freelance, which seemed like a smart move, but life outside photography took some wrong turns. The mid-nineties didn't turn out as successful as I had hoped, even after my photo made it to the cover of Time magazine. That's why I was in Vienna, rather than somewhere more newsworthy. But I was still taking photographs and getting paid for it, which wasn't bad. 

The Vienna assignment came by chance. I had done the London photos for a picture book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons," which included London, Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The project gave me a good commission to capture my home city in different seasons. I had my own take on London, but I knew the best of my work might not be used. It was just a picture book, not meant to challenge perceptions. After finishing the London-in-winter photos, I learned that the Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, had left the Vienna job. They offered me the role because the Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available. Things at home weren't great, so I was happy to go. A week in snowy Vienna was appealing, and I didn't need it to be a compliment to my artistry. 

They put me up at the Europa hotel in the heart of the old city. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy summer trip, and I didn't take many photos. This time, in a cold January, it was going to be different. I felt it as soon as I arrived and saw the city covered in snow. I was going to enjoy myself and take great pictures. The first day, I didn't take any photos. I rode the trams around the city, observing and absorbing the atmosphere. The weather was cold and set, like the grand baroque buildings of the city. I hadn't seen Schussner's work from other seasons because I wanted this to be my Vienna. I waited for the right moment to take my photos. 

The next morning, I was out at dawn. Fresh snow meant Stephansplatz was white and empty. I hadn't figured out how to capture the cathedral in one shot. Its spire reached into the sky, but at ground level, it was massive. I might have to settle for a partial shot, but it could still be magical. Photography has always had a magical quality. In the past, people saw it as mysterious, even when they understood the chemistry behind it. Watching a photo develop in a dark room is still a magical experience. Perhaps that's why what happened at Stephansplatz that morning didn't surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Rejoice**

Something remarkable has happened: London's serious Hayward Gallery has become a place of wonder. This change wasn't due to a big-budget, heavily promoted show, but rather a unique exploration of a nearly forgotten art form from the past 60 years. The new exhibition explores the history of kinetic art, which is art focused on movement, in the twentieth century. It shows that creating artworks that move or explore movement has been a consistent, though often overlooked, theme in fascinating creative work of this century. Curator Guy Brett, who has dedicated his life to studying this subject, has gathered a wonderful collection of paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. These are presented with minimal text, allowing visitors to enjoy making their own connections and discoveries.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art attracts many people who might not usually be interested in art. This could be because his work is figurative and easy to understand, or because it offers an escape from everyday life. Some might be drawn to Hockney's charming personality and witty comments, which make him popular in the media. Some critics think Hockney is overrated, but this might be because being popular is not always seen as a good thing today. Hockney himself knows his limits and believes it's not fair to judge his work against an abstract idea of greatness. He doesn't claim to be a great artist and understands that only time will tell his true place in art history.

**Window-shopping - an art exhibition**

Recently, I've seen many contemporary art exhibitions, some brilliant and some mediocre. What bothers me are shows that push a hidden agenda, suggesting a common attitude among artists. Sometimes this works, revealing new trends, but often it feels forced. As a curator, I wanted to create a show that was the opposite of this. With seven artists, I took over a space in an empty warehouse. "Window-shopping" was a collection of individual artworks connected only by their claim to be art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats chased each other on a toy train track, while Matthew Crawley's video camera experiment flickered on a monitor. These works didn't fit into a themed exhibition but complemented each other through contrast. I didn't make any grand statements about contemporary art, but perhaps there aren't any to make about an activity where artists set their own rules.

**Art History**

People who enjoy paintings sometimes hesitate to analyze them, fearing it might spoil their experience. Some say art historians, who focus on theory, ignore the pleasure of looking and the act of creativity. This idea is like thinking that knowing a recipe's ingredients and cooking method takes away from enjoying the dish. Understanding an artwork can enhance our enjoyment. Pleasure is complex, and how we experience it can be examined. Our preferences are influenced by societal values, not just personal taste. While sensuous responses to art are important, the idea that intellect undermines them is outdated, from a time when art was seen as separate from thought.

**Metals**

Stone Age people might have been interested in metals because they wanted to decorate themselves. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, when one of our early ancestors found a shiny yellow pebble. It wasn't like a regular stone, but it was attractive. This is how gold might have become part of their lives. Gold is easy to shape, so it quickly became popular. Copper might have been discovered by accident too. Once people realized how useful copper tools were, they eagerly searched for copper ores and ways to extract the metal. This led to the development of metalworking, which greatly improved their lives.

**St Ives**

We walked silently, carrying our bags down the winding, cobbled lane into the town center. We struggled against the strong wind and tried to avoid the icy waves crashing over the promenade. The streets were empty, and the shutters on every waterfront cottage were tightly closed against the storm. We had watched the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on the small single-track train. As the dark grey skies closed in, visiting Cornwall in the off-season without a car seemed like a bad idea. I had convinced my friend to join me with promises of beautiful coastal walks and cozy evenings by open fires.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is challenging because it is gone. The people who lived through peaceful times and hardships are long dead. The reasons they settled in certain places or formed communities have been forgotten. Archaeology gives us some clues, but we can't test our ideas on past cultures. We can't replay history. However, computer modelling offers a solution. It allows us to recreate ancient landscapes and fill them with virtual communities. These digital creations have some of the needs and abilities of real humans. We can set rules for their behavior and simulate social groups. Then, we can change conditions, like reducing rainfall or increasing population, to see how these virtual societies react.

**Vervet Monkeys**

Cheney and Seyfarth observed a group of vervet monkeys. One day, the dominant male noticed a strange male in a nearby grove of trees. The stranger wanted to join the group, which could mean the dominant male would lose his position. To prevent this, the dominant male used a clever trick. Whenever the stranger tried to approach, he gave an alarm call that vervets use to warn of a leopard. This scared the stranger back into the trees. The plan worked until the dominant male made a mistake: he gave the alarm call while casually walking across open ground himself.

**What Cats Catch**

In the English village of Felmersham, residents collected prey caught by their cats. Over a year, seventy cats caught over 1,000 prey items. An American professor estimated that, based on these figures, cats in Britain might be killing 100 million birds and small mammals annually. However, this calculation is misleading. Most British cats live in towns, have smaller ranges, and catch less prey than the rural cats in the survey. The important question is whether these numbers are sustainable. The answer seems to be yes. Many people feed birds in winter, and gardens provide nesting sites, keeping bird populations above natural levels. The survey showed that cats are significant predators but not devastating to Britain's bird population.

**Buffalo's Day**

Buffaloes are essential to marshmen and are well cared for. Each morning, the buffaloes leave their sleeping spots, moving slowly and groaning, to reach the distant reed beds. They stand on the platform's edge, expressing their fatigue, until the leader finally steps into the water. Once in the water, they seem to forget their purpose and may linger there, complaining softly. Their movements are so slow that they are barely noticeable, but eventually, they swim away, appearing almost submerged. They spend the day among the reeds, grazing on green shoots at eye level.

**PICASSO, Pablo - The Soles, 1940**

In early 1940, while staying in the fishing port of Royan, Picasso painted several fish still lifes. One painting shows a fishmonger's slab with a crab and a pair of scales holding two or three soles. Despite their situation, the sea creatures appear alive. The painting is complex, with overlapping and interlocking transparent planes. The thin, delicately brushed paint and cool colors create a calm, underwater world. However, this calm is disturbed by an impending battle between the fish and the crab. The sharp forms of the fish and crab, along with the scales, suggest a sense of menace and hidden violence, giving the painting a symbolic depth.

Photography Over the past 150 years, photography has been used to capture all aspects of human life and activity. In this relatively short time, it has expanded its ability to record time and space, allowing us to see fleeting moments and visualize both the vast and the tiny. Photography has shown us images from remote parts of the world, distant areas of the solar system, and the social complexities and crises of modern life. It has become one of the most important ways to express the human condition. However, the recording of events through images has a much longer history. The earliest pictorial recordings date back to the Upper Palaeolithic period, about 35,000 years ago. Although we cannot be sure of the exact purposes of early cave paintings—whether they recorded actual hunting events, served as magic to increase animals for hunting, acted as religious icons, or simply brightened domestic life—pictorial images seem deeply connected to human culture. Throughout history, questions have been raised about the accuracy of visual images and their status in society. The idea that 'seeing is believing' has always given special importance to visual images. So when photography was invented in the mid-19th century, its social and cultural impact was immense. Photography promised to provide a truthful visual record automatically. The camera, functioning like the human eye, was seen as a machine that could provide a fixed image, closely resembling what we actually see. The chemical fixing of images allowed the capture of what might be considered a natural phenomenon: the camera image. At the same time, the photographic image was seen as a cultural achievement, producing images that artists had long struggled to create. Ironically, because of the camera's perceived realism, it was assumed that everyone would naturally understand photographs. This led to the question of whether photography was a 'universal language'. For example, in 1933, photographer August Sander expressed this view, saying even the most isolated person could understand a photograph of the heavens. However, with the rapid increase in global communications in the late 20th century, we need to ask to what extent photographic images can cross cultural differences in understanding. Is photography as bound by cultural conventions as language? Is it possible that our familiarity with photographs has led us to overlook the medium's ability to convey vivid impressions of 'reality'? Photography is often seen as providing convincing pictorial evidence, making the medium seem transparent and blurring the line between our perception of the environment and its photographic representations. It is common for someone to show a photograph and say, 'this is my grandson'. Since its invention in 1839, photography technology and attitudes towards it have changed significantly. This may be because photography has moved into 'mythic time'—its initial role as a 19th-century record-keeper has now moved beyond the human scale. Photographic images, once immediate and close to photographer and subject, have now become historical documents, revealing as much about the society that produced them as about their subjects. The camera is not just a passive recorder of events, and photography does not merely reflect culture. It can provide vision and drive social and political change. For example, the cultural changes of the Italian Renaissance were influenced by the development of perspective, which brought new visual representation methods. Similarly, photography has contributed to the media culture of our era and has played a role in bringing the world's harsh realities to the coffee table.

**How to Write Poetry**

Writing poetry is like navigating a minefield: you need spontaneity, but one wrong move can disrupt everything. Claiming to know everything about poetry is risky, so instead, I suggest that beginners focus on reading widely, writing a lot, and freeing their imagination and spirit, without descending into chaos. Some people need stability to write, while others find inspiration in difficult times. Some follow a schedule; others wait for inspiration. All approaches are valid as long as they are not just following a set formula. The key is to find your own voice, nurture it, and let it grow until it can stand on its own.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, there is no space for too many characters or lengthy narratives. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if necessary to clarify an issue. A character's memory can effectively move the story forward, but it should never slow down the action. Dialogue is more useful than many writers realize, as it can present different perspectives quickly and keep the reader engaged. Overwriting can ruin a short story, but brevity should not reduce it to a mere summary. Conflict and action must be as strong as in a novel, but every word must count in a short story.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is similar to playing chess. Many chess players move without knowing the outcome, seeing only a few moves ahead. Over time, they realize that chess relies more on long-term strategy than short-term tactics. They start to see the game as a whole, noticing patterns like openings, middle games, and end games. Similarly, the more you write screenplays, the more you understand their complexities.

**Looking at Writing**

Charles Darwin noted that humans have an instinct to speak, but not to write. Language is universal across societies, but writing systems have been invented only a few times in history. Languages change but do not become more complex. All children learn to speak without formal lessons, but writing is a skill that must be taught. Unlike language, writing is not instinctive and requires effort to learn. Understanding how writing works and how children learn it is crucial for teaching it effectively.

I have never started a novel with more uncertainty. I call it a novel only because I don't know what else to name it. I have little story to tell, and it doesn't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader hanging. This book is made up of my memories of a man I met only occasionally, and I know little about what happened to him in between. I could invent details to fill the gaps and make the story more coherent, but I don't want to do that. I just want to share what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have given the characters in this story made-up names, and I've taken care to ensure no one can recognize them. The man I'm writing about is not famous. He might never be. When his life ends, he might leave no more trace than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the water's surface. Then, if my book is read at all, it will be for its own interest. But perhaps his chosen way of life and his unique character might influence others, so that, long after his death, people might realize a remarkable person lived in this age. Then it will be clear who I am writing about, and those interested in his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book, despite its limitations, will be a helpful source for my friend's biographers. I don't claim that the conversations I've recorded are exact. I never took notes, but I have a good memory for what matters to me, and though I've put these conversations in my own words, I believe they accurately reflect what was said. I mentioned earlier that I haven't invented anything, but I've taken the liberty, like historians do, to put words into the mouths of people in my story that I didn't hear myself. I've done this to make the scenes lively and realistic, as they would be dull if just recounted. I want to be read, and I think I'm justified in making my book engaging. The intelligent reader will easily see where I've used this technique and can choose to ignore it. Another reason for my hesitation in writing this book is that the people I write about are from another culture. It's very hard to truly know people, and I don't think you can really know anyone but your own countrymen. People are not just themselves; they are also shaped by where they were born, the homes they grew up in, the games they played, the food they ate, the schools they attended, the sports they followed, and the poets they read. These things make them who they are, and you can't know them just by hearing about them; you have to live them. You can only know if you are them. Because you can't fully know people from another nation except by observing them, it's hard to make them believable in a book. I've never tried to write about anyone but my own countrymen, and if I've done so in short stories, it's because you can treat characters more briefly there. You give the reader broad hints and let them fill in the details. In this book, I don't claim that my characters see themselves as I see them; they are seen through my eyes, just like the main character.

**POETRY RECITALS**

Throughout history, the literary world often seems confusing to those experiencing it. It's only later that patterns and rankings become clear. Today, poetry is especially complex, with many styles, debates, and ideas about the poet's role in society. Generally, there is a divide between 'literary' poets, who write for reading, and 'popular' poets, who prefer performing their work. However, this division isn't strict. Public poetry readings have become more common over the past twenty years. These events happen in various places, from small town halls to schools and arts festivals.

For 'pop' poets, who write for live audiences, public performances are beneficial. Their work is simple and easy to understand when heard. However, on the page, their work may seem less impressive. In contrast, poets dedicated to traditional craft, who aim to pack deep meaning and rhythm into their work, may not be fully appreciated in a single hearing. They might feel pressured to read their simpler works to connect with the audience quickly.

Listening to poetry readings is not a replacement for reading poetry, but it can be a helpful addition. Hearing poets read their work can show where emphasis should be placed, but it's best if the audience has the text or knows the poems beforehand. The main benefit of popular poetry recitals, sometimes mixed with music, is that they make poetry enjoyable and accessible, not just for a select few.

**Oral History**

Historians increasingly use oral evidence, but this method has challenges. It's unrealistic to think that someone's account is a perfect reflection of past events. During an interview, both the historian and the informant influence each other. The historian chooses the informant and the topic, and even if they just listen, their presence affects how the informant remembers and talks about the past. The final account is shaped by the historian's social status compared to the informant and the way the historian has learned to interpret history, which might influence the informant. Historians must acknowledge their role in creating new evidence. Even without the historian, the informant's memories are not directly connected to the past. Memories can be influenced by other sources, like the media, or altered by nostalgia or later life experiences. Emotions and attitudes in the testimony can seem convincing but might be influenced by events after the period being discussed.

**Animal Science**

Animal science has two main approaches: physiological and whole animal. Physiologists focus on how the body functions, such as how nerves and muscles work together to create behavior. The whole animal approach looks at the behavior of the entire animal and the factors affecting it. Within this approach, psychologists and ethologists are distinguished. Psychologists usually study learning in a few species, like rats and pigeons, in labs. Ethologists study natural, unlearned behavior in animals, often in the wild. Although these fields are merging, physiologists claim their methods are more fundamental. However, understanding nerve cell functions doesn't eliminate the need to study behavior at a broader level. Behavior has its own structure and units for study. Describing a bird's nest-building by nerve cell actions is like trying to read a book page with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

New social science students face a dual challenge: learning the subject's content and its methodology. They must understand both the knowledge in textbooks and the methods used to gather and organize this knowledge, which is the subject's logical foundation. These elements are closely linked. While social life seems familiar from daily experiences, social sciences go beyond common sense. Each discipline focuses on a specific aspect of social life, uses particular study methods, and has its own concepts. These concepts form the subject's logical basis, allowing social scientists to surpass everyday understanding and differentiate one discipline from another.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building structures. According to the Roman architect Vitruvius, architecture involves order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. Some of these terms have Greek origins, likely from earlier Greek sources now lost. Utility and function are not part of this definition, though Vitruvius later discusses the best forms for different structures. Initially, the focus is on aesthetics, viewing architecture as an art. Classical architecture has complex origins, with a long history of basic construction in Greece and Italy. These simple structures didn't meet Vitruvius' artistic standards but contributed essential elements to later architectural concepts. Despite its elaborate appearance, the classical temple is essentially a simple, single-roomed hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the allotments, the railway line, and the gasworks, even jumping a small bridge with all four wheels off the ground, which was her only mistake. Despite this, Chen was amused when he found out. "So you can really drive, Lily? Well done!" he said. Mui thought men were strange; Chen should have been upset, but instead, he was excited and started planning a trip with Lily. They decided on a Monday at the start of the next month, the quietest day of the week, to leave early and return by midday, so they wouldn't lose any customers. Meanwhile, Lily practiced driving around the allotments. Mui, despite her doubts, bought a road map and got a ten percent discount, which impressed Chen. Lily felt a bit insulted by Mui's lack of trust in her navigation skills.

On the day of the trip, they left home and soon reached the English Channel. Lily drove perfectly, even overtaking a few slow vehicles with great skill, which Mui, sitting in the back, had to admit. Chen even applauded. After passing through the gasworks of a seaside town, they drove along the empty promenade. Lily parked in a street with empty parking bays, unsure of the road markings, and preferred to pay a fee rather than risk being towed or fined. She locked all the van doors carefully. "Don't worry," Chen joked, "No one will want that heap of tin." The sisters were annoyed. Lily accused Chen of being ungrateful, and Mui scolded him for being too easily fooled by appearances. Surprised, Chen took their son, Man Kee, to look at the sea. He lifted Man Kee onto the railing and held him. Man Kee, warm and increasingly responsive, put his small hand on Chen's sleeve. In that moment, Chen decided to raise Man Kee his way, ensuring he got a good education and grew up to own many restaurants.

The sight of the sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future. He saw a ship on the horizon and used a telescope to look at it. At first, he couldn't find it, but then he saw it clearly: a small, old tramp steamer. He lifted Man Kee to the eyepiece. "Do you see the ship, Son?" he asked. "It's a special ship for people like us. It will take us back home when we're done here." Chen kissed Man Kee's head. Lily and Mui joined them. Chen said, "Let your mother see, Son." But Man Kee didn't want to let go of the telescope, and by the time he did, the ship was out of sight. All Lily could see was a circle of white light. When Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and Lily only saw seagulls following the ship's wake.

Text: 'THE WELL I had read somewhere that if you looked up from a deep hole, you could see the stars during the day. I convinced you to help me test this idea. You watched nervously as I pulled up the well bucket, steadied it, and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I hadn't considered how much heavier the bucket would be with me in it, or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You tried to hold the handle, but as soon as the bucket left the well's edge, I fell. You screamed and tried to stop the handle, but then let go. I hit my head. At that moment, I didn't realize I had, in a way, achieved my goal. I saw strange lights, like the stars and planets in cartoons when a character gets hit. I was first dazed, then scared, then relieved, and finally angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down, asking if I was okay. I was about to shout back when you called again, sounding more panicked, which stopped me. I lay still, watching you through my eyelashes. You ran off to get help. I quickly climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows near the moat bridge. I could hear alarmed voices from the castle. Mother and Father appeared with you and old Arthur. Mother was frantic, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked pale and shocked. I felt a mix of excitement and fear. Then I noticed the trail of water drops I had left from the well to where I was hiding. I was horrified that no one had seen them. Father was shining a flashlight into the well. The drops glistened in the sunlight. Mother was screaming, a sound that shook me deeply. I realized this prank had gone too far and would lead to serious consequences. I regretted not thinking it through. From a clever plan to disaster in minutes. Desperate, I left my hiding place, pretending to be weak and disoriented. I cried out, then collapsed dramatically. Comforted by my weeping mother, I claimed I had found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and escaped through it. I thought I might get away with it until Father asked me to repeat my story. I hesitated, and his eyes narrowed. Trying to cover my lie, I said the tunnel had collapsed, making it pointless to search for it. Father looked at me with disbelief, as if seeing me for the first time. His words were filled with contempt. He walked away, leaving me with Arthur, who looked at me with pity and concern for my character. His silent rebuke was as painful as my father's words, making me realize the seriousness of my actions.'

**REMOVAL DAY**

Susan, now a widow, is leaving her family home as her children have grown up. The moving van, labeled 'Removers of Distinction', was taking away everything that made the house unique. Fred, the removal man, with his large, gentle hands, was carefully packing fragile items, while his team was less gentle. The house was beautiful, a four-storey building with a view of a small harbour. Memories of her children growing up lingered in the air like dust. Susan recalled when Robert, at five, asked how they would bring the house home after buying it. Now an adult, Robert was helping with the move, ensuring Susan didn't mention the piano. Francesca, her daughter, was also there, insisting she handle the Steinway piano herself.

Fred noted that Susan didn't seem like she would cry, which surprised her. He explained that people often cry when they see their home being dismantled, though they feel better at the new place. Susan could understand this. She would have warned the movers about the piano, but Robert insisted it was their responsibility to notice any issues. The piano, a prized possession, was in the best room of the house and would be moved last.

Sitting on the stairs, as all the chairs were gone, Susan remembered when they first moved in. The piano had been the first item brought in, but it got stuck on the stairs. The movers struggled for hours, and young Francesca was distraught, insisting they couldn't live without a piano. Her husband, Peter, had resolved the crisis by hiring a builder to remove a window and using a crane to bring the piano in. This process was costly, delaying the piano's tuning for months. Peter had declared the piano would stay forever, but forever is a long time. The children visited less often, and Susan found the stairs challenging.

As the movers prepared to take the piano, Susan felt anxious. Fred reassured her, and Robert and Francesca watched from the hallway. Susan was on the verge of tears, realizing how moving things made them significant. But when the piano was successfully moved out, they all burst into laughter, relieved. As they left the house arm in arm, Susan's only tears were from laughter.

Text: 'Online Literary Criticism For Everyone

Do-it-yourself literary criticism: more than just harmless fun? From the beginning, the idea of open access to the Internet was a key principle. In theory, anyone could publish a manifesto or start a music channel online. In practice, though, some technical skills were needed, especially in the early days. However, one area that was truly opened to everyone was literary criticism. By visiting Amazon.com, the first popular online bookstore, anyone could try their hand at reviewing books. Amazon's approach to book reviews was simple: anyone could share their opinion and rate a book up to five stars. This seemed like a brilliant idea. Each book had its own page on Amazon's site, and new reviews appeared automatically. This allowed Amazon to fill its pages with free reviews, and potential buyers could see what other readers thought, rather than just reading the publisher's blurb or professional critics' opinions. Other online bookstores with physical stores offered similar features. But as the largest player, with over 80% of the online market, Amazon initially had the most customers, attracted the most reviews, and faced the most issues. This open review system led to various kinds of misuse. Thousands of reviews were submitted daily - Amazon wouldn't say exactly how many - so it was impractical to check them all. Instead, a team of editors reviewed the site, ensuring reviews followed the company's guidelines. Single-word reviews, personal attacks on the author, obscenities, spoilers, or references to other reviews were not allowed. However, reviewers were anonymous (they didn't have to use their real names), and offending reviews were removed only if Amazon's editors noticed them. This left room for mischief. For example, writers could give their own books glowing reviews. One writer, Lev Grossman, was so upset by bad reviews of his first novel ('infantile trash', 'puerile pap') that he submitted several anonymous positive ones ('hilarious', 'fabulous') to balance things out. His trick worked until he wrote an article about his deception. The fake reviews were then removed. Authors could also comment on their books by clicking a link marked 'I am the Author, and I wish to comment on my book.' Most authors used this feature to post friendly messages hoping readers would buy and enjoy their book. Some even shared their email addresses, inviting direct communication. However, Amazon did not verify that these comments truly came from the author, except for well-known writers. A little-known writer submitted a comment pretending to be from John Updike, admitting to being a 'talented but ultimately over-hyped middlebrow author'. Unsurprisingly, it was deemed fake and removed. Still, the real drama came from readers, not writers. When James McElroy's We've Got Spirit, about a small-town cheerleading team, was published, it was well received by the mainstream press. But many people mentioned in it felt betrayed, and Amazon's page for the book became an outlet for their anger. Dozens of critical reviews were submitted, only to disappear a few days later. Despite this, Amazon saw the high number of reviews as good for business. Since readers' reviews were meant to be a 'forum to talk about a book' rather than a chat room, a close watch was kept on bestselling books to ensure reviews followed the rules. This meant that the best place to post a silly review was on a page for a less well-known book. The Story about Ping, a classic children's book about a duck named Ping, inspired much geek humor because 'ping' is also a software utility used to measure Internet congestion. One long review drew an elaborate analogy between the book's plot and Internet architecture, concluding that the book provided a 'good high-level overview' of basic networking concepts. Such silliness was rare. Most reader reviews on Amazon.com were taken seriously by their writers. Overall, the reviews gave a remarkably accurate indication of whether a particular book was worth buying. The writer George Orwell once complained that 'reviewing too many books involved constantly inventing reactions towards books about which one has no spontaneous feelings whatever'. This makes the democratization of the review process seem like a good thing.'

**Art in Modern Times**

Over the last two hundred years, we have started to believe that every artist must rebel against the art of their time. We praise art for being unique, revolutionary, and even shocking. We admire artists whose work was not appreciated a hundred years ago. However, when it comes to contemporary art, we often hesitate and say an artist has gone too far, questioning if it can still be called art. The media often voices these doubts for us, and we tend to agree because we expect art to be puzzling and new. This expectation makes us overlook the old themes, methods, and virtues present in modern art. We see artists as separate from the rest of us, with special talents and energy that cannot be contained by conventions. In the past, people commissioned art for specific purposes, integrating it into their daily lives. Today, we leave artists to their own devices and get annoyed if they try to step down from their creative heights.

**Picture This**

I will describe a situation and then ask an important question about it. An artist selects a piece of text from an art book. The text questions the diversity of pictures, asking, "What are they all about?" and concludes, "There is no end to the number of different kinds of pictures." The artist then asks someone to prepare a canvas and take it to a sign painter. The sign painter is instructed to write the chosen text on the canvas in simple black letters, without any flashy or charming effects. The sign painter completes the task. My crucial question is: Is the finished product a painting?

**Underground Encounters**

At the Mercury Gallery, London until 26th June

In the art world, it is often expected that once a painter finds success in a particular style, they should stick to it. Collectors expect consistency, and attempts to change direction are often met with disappointment. Gallery owners prefer safe bets, and the art-buying public may find comfort in continuity. However, some artists break this mold and succeed, like Picasso and Hockney. Eric Rimmington is another artist challenging expectations. His new show moves away from the still lifes that made him famous to paintings of the London Underground. Railways have always fascinated Rimmington. After drawing the railway land of London's Kings Cross Station in the 1980s, he logically moved underground to explore what happens below. These sketches inspired "Underground Encounters," an exhibition of 40 paintings and drawings capturing the unique magic of this underground world designed for people in transit.

**Extract from a Novel**

I have come to this island with a few books. I use the word 'escape' because the villagers jokingly say only a sick person would choose such a remote place to rebuild. So, I am here to heal myself, if you want to put it that way. Apart from an old peasant woman who comes from the village each day to clean the house, I am alone. I am neither happy nor unhappy; I feel suspended like a hair or a feather in the cloudy mixtures of memory. I spoke of the uselessness of art but did not mention its consolations. The comfort of my work as a painter or writer lies in the ability to reorder and rework reality, revealing its significant side. Our everyday actions are like a sackcloth covering the cloth-of-gold, the true meaning of the pattern. For artists, art offers a joyful compromise with all that has hurt or defeated us in daily life. It allows us to fulfill our destiny through imagination, rather than evading it like ordinary people. Otherwise, why should we hurt one another?

Text: 'Family Business'

"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were driving back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from the posh girls' school I attended. He had also just sat through Parent's Day, where I received the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my exams. After a long talk with my headteacher, we were heading home for the holidays.

"What isn't?" I asked, though I had guessed what he was thinking from his unusual silence. He was usually very talkative. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you'll get a scholarship to Oxford."

"So?" I said, trying to be bold. "Mightn't that be useful?"

"I also hear," he continued, and I knew a confrontation was coming, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.

"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"

"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can quickly understand a lot of information, you can talk well, and you enjoy performing."

"I don't know about that," I said. "All I know is what I see in TV dramas."

"Be that as it may," he continued, "I feel your heart's never going to be in the business now. Obviously, you'll go to Oxford University, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."

The problem was that, like many children of family businesses, I felt trapped by family expectations. I saw other career options and wanted to explore them. At the same time, I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him intimidating.

"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.

"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was often right about such things, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."

"There's still Maurice," I said, sulking. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.

"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a sort of consultant."

My mother wasn't around to help - she had died early in my childhood, and my father raised Maurice and me. Maurice was two years younger, and because he was motherless, I got into the habit of taking care of him. It wasn't a hardship. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived in luxury - a big house in London, posh schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew all kinds of people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was full of interesting conversations and encounters.

"I tell you what," my father continued. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then if you decide to leave us, you can. It will give you some pocket money and be a real help to me."

"OK," I said, relieved to avoid immediate decisions and especially the depression and sulks my father would fall into if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.

So it happened. In my last term at school, and then during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on the safer tasks. I became one of the smarter undergraduates, with a little house of my own, a small but powerful white car, designer clothes, and a black dress with a Paris label that I planned to wear for my final exams.

In my last term, my father visited me and took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor predicted I would get a First Class degree in Law, and I knew that if I stayed focused, he might be right. I felt poised, confident, concentrated.

This was not to be. My father told me that, in about a week, he needed me for one last assignment, the most important business the family firm had ever attempted, and that it would be worth my while.

"But Dad," I protested, "I've got my final exams coming up, and I need to concentrate on that. It's really important that I do well, and I don't want to think about anything else right now."

I could tell that such pressures were beyond my father's imagination (or was he somehow jealous of my life away from him?) and that he would see a refusal as a betrayal in his hour of need. That was not all. As he described the procedures, I saw more clearly than ever his single-mindedness -- the clarity and resourcefulness with which he approached his work, his dynamic energy, his perfect self-control. In his way, he was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans and hopes seem less important.

"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being extremely careful with their money, which made it a poor decision. Initially, it seemed like a good idea because Simon had been successful in his legal cases, and Lois had returned to her job at an advertising agency shortly after their twins were born, receiving a raise to thirty-five thousand. Lois was the one who pushed for the move, arguing that their flat was too small for a family and that they needed more space, a garden, and a place for an au pair. These needs could have been met in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted more than just space. She felt their old address, Mornington Mansions, was not suitable for a rising barrister and a successful businesswoman. 

To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport, and since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube. This commute left him feeling resentful and thinking about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he had fond memories of being cared for after a long day. His grandmother had been a supportive 'lawyer's wife,' but times had changed. Lois made it clear before they married that her career was as important as his, and their lifestyle depended on both their incomes.

Now, their situation was threatened by Venetia, who had confronted Simon with intense anger. She accused him of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed jurors in a past case and of accepting shares for his fiancée. Simon denied the accusations, but his response was unconvincing even to himself. He felt guilty and remembered the fear of punishment from his school days. He wished he had been prepared and could have responded differently. Venetia's anger puzzled him, as he wondered why she felt the need to challenge his actions. He questioned whether her own conduct was flawless and feared that if the accusations spread, even as rumors, his career would be ruined.

I chose this place to live, thinking I would find anonymity among people who didn't mind if the rented houses' plaster, glass, and paintwork fell apart, or if the gardens were overgrown and the sofas were rotting. But, as with most things, I was wrong. People in the shops, who are living their real lives, even if you aren't, soon start to recognize you. The roses next door, spilling over the fence, remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, trying to forget that it's summer outside, but tonight, I'm watching the swifts fly in the clear space between the treetops and roofs. I've cleared some rosemary and lemon balm to make space for a chair, and my arms and hands are tingling with stings and scratches. It's a narrow London garden, where plants must grow tall or spread out to survive. 

"Been doing a bit of clearing, I see," says my upstairs neighbor, Jaz, leaning out of the window. She's the author of several unpublished manuscripts, which I sometimes have to pretend to like as an English teacher. I have a copy of her latest one now. "How's the work going, Jaz?" I ask. "For goodness' sake. In no other profession does one have to explain oneself a thousand times a day to everyone," she replies, her voice trailing off before picking up again. "Tell you what, Ann, I've got something to drink in the fridge. I'll bring it down." I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I now see that it looks messy and empty. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. "So, you're on holiday now, you lucky thing," she says, sprawling in shorts and a vest on the chair while I drop a cushion onto what used to be a little lawn. "Cheers," she says, pretending to be young. "I should've gone into teaching—a writer doesn't have holidays. Still, you know what they say, those who can, do; those who can't, teach." And there are those who can neither write nor teach. "So, what plans for the holidays?" All my postponed dread of the school year's end overwhelms me. Empty days. Hot pavements with melting chewing gum. The walk to the shops and back. The little park with its fountain, and loneliness sitting beside me on the bench. "Actually, I'm going down to Stonebridge tomorrow. I've been meaning to ask you if you'd feed the cats." My heart races as I speak. "Of course I will," Jaz says. "If I'm around," knowing, as I did, that she would be. "So where will you stay? Some fancy B and B?" "No. I'll be staying with my oldest friend, Ruby, at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight." It's not true that I will stay there, but then I spend my life dealing with fiction of one sort or another. "Going back to your roots. So what do you think of it so far? My opus?" My silence on the subject has forced Jaz to ask about her manuscript, The Cruelty of Red Vans, which lies half-read on my desk. I like the title and tell her so. I can see how red vans could be cruel, always bringing presents and mail-order goodies to other houses and delivering returned manuscripts in silly bags to hers. Something prompts me to speak honestly for once. "Let me give you a little tip, dear," I begin. "What?" She is offended. "Try writing about nice people for a change, pretty people who at least aspire to being good: a touch less self-centeredness, a bit more fiction..." "Teachers!" Jaz is like a rebellious schoolgirl about to snatch back a poorly marked essay. "I myself keep a journal, I have for years, in which I write down something good, however small or trivial, about each day." My words sound as old-fashioned as my print dress. "Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann." Oh, I've got a life. I've got my work, and I go out sometimes and fly home again, sitting on the tube with my nose in a book. When we finally go inside, my calm kitchen gives a moment's reassurance, then out of the blue comes the image of my school geography teacher Miss Tarrantine, who must have been about the age I am now, closing an ancient reptilian eyelid in a monstrous wink as she tells us, "I've had my moments." We nearly died.

**Heritage**

Heritage connects people and communities to the past. We often feel linked to our personal heritage, knowing about our grandparents and their lives. Beyond this, there is a broader need to understand our past to help us interpret our individual and national futures. Heritage represents a desire for continuity; understanding the past helps assure our future. Just as you inherit genes, you also inherit a culture passed down through generations. There may be parts of your national heritage you dislike, but it is yours, and it is comforting to belong to something. Heritage teaches us a lot and is essential for our well-being, influencing everything from customs to material culture. Traditionally, our link to the past was through stories and legends from our ancestors. However, Western industrial society disrupted communities and families, leading to the loss of much oral tradition. Now, places and architectural 'memories' provide clues to our past. It is crucial to conserve and restore these links as a testament to our ancestors' identity.

**The Fens**

I started a novel, "Waterland," where the landscape of the Fens in England became significant. People often ask why I, a Londoner with no personal connection, chose to write about this area. The short answer is that I chose the Fens for their apparent simplicity—a flat and empty stage for my book's drama. However, I learned that the Fens are neither flat nor empty. They are as richly English as any other part of England but also strangely compelling and haunting. It is remarkable that in the middle of England, there is a region that many English people find foreign, especially when other distinctive areas of Britain have been absorbed into the nation's cultural and literary heritage. The Fens are both empty and full, cultivated and wild, seemingly open and obvious yet deeply mysterious. My research for the novel was not extensive; I have not visited places like Wisbech or Prickwillow. As a fiction writer, I am interested in imagined worlds and prefer inspired guesses over documentary proof. Imagining the Fens has its logic, as Edward Storey's scholarly book shows, the Fens are not just a landscape but a state of mind.

**Museums**

Museums must make their collections accessible. In the past, this meant displaying items with lengthy labels that were hard for the average person to understand. Today, accessibility requires more. Displays can be lively and interesting, using theatrical or architectural techniques to capture visitors' attention and evoke emotions. Museums should do more than just display items; they should make collections accessible to the widest community. Loan boxes for teachers are one example, and some museums now offer similar materials for elderly people with memory loss. Museums focus on 'artefacts and specimens'—not replicas. They provide encounters with authenticity, presenting items that existed and had meaning in history. This is their strength, distinguishing them from heritage centers, theme parks, books, and CD-ROMs. Museums that embrace this challenge and offer exciting displays, catalogues, and outreach programs will find that their competitors in 'virtual history' are actually allies, stimulating interest in the 'real thing' that only museums can satisfy.

**Architecture and Environment**

The desire to preserve things is not new, but now changes in our towns happen so quickly and on such a large scale that most of us are affected. This turns some people into strong preservationists and encourages others to think more about the nature of towns today and their future. It can be argued that generations who have lived through events like world wars are more inclined to preserve than those before them—anything expressing stability becomes important. If there is a psychological need for preservation, planners must consider it. Change is not an enemy if we learn to manage it. Physical change in our towns reflects social change—changes in our population, welfare, and demands.

**Einstein**

If you ask someone on the street to name a scientist, they will likely mention Albert Einstein. His image is often used to promote products related to intelligence, like computers and encyclopedias. Most people know little about his work, except that he developed theories called 'relativity', which are known for being hard to understand and making strange predictions that seem to contradict everyday experiences. Einstein was part of a major shift in scientific thought, marking the start of modern science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to create a new, more logical description of the universe by studying the relationships between matter and natural forces. Einstein made significant contributions by re-examining the basics: time, space, matter, and energy. Earlier explanations relied on Isaac Newton's idea of a universe where stars and planets moved within a fixed framework of space and time. Einstein challenged this idea, proposing that time and space are not absolute but relative.

**Young Readers**

During our childhood, Lydia and I were skeptical of any book that won a prize because we assumed it would be 'worthy', which we equated with 'boring'. While our mother disapproved of our lack of appreciation in a disdainful manner, our father would happily offer us small amounts of money, chapter by chapter, to encourage us to read an occasional educational book. He would also sneak in a few high-quality books among our Christmas and birthday gifts, marked with a bold label, 'This Book is NOT Literature'. Although we dismissed most of his selections as 'boys' books', he did manage to introduce us to some shorter works of good fiction and, on one occasion, a well-known collection of poetry.

**Language**

"The origin of human language is truly secret and marvellous," wrote Jacob Grimm in 1851. This mysterious origin has inspired many strange theories. In 1928, Charles Caller suggested that early humans might have made sounds like "meuh" when sensing danger. "Meuh" has a sad tone. Humans wandering through dangerous lands filled with fearsome creatures made desperate sounds, and languages have kept some echo of these cries, like the word malaria meaning "fever" or the Latin mors meaning "death". Due to such odd speculations, many avoided the topic, seeing it as a field for eccentrics. However, recently, the origin and evolution of language have become important research areas. Language likely developed in East Africa around 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly interaction and played a key role in power dynamics. Sharing information was probably not its original purpose, contrary to philosopher John Locke's view of language as a 'great conduit' for conveying knowledge.

Text: 'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode explores the art of writing reviews from a reviewer's perspective. Most reviews are created and shared under conditions that ensure they have a very short lifespan. There are deadlines and strict limits on their length. Once published, they remain relevant only as long as the newspaper or magazine they appear in—usually a day, a week, or at most a month. The temporary nature of reviews often defines their literary value. It's commonly believed, not just by the public but sometimes by the reviewers themselves, that reviewing is a task done out of necessity—often due to financial need or because one cannot work on a novel or a 'serious' book all day. However, reviewing is a skilled and complex job. Writing a concise and fair review in six to eight hundred words for a newspaper is different from crafting a detailed six to eight thousand-word piece for an international journal. A fifteen hundred-word article in a weekly magazine presents challenges of both short and long formats. Length isn't the only factor. Reviewers must consider their audience, ranging from casual weekend readers to those deeply interested in the subject. A reviewer must know a lot about various topics and write in a way that intelligent readers can understand and enjoy. This often means the reviewer also writes other types of work. The American novelist John Updike, who views criticism as 'hugging the shore,' still enjoys writing reviews between his major novels. He collects all his reviews, even the short ones, into books with modest titles. While some might think lesser-known writers should accept the temporary nature of their reviews, it's understandable if they seek some permanence and recognition, especially if they believe their best work is in their reviews. I feel this way about my own work. My main job has been academic, and most of my serious books are academic, the kind professors are expected to write. Fortunately, in the English-speaking world, there isn't a strict separation between reviewing and literary study, so it's common for the same people to do both. The days when academics criticized professors for writing reviews are mostly over, as are complaints from non-professors about professors taking their opportunities. This is partly because there are more reviews now, so there's enough work for everyone, and partly because the rewards are often modest. I believe this situation benefits both readers, who can trust the reviewer knows the subject, and professors, as it helps them stay grounded. It also reminds them to communicate clearly with non-professors. While they might use complex language among themselves, they need to be clear when addressing intelligent non-professors. Ultimately, reviewing is a secondary occupation. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph unlocked the door to his apartment and, as he entered the dark, still hallway, felt a brief moment of doubt about owning it. Even after three years, this feeling sometimes came over him when he returned home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the flat, he would come home eagerly, often as early as possible, curious about what the flat had been like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about intruders or leaks, but the flat always seemed to be waiting for him, either tidy or messy, depending on how he left it. Over time, he began to see it as an extension of himself, a space filled with his thoughts and feelings. He became frustrated with its inability to change. Occasionally, there would be a small pile of letters by the door or a blinking light on the answering machine, signs of life in his absence. He was thankful that the windows hadn't been broken or the contents disturbed, though he wondered what it would look like if they were. From his dull office on Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his three or four quiet evenings at home each week. Once he left the artificial world of the office and felt himself returning on the bus ride home, he no longer needed to be alone, a fact he often overlooked in his social plans. At his desk, he longed for solitude and time with his belongings, but the relief of leaving work left him empty, waiting for a sense of self to return. Instead, he felt a deep emptiness, making him suspect that working in a job that didn't suit him had changed him, moving him away from who he thought he was. He would often read or listen to music as the night grew darker, but now he questioned why he did these things. His sense of direction was unclear, and his thoughts and feelings seemed to get lost in his mind. There was a time, he thought, when he didn't feel this powerless, when he might have escaped if he had recognized his own worth. But he had been eager to settle into something and followed the first path that seemed right. After university, he tried to plan for a better future, but he wasn't surprised to find that he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends, following their paths without imagining a role that would make him happy. He attended his only job interview with gratitude and didn't think to evaluate the position—a vague editorial role at a free local newspaper. He was relieved to have a pleasant conversation with Neil, his boss, and didn't consider the future interactions he would face. Neil offered him the job on the spot, saying Ralph was the only graduate who applied, which Ralph took as a compliment at the time.

**Goat Racing**

I was about to see goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. I pushed through crowds, ice-cream vans, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was heading to the racecourse, and I tried to find a good spot. A section was marked off for the race. It wasn't like professional racecourses, but the idea was the same: spectators stood on either side of the track. Organizers were trying to keep a few goats in line, which is not easy since goats are known to eat almost anything.

**Canoe Trip**

As the day ended, I worried about the night ahead. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our torch to see the cliffs, but the batteries were dying. We replaced them, but the new ones didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. A few miles later, Lesley thought she saw a light, and we got hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard the loud noise of fast water, but we couldn't see what was happening. Time seemed to stop as we continued.

**How to be Presentation Perfect - we answer your questions**

I am not naturally good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I often have to present to my colleagues and major shareholders. How can I improve my presentation skills and confidence?

You're not alone. Presenting requires different skills than running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. To convince your audience, you must believe in what you're saying. Show your conviction with passion and enthusiasm. This means you need to prepare well. Test your ideas in advance and ask colleagues to think of tough questions the audience might ask. Start your presentation by finding common ground with your audience and build towards your conclusion.

Some activities cannot be rushed; they take the time they need. If you're late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you rush making mayonnaise by adding oil too quickly, it will curdle. Similarly, if you pull too hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot tightens. The mind also works at different speeds. Some mental tasks are quick, while others take longer—seconds, minutes, hours, days, or even years. Some tasks can be sped up, like solving puzzles or doing mental math. However, others cannot be rushed without breaking down, like the mayonnaise, or getting tangled, like the fishing line. Demanding quick results can be as counterproductive as trying to sleep in half the time. We learn, think, and understand in various ways, each operating at different speeds and suited to different tasks. "He who hesitates is lost," says one proverb. "Look before you leap," says another. Both are true. The mind has three processing speeds. The first is faster than thought, requiring immediate, instinctive reactions. For example, when my motorbike skidded on a wet road, my brain and body reacted instantly to keep me safe, and only afterward did my conscious mind catch up. Concert pianists and Olympic fencers also rely on this fast, instinctive intelligence, which we might call "wits." The second speed involves deliberate thinking, where we figure things out, weigh pros and cons, and solve problems. A mechanic diagnosing an engine issue, a scientist interpreting results, or a student tackling an assignment all use this logical, conscious thinking, often called "intellect." People good at this are considered "bright" or "clever." The third speed is slower and less focused, more playful or dreamy. In this mode, we ruminate or mull things over, being contemplative or meditative. Sitting by the sea, lost in the sound of the waves, or hovering between sleep and wakefulness, we are in a different mental state than when planning a meal or writing a letter. This slow, seemingly aimless way of thinking is just as intelligent as the faster ones. Allowing the mind to wander is not a luxury to cut back on when life gets busy. On the contrary, slow thinking is essential. We need the "tortoise mind" as much as the "hare brain." Some problems are better solved with a slow mind. Recent studies show that patient, less deliberate thinking is suited to understanding complex, unclear situations. Deliberate thinking works well for straightforward problems, like choosing a holiday destination. But when we don't know what to consider or which questions to ask, or when issues are too subtle for conscious thought, we need the tortoise mind. For complex decisions, like managing a difficult team or changing careers, pondering may be more effective than searching for quick solutions. This type of intelligence is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets have long recognized the limits of conscious thinking and embraced slower, deeper ways of knowing. Philosophers have explored the mind's realms beyond conscious intellect. Recently, scientists have begun studying these slower ways of knowing. Cognitive science shows that the unconscious mind can accomplish complex tasks if given time. It can learn subtle patterns, understand complex situations, and solve difficult issues better than conscious thought.

Surviving in a Foreign Land I have been warmly welcomed. It's a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very remote place. At any time, there are about forty people - scientists, students, weather experts, satellite trackers - forming a close community where everyone helps out. My basic French is just enough to communicate, but not to have casual conversations. I miss the subtle meanings, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. This isn't a practical problem for me, but at first, it affected my self-confidence. I found myself slightly dreading mealtimes. I would hesitate, unsure which table to choose, worried about the silence when I spoke, anxious in a way I haven't felt since my first weeks at school. I still smile awkwardly or panic when people talk to me. I think the reason for this occasional sadness isn't about missing company or communication; it's because I've lost the social advantage my ability to talk has always given me. Elliot When I first met Elliot, I was just a young author like any other, and he didn't pay much attention to me. He never forgot a face, though, and when I saw him again, he would shake hands with me politely but didn't try to get to know me better. If I saw him at the opera with someone important, he tended to ignore me. But then I had a surprising success as a playwright, and I noticed that Elliot started to show more interest in me. One day, he sent me a note inviting me to lunch, and I thought he was testing me. After that, since my success brought me many new friends, I began to see him more often. Alfred Hitchcock The film director Alfred Hitchcock always said he didn't care about the story of his films or the acting, but he did care about the photography, the soundtrack, and all the technical details. For Hitchcock, it wasn't a message or a great performance that moved the audience; he believed people are affected by pure film, no matter their cultural background. So, if a film is made correctly, in terms of its emotional impact, audiences from Japan and India should react at the same moment. Hitchcock's view of himself was always clear, logical, and hard to argue with. He was a man of reason and a genius craftsman who enjoyed hearing an audience scream. He didn't deal with speculation, abstract ideas, or intellectual hints, and his view of his own film characters wasn't deep. He focused on film, pure film, and the precise, calculated beauty of what a strip of film can do to an audience.

**Amateur Astronomy**

Astronomy has changed a lot in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts or catalogues. Telescopes were basic, and there were few books on how to do astronomy. Now, you can buy almost any telescope or equipment you need. Electronic calculators and computers have transformed how we make charts and analyze observations. This might seem like the best time for amateur astronomy. However, some things have been lost. You might need to travel 80 km to find a sky as clear as it was in cities 50 years ago. Daytime skies are often filled with aircraft trails that can last for hours, forming clouds that make it hard to observe the sun and stars.

**Too Much Choice**

Society today has too many choices. There are too many things to do and too many options. In the modern economy, people are always looking for the next new product or service. Technology speeds up this change, creating more noise and more choices. As soon as a new product is available, another one is ready to launch. This can be overwhelming and stressful, leading to a feeling of disconnect from life. More choices mean more stress, less time, and more complexity. People are now looking for 'simplexity'—simple things that bring meaning in a complex world. But simplifying life is hard when there are so many products and services. There are more brands of detergent and cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can follow.

**McAndrews Hotel**

Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. This is a family tradition started by my grandmother, and it has become very important to us. Nothing can interfere with this ritual. The guests at McAndrews are similar: old-fashioned, perhaps a bit odd, and some might say snobbish. I dislike the rude behavior of shop assistants that is common today, and I don't like overly friendly waiters who seem like they might slap you on the back. I know most of the other guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children, like me. But I can be sure that when I see them around the hotel, we will only exchange polite greetings. Such respect for dignity and privacy is rare in commercial places these days.

**Othello**

The transfer of an outstanding production of Shakespeare's play *Othello* from Stratford to London gives me a chance to correct an unfair review I wrote when the show first opened last spring. At that time, I criticized Ray Fearon for being too young for the main role and underestimated his acting. I still believe that changing the age difference between Othello and Desdemona alters the tragedy, but I take back my criticism of Mr. Fearon's remarkable performance. In fact, the entire cast is excellent. Memorable scenes include Cassio's competitive games with other young officers, which become dangerously intense, and the moment when Iago starts to lose control and struggles to regain it. I challenge anyone not to be moved to tears during the scene where Emilia prepares Desdemona for bed. The pace and tension throughout are incredible. Do not miss this production.

**Lake Vostok**

In the heart of Antarctica, nothing moves. On the edges of the continent, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But on the vast white plateau in the interior, life does not exist. Except, that is, in a large hidden body of freshwater called Lake Vostok, which lies beneath nearly 4 kilometers of ice, directly below the coldest place on earth. The water has been cut off from air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are eager to explore its mysterious depths and find out what strange organisms live there. Geologists and glaciologists are also very interested. For two years, researchers worldwide have been planning how to uncover the lake's secrets, and if they succeed, the next few years will be known as the decade of Lake Vostok.

**Scientists**

There was an interesting discussion on the radio last week. It seems that a group of scientists is getting very excited about what motivates them to be scientists; the phrase "because it's there" comes to mind. We all know it's the age-old quest for knowledge, the desire to understand everything from atoms to black holes. But these scientists want to know why we want to know all of this in the first place and why science can't explain our curiosity. Surely, it's more important to know whether what we scientists are doing is right, rather than getting stuck in debates about the purpose of it all. I would have thought that the key issue here is not why we pursue it, but to recognize that science is a tool, and we are the ones who should decide how, where, when, and why to use it.

**Food**

Our connection with food is basic and fulfilling. Many people who enjoy cooking might already agree with this, as they often buy cookbooks like this one. We sometimes think that cooking is only worth it for special occasions or complex dishes. But that's not true. You can make a delicious soup by simply adding some chopped carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs to water. This is more satisfying than buying a packet or opening a can. Instead of purchasing a chocolate mousse filled with preservatives, you can make a delightful dessert in five minutes that both adults and children will love. Cooking is also a way to show care and love by bringing your own creation, no matter how simple, to the table. Sharing food is rich in symbolism and meets our deep human needs, which is why our celebrations often happen around tables, whether for birthdays, anniversaries, or engagements. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding or anniversary party, and few would discuss a business deal over canned soup.

**In the Elevator**

This morning, Alistair tried to tidy his office, but papers were still everywhere. Tax forms were overflowing from drawers and boxes, waiting for a day when he felt like filing. Owning an apartment building added even more paperwork. Books and journals were piled near the new bookshelves. As the elevator took him to his floor, he knew Mallory would be punctual for their meeting. She would knock on his office door exactly on time. She was as precise about time as she was about neatness. How would she react to the mess? She might think he had been robbed. He could pretend to be shocked when he walked in behind her. Mrs. Wilson, his cleaning lady, arrived while he was trying to clear some space on the carpet. He smiled at her hopefully as she unlocked his apartment door. Her look said she had no intention of cleaning his office. She believed he was from somewhere far away, not from her familiar world in Brooklyn.

**KAREN**

Karen's simple wish not to be like her mother led her to create her own story, one of difference and strength. In her personal tale, there were key moments, like when she was twelve and her brother accidentally hit her in the eye with a golf club. At first, she thought she was blind, but the bone protected her, as the doctor later explained. The club missed her eye, leaving only a few stitches that healed as a reminder of past pain. When she opened her eyes in the doctor's office and saw her mother talking about miracles and small mercies, she felt she was saved for a purpose.

**Miss Fogerty**

Miss Fogerty, walking quickly across the wet grass of the village green, felt both excited and sad about what she had just seen. It's thrilling to be the first to know something important, especially in a small community, and her quiet life had little excitement. But she was deeply saddened by Dr. Bailey's condition. He had been her doctor for many years, and she appreciated his care during her annual bouts of laryngitis, which were her only health issues. His most valuable trait, she thought, was making patients feel he had plenty of time and genuinely wanted to hear their concerns. This quality made him beloved in the village. He always gave his time, knowledge, and humor, earning loyalty and affection in return.

Joanna's Lessons

Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. Despite her hectic schedule, she has started writing books for young children learning the piano. Her performances are captivating, showcasing her incredible skill and energy. At a recent concert for children, after playing various styles like classical, jazz, and blues, a young boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." For Joanna, this was amusing, and she easily fulfilled the request, proving herself to the young audience.

Joanna is unique among top pianists because she is interested in how children learn the piano.
