However, by the late 1960s in Britain, these skills were nearly lost because heavy industry no longer needed them, and modern architecture rarely used elegant wrought-iron features. In the past decade, there has been a revival due to increased interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Despite this, much of the work seems clichéd, with manufacturers still promoting 'classical' or 'Victorian-style' gates and balconies. Trendy design stores often feature rusty candlesticks with decorative elements. Fortunately, there are alternatives, and upcoming events aim to promote the blacksmith's craft. The first event, an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says, 'We might be entering a new Iron Age, as both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently.' Power tools have freed blacksmiths from the hard labor of working over a hot anvil, allowing them to bend, split, twist, and weld metal more easily. 'In short,' says Dawson, 'these artists now have a material that lets them express themselves.' About 250 pieces are on display, ranging from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go into the thousands. Most of the money will go to the makers, but a portion will support the promotion of quality ironwork, says Dawson. His own works include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. 'My style comes from letting steel bend and flow when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space,' he says. Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike most metals, which are easy to shape when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging. Susan May, a jeweler, says, 'It's magical because it's very soft when hot, but becomes rigid when it cools.' Ann Catrin Evans' steel door-knockers and handles seem inspired by the castles in horror films. One design looks like a ball and chain, another like a Celtic cross. 'I love that steel is cold and hard,' she says. 'And it feels like it will last forever.' No other base metal has given people as much visual pleasure or a greater sense of security. Iron is likely to be used decoratively for the next thousand years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

Text: 'THE DAY I GAVE UP SMOKING I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my colleagues was very angry. 'What do you mean?' she shouted. 'If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?' I guess my inability to explain how one afternoon I was a pack-a-day smoker, and four hours later I was not, was a bit annoying. I find it strange myself. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy and it happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I hadn't planned to stop and I didn't even really want to. For one thing, I resented the constant pressure from anti-smoking groups - and I still do. For another, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and seemed to recover from colds more easily than friends with healthier lifestyles. On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about others trying to quit. 'I won't be trying to stop myself, it wouldn't be fair,' I said firmly. 'Since my reason for being here is writing, not quitting, it wouldn't be right to expect your method to work on me.' I thought I was being reasonable. After all, I really enjoyed smoking. It gave me real pleasure. I thought the counsellor looked at me knowingly. We were encouraged to smoke as much as we wanted and most of the afternoon was in a room so filled with smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed with interest that when I was told to smoke, I was reluctant to do so -- and so were the others. I suppose what happened was that the stop-smoking messages made sense. Just as smoking had become a challenge against opposition, the idea of stopping started to feel appealing. The possibility of not being a smoker was beginning to make me feel powerful. It was a secret feeling that had nothing to do with anyone except myself. Could I also conquer the world? In many ways, it was easy. The physical craving, the desire for nicotine, in the same place where you feel hunger, faded after a minute or two and I experienced them for only four or five days. The one activity - my work - that I thought would be the hardest to do without cigarettes did not cause a single problem. I had really believed that I would not be able to work to deadlines without nicotine and that for the first time ever I would fail to write a story on time. Surprisingly, spending time at home on weekend mornings was the hardest thing - and it still is. I am increasingly thinking that for me smoking had a lot to do with avoiding boredom; having a cigarette was an activity in itself. Yes, I do miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each 'new' experience as a non-smoker has to be faced - eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, a theatre break. All are key moments when I would have previously smoked cigarettes.'

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to have won a Nobel Prize, yet she is not widely known in her own country. Georgina Ferry, who is writing Hodgkin's first biography, has noticed that few people recognize Hodgkin's name. This is surprising because if a British woman had won a Nobel Prize in literature, she would likely be famous. Hodgkin, who passed away in 1994, was an extraordinary person. Her life mirrored significant changes in the 20th century, such as the progress of women's education and the globalization of science.

When Ferry started her research, she read scientific biographies and was advised to read about Linus Pauling, a friend and contemporary of Hodgkin. Pauling, a Nobel laureate in both chemistry and peace, was not well-known in Britain, which surprised Ferry. This lack of interest in scientific biographies is partly due to the belief that scientists' lives are not as interesting as those of artists or writers. This idea is part of the 'two cultures' mentality, which suggests a divide between the arts and sciences.

However, this view is changing. Scientists are becoming more visible in the media, and scientific biographies are becoming more engaging. Richard Feynman's memoir, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman?", showed that scientists can have fascinating personal lives. Recent biographies of famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Albert Einstein have also highlighted their personal flaws and challenges.

Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her scientific work, achieving major breakthroughs in understanding the structures of penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin. She balanced her career with a family life, having three children and a husband who was often away. Her ability to integrate her personal and professional life is inspiring. While her personal life may not directly relate to her scientific achievements, it is still of interest.

Communicating the passion that drives scientific inquiry is challenging for biographers because many readers lack the scientific background to understand complex ideas. However, understanding science is not more difficult than learning a language or reading Shakespeare; it just requires effort. It is unfortunate that many educated people remain unaware of the contributions of scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin.

Margaret and Her Water-Finding Skills

Margaret Wilkins is known for her special ability to find water using a forked hazel rod. This skill, often called a 'sixth sense', makes her popular among farmers whose wells have dried up. Together with her husband, she runs a well-drilling business using modern equipment like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she only needs her hazel stick. Their success rate in finding water is over 90%.

Dowsing is the term for finding water, minerals, or lost objects underground. There are many theories about how it works, from physical explanations like magnetism to spiritual ones. A credible theory suggests that everything vibrates, and water vibrates more than other materials. Dowsers, like Margaret, might have a heightened ability to sense these vibrations. Some say they can 'sense' or even smell water.

In recent drought years, Margaret has been very busy, with a waiting list of almost six weeks at one point. Most of her clients are farmers with dry wells. She also helps owners of remote cottages or barns, now used as holiday homes, where installing water pipes is too costly. Golf-course developers also seek her help for clubhouse facilities. Margaret aims to find water 50 to 70 meters deep. She avoids drilling where farm waste might contaminate the water. The water she finds flows through fissures in rock, ensuring a clean supply, though she must be cautious of minerals like iron in Cornwall.

Electricity is needed to power the pump, so the well should be near existing power sources. After considering these factors, Margaret starts her search. On large sites like golf courses, she uses a map and a pendulum. The pendulum swings over areas with water. Then, she walks the fields with her hazel stick. When she senses water, she feels a peculiar sensation and uses the stick to pinpoint the drilling spot. Holding the stick's forks, she applies tension. When water is directly below, the stick rises. It's crucial to drill exactly where the stick indicates, as even a small error can miss the waterline. Her husband also dowses the area, and they must agree on the spot before drilling.

Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition in England. Anthropologists and writers are intrigued by this mysterious intuition. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment', which helps explain her accuracy. Without this 'sixth sense', her family couldn't sustain their well-drilling business year after year.

Text: 'We changed lives for a day! Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different for a change? We arranged it for four people - read about their experiences. Amanda (23), a young mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy (30), who works as a waitress at a busy London restaurant. A. Amanda's story I had never been anywhere like it before. I was amazed by how dark and noisy it was - there were so many people and such a lively atmosphere. It was very different from my hometown, and honestly, I wasn't sure I'd manage! Being a mother is definitely a busy job - but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks at shoulder height with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting the hang of it, the drinks started to slide off the tray and crashed onto the floor, spilling cocktails everywhere. I was so embarrassed, but all the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first! By opening time at 11.30 am, a queue had already formed outside and I began to feel really nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but that wasn't a problem because everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet really hurt and I couldn't get used to the constant loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me I had to say 'Pardon?', which was so embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was totally exhausted and longed to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn't believe it when one of the waitresses told me it had been a 'quiet' day! I never realized how tiring waitressing would be. I've always thought it was a job for shy people, but in fact, you need to be quite outgoing, as well as having the ability to stay calm and deal with what is known in the trade as a 'high-volume experience' - in other words, lots of customers! I'm really quite shy and I don't think I could cope on a Saturday night, when it gets very busy. I wasn't too impressed with the pay either. Unfortunately, I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me anything! I must admit I was very glad to get back to my children. It seems quite easy after waitressing! B. Cindy's story I was feeling quite nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it, too. I'd been warned the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. Little did I know! As Amanda left to go to the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing. At 1 pm I picked up Katie, rushed around the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But it was when I brought Sophie home from school that the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and played a game which involved screaming as loudly as they could! I decided to take the relaxed approach, thinking they'd soon get tired. Wrong again. I thought I had a fair amount of stamina, but they beat me, hands down! After much persuasion, I managed to get them into bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun and games started! How many glasses of water can a child drink, for heaven's sake? Of course, I realized it was just a trick so they could come downstairs and watch television, but it was exhausting to spend all evening negotiating with them. I never realized how tiring it could be looking after two small children. You don't get a second to think about yourself - and the sheer sense of responsibility is overwhelming. Even so, I really enjoyed the day. Rosemary (42) runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary (30), a teacher at a primary school. C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I have to get up at 5.30 am so sleeping in until 7 was pure luxury! But I hesitated for ages about how to look. I could hardly turn up in overalls and boots, could I? Looking at a sea of faces -- about 400 pupils -- at assembly, I hoped I blended into the background and that my fresh complexion didn't make me stand out as being straight off the farm. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, using workcards graded according to difficulty - rather different from when I was at school and we had to recite tables in unison! Then I helped out with a nature project - identifying and feeding species of snails. By lunchtime, I was exhausted and looking forward to an hour's break, but the teachers only have about five minutes to eat their meal. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and couldn't avoid getting roped in to help with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (bliss!) and then a French lesson in the video room. This was great fun because all the children wanted to practice on me, which really showed up my rusty French. Finally, we moved on to the school hall for Physical Education. I was drained by now, but the children seemed to have inexhaustible energy. The hardest part of the job was standing up in front of the class and speaking - even for just two minutes, it's daunting. Teachers may get more holidays a year, but I think I'll stick to farming, anyway! D. Hilary's story I arrived at White House Farm at 8.30 am, bright and early, only to discover that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's 280-acre farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves and heifers, and about 800 ewes! As well as milk, she makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream, which is sold in shops, restaurants, and at tourist attractions. I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk into plastic litre containers, squeezing ice-cream from a machine into cartons, and sticking on labels. It was difficult to stop myself from dipping my fingers into the goodies! At lunchtime, it was time to inspect the sheep. I drove over to one of the fields and picked up a ewe that had fallen over. If the sheep are left for more than 12 hours once they have fallen over they could die, so they have to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started the milking. The process took an exhausting two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite a lonely day. I was surprised how much I missed the children - animals don't answer back! The worst aspect of the job is not being able to get away from work. The cows always have to be milked twice a day, so it's really difficult to plan any time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems romantic but the reality is very different. The income is irregular and I'd hate to be at the mercy of the weather.'

Text: 'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many musicians, even famous ones, come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of non-musical parents in a rural area of southern Sweden, has become a unique trumpet player at the age of 30. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by lesser-known composers from the baroque and classical periods, as well as new works. When you meet him, he appears younger than his age, with a fresh and open manner, much like the sound of the trumpet. Recently, he performed the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London's top concert halls, and a television feature focused on his work and development, filmed in both the UK and Sweden. Born near Malmo, his career began with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's music, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played constantly. His mother contacted the second trumpet player in the Malmo Symphony Orchestra, Bo Nilsson, to teach her son. Nilsson, an emerging musician, immediately recognized Hardenberger's talent. Hardenberger is grateful for having such a dedicated teacher who was passionate about the trumpet and connected with players worldwide. Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a primitive instrument with imperfections, and it's about understanding and working with them. From the start, he had the ability to find the right balance and develop his unique sound. Unlike John Wallace, a great British trumpet player who started in brass bands and orchestras, Hardenberger always saw himself as a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre, who also focused on solo performances. His parents supported his ambition to make a career in trumpet playing. At 15, he needed to decide where to study. America was considered too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud reinforced his desire to avoid orchestras, comparing it to 'digging in the garden.' Hardenberger knew he played better than others his age, but it was during his first competition at 17 in Paris that he realized he had a special gift for communication. Thibaud suggested entering the competition for experience. Hardenberger learned the pieces for the first round and advanced to the second, where he knew most of the pieces. In the final, he faced a challenging concerto. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and realized that even if he 'played like a pig,' people listened to him. His realism about his work might seem arrogant, but that's not true. He thoughtfully avoids analyzing his gift for communication, believing that trying to explain it could ruin it. The power of music lies in its ability to move people.'

Text: 'New In Paperback A. The story of citizen Tristan Smith takes place in the fictional republic of Efica. It is a remarkable tale about human power, history, and humor. The author has skillfully created a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's unique vision, combined with deep psychological insight. It is a challenging but rewarding read. B. Harriet is a poised, middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would never have met Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change dramatically when Leo violently attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to discuss the incident. Leo, who was a model student and had never fought before, won't explain his actions, while Joe recovers physically but becomes withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by her son's condition, and caring for him consumes her life. Sheila feels so guilty that she asks for a meeting, leading to an unusual friendship. The author excels at showing how people react to major changes in their lives and captures the mothers' feelings of inadequacy. C. Shortlisted for the Booker Prize, this book follows the history of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people. The story is set against key moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of the young protagonist, Thorfinn Ragnarson. He disappears at one point in the book, only to return after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors. D. After his recent bestseller, the author has written a sequel with the same gentle irony and sharp observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies with her lively companion, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's approach to life is still a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, with Rosie as her ally in managing suitors and friends. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passage of time and the rise of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness beneath the ordinary aspects of life, focusing on the shadows rather than the bright moments and highlighting the randomness of events. E. Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author, with her impressive descriptive language, explores the personal journeys of self-discovery each of these sailors undergoes. They return home with their spirits renewed by their time on 'the desert cities of waves'. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which are both alienating and enlightening.'

Text: 'Five Careers Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their jobs: the highlights, the challenges, and their typical workday. A. THE BRAIN SURGEON Name: Anne Age: 34 ANNE'S DAY "I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and start work by 8 am. I begin operating at 8:30 am. I operate all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and some Friday afternoons. Most head surgeries take three hours, but some can last all day. I've worked ten hours straight without eating or using the bathroom. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed while operating, but I sometimes worry about the next day's tasks. Brain surgery is often a last resort, but when successful, it's very rewarding. From 10 am to 1 pm, I have an out-patients' clinic where I explain operations. I enjoy talking to patients, but time pressure can make it hard to comfort them if they're upset. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I'm on call and always carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first few days about my patients, and I dream about operating. I find it hard to switch off." B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER Name: Marita Age: 31 MARITA'S DAY "I get up at 7:45 am, leave by 8:20 am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our projects and any issues. We work in teams; mine includes three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only 10-15% of the work is design; the rest is production. I get a brief from the client, then spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After presenting my ideas to the client and getting approval, we set budgets and I start hiring photographers and illustrators. I coordinate with printers to ensure everything is on time. Managing people is a big part of my job, and clear communication is crucial. I assemble everything and send it to the printers. Handling multiple projects can be very stressful. Deadlines are always near, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour, often at a pub. If not, I have sandwiches and work through. It's great when a client likes your work, but disappointing if it's rejected. I get home at 7:30 pm at the earliest, often later. It's hard to relax when I'm busy." C. THE CHAUFFEUR Name: Linda Age: 42 LINDA'S DAY "I usually get up at 7 am, but two or three times a week, I meet early flights and get up between 4:30 am and 5 am. Around 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is sedentary, I watch my diet and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snack during the day. People often ask for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know my way around. Many jobs are pre-booked, so I can plan routes. Not everyone is polite; some passengers are rude. But most are well-behaved, and I have a good rapport with regular clients. Sometimes I overhear conversations and have to focus on driving. The press has tried to get me to talk about clients, but I don't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and try not to get too tired. I aim to be in bed by 11 pm." D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER Name: Tracy Age: 27 TRACY'S DAY "I get up at 7 am, leave by 7:30 am, and start my first job. My assistant and I mostly maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but mostly private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each site. Around 11 am, we have a big breakfast at a cafe. I often wish time passed more slowly. In summer, I may work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. The business office is at home, so I check messages and return calls when I get back. If someone wants their garden landscaped, I arrange an evening consultation. We use old materials and unusual plants to make gardens look aged. Sometimes clients have specific ideas that aren't great. It's satisfying to see a garden completed and blooming. It's hard to relax in the evenings because I hear the business phone. I sleep well because the work is so physical. I'm not very strong, but I'm fit. It's a tough job, but it lets my imagination run wild." E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER Name: Zena Age: 27 ZENA'S DAY "I arrive at the site by 8:30 am. I'm the assistant resident engineer, overseeing the building of bridges and a retaining wall. I ensure contractors follow the schedule and safety standards with minimal environmental impact. I coordinate site professionals and solve problems. Contractors start at 6 am, so I first check with the clerk of works about what's happened since I left. The rest of the day depends on this update. I review paperwork and answer design queries. Lunch is usually half an hour between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat on the go. When contractors are on break, it's easier to check the site. Our relationship with contractors must be open to avoid conflict. I see the duty resident engineer daily, but act immediately if something important arises. I usually leave the site around 6 pm and am always on call."'

**Careers: Six People Discuss Their Typical Workday**

**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and reach the office by 7:30 am. I handle customer development programs for our regular credit card users. My duties include launching and managing the Membership Rewards scheme in major European markets. I maintain contact with current card users, attract new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and responding to emails. I oversee advertising for the membership program across Europe, meeting with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan strategies and future developments. My day is filled with meetings, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different European markets once or twice a week to address issues. In London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**  
I start work at 10:00 am, reviewing the post, which includes demo tapes, letters from producers, concert information, and invoices. Calls begin around 10:30 am from producers and publishers, and I have meetings throughout the day about campaigns or projects for artists. When listening to demo tapes, I try to be constructive, knowing it's someone's life's work. I can tell if the sound suits our label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs, producers, and musicians. I communicate my vision for the album to the company for marketing and sales. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7:00 pm at the earliest and often attend gigs, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. After gigs, I might visit an artist in the studio. My social life revolves around work, and I often get home by 1:00 am, where I listen to a record to relax.

**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the post and diary to see if we have client visits. I enjoy showing people around the showrooms and making sales, knowing the furniture is going to a good home. We sell antiques ranging from £1,000 to £6,000, buying from London salerooms, country house sales, private clients, and overseas. Many items need restoration, so I work closely with gilders, framers, and repairers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette during coffee breaks to stay updated and often visit the Victoria and Albert Museum to compare furniture. I handle accounts monthly and do tax returns quarterly. I go home at 5:30 pm, taking about an hour to unwind.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work set shifts, leaving home at 6:00 am for early shifts. At 7:00 am, I take over from the night shift at one of four control positions in the tower. We rotate stations, working for about an hour and a half, then taking a break before returning to a different station. The team includes air traffic controllers, a supervisor, and a watch manager, all working together to control aircraft movements. We handle about 1,000 movements daily in winter, more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, allowing time to read up on new air traffic requirements. It's crucial to be alert, so I don't hesitate to call in sick if I'm unwell. The job is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I aim to become a watch manager and eventually a general manager at the airport.

**E. Shop Manager**  
For early shifts, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by setting up the electronic point-of-sale system and ensure someone is at the till. I coordinate staff lunches and breaks. I spend mornings helping customers and ordering books. I enjoy serving customers, though it can be frustrating when they expect me to gather books based on reviews. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' reps visit, and I discuss new titles, considering how many copies the shop might sell. It's crucial to ensure new titles are delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. Twice a week, I work late shifts, closing the computer system and locking up before going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about events in my region. I assess financial risks for multinational companies abroad, warning clients of potential issues. I provide three services: an online executive preview, a security forecast, and a travel information security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first executive preview is due online by 10:00 am, and the second by 11:00 am, so I quickly follow up on stories. I type them, send them to my editor for approval, then make any necessary changes before they are published. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events or stay informed. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but it's hard to switch off, and I'm often awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires and guides change. Leadership isn't about appearance or intelligence. Pat Dixon, author of *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, says leadership is about 'making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are.' Enthusiasm is crucial, and a good leader should speak confidently and with conviction. Dixon suggests saying "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. **Recognizing Leadership Potential**  
John van Maurik, director of a Leadership in Management course, believes most people have more leadership potential than they realize. Becoming a leader involves recognizing, developing, and using these talents. While we easily see leadership in figures like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see in our own workplace. Yet, leadership is essential for effective management.

C. **Reflect on Leadership Experiences**  
Think about the best and worst bosses you've had. Both may have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines, but how did they achieve them? The best leader motivated and supported you, while the worst made you feel insignificant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first led well; the second managed poorly.

D. **Leaders vs. Managers**  
Leaders and managers are different. Managers work within set boundaries, while leaders create new horizons. Michael Shea, author of *Leadership Rules*, writes that a good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can transform a demoralized organization, whether it's a company, a team, or a nation.

E. **Improving Leadership Skills**  
Whether you're a boss or a middle manager, improving leadership skills is beneficial. Here are some lessons:  
- Leadership is best when chosen. Find your passions and act on them when inspired.  
- See yourself as a leader. Recognize your ability to lead.  
- While collaboration is good, sometimes firm leadership is needed. Experiment with your style. If you're a natural transactor, try negotiating. If you usually seek others' views, try leading. Notice how outcomes change.  
- Set and exceed goals. Identify job demands where leadership enhances effectiveness and career prospects.

F. **Developing Leadership**  
- Leadership develops by taking the lead, taking risks, and learning from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, organize, and praise.  
- Don't assume your leadership style will immediately win over colleagues. It might alienate them. Work on communication skills. You don't have to be liked, but your ideas and accomplishments should be.  
- Be visible and accessible to important people. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your contribution is vital and help others develop as leaders.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before Titanic, director James Cameron created this intense Cold War thriller about oil rig workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The witty and brave foreman Bud and his team remind us of the cool heroes in Howard Hawks' films. The production design and special effects are impressive, but the dialogue and character development are lacking. Despite the skilled filmmaking, the story feels like a B-movie.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This video release of Andrew Marton's adaptation of James Jones' novel about the battle for Guadalcanal offers an interesting contrast to Terrence Malick's new film. While Malick's version is mystical and poetic, Marton's is a more traditional war movie, often truer to the book. It focuses on a single soldier and his tough sergeant. Although Malick's film is richer and more complex, Marton's has its highlights. The flashback of the soldier dreaming of his wife is portrayed with a harshness that might be more effective than Malick's softer imagery.

**C. On Guard**  
Loosely based on Paul Feval's 1875 novel, this entertaining swashbuckler stands out among musketeer adventures. Fabrice Luchini plays a perfect villain, a scheming politician causing chaos behind the scenes. Vincent Perez is a lively, though short-lived, hero, and Daniel Auteuil, despite being a bit too serious for this type of film, shines as an acrobat-turned-swordsman. The filmmakers use costume-drama clichés with such wit and energy that it remains enjoyable.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 20th-century Rotterdam, this film is a handsome but somber tale. The detailed production and costume design make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays the grim bailiff Dreverhaven, who is ruthless in evicting tenants. The tense relationship with his son is central to the story, but the filmmakers focus too much on period details, neglecting the dark and intense narrative.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This digitally re-mastered video highlights director Leone's skill. The sound editing is exceptional, with every footstep and creak clearly heard. The storytelling is relentlessly harsh, and whenever there's a pause, Morricone's powerful music revives the excitement. Morally, there's little difference between the good (Clint Eastwood), the bad (Lee van Cleef), and the ugly (Eli Wallach), as they all act unscrupulously in the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war epic by Darryl Zanuck boasts 'forty-eight international stars.' With four directors and 23,000 extras, it's an overdone production. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, feel as slow for the audience as for the characters. Logistically impressive, it lacks aesthetic appeal and is best suited for the big screen. On video, it loses much of its impact.

**BOOK A**  
"Compelling Evidence" by Steve Martin is truly gripping. The story follows a lawyer trying to start a new practice after leaving a top law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife, accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are intense, with the verdict uncertain until the end, and there's a surprising twist in the final pages. This is an impressive debut in a competitive genre.

**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" starts with excitement, throwing Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the Italian Renaissance aristocracy, into a mix of politics, church intrigue, and murder. We trust he will solve the mystery and reveal the culprits. The plot is complex and a bit lengthy, but it's still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" introduces a unique detective from new author Sarah Lacey. Leah Hunter, a tax inspector, finds herself investigating when a man suddenly dies at her feet. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a local detective sergeant, Leah proves to be a strong and capable character.

**BOOK D**  
In "Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker, private investigator Spenser helps his friend Hawk clear drug dealers from a poor area in Boston. The dialogue is quick and sharp, with more philosophy than violence. As always, Parker delivers high-quality entertainment.

**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate an attack and burglary at a famous film star's daughter's house. Kellermann's easy writing style and keen observation of human behavior make this mystery enjoyable.

**BOOK F**  
In "Blood Red, Snow White," Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock team up to write about a lawyer with a female client. The action takes place outside the courtroom, and the lawyer becomes a victim as the plot unfolds. Romance, money, and violence are skillfully combined to create a captivating suspense novel.

**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a potential victim. A funny group of characters gathers to film a Robin Hood story, but Philip feels his career is off track. While Shaw usually entertains, this shift from black comedy to farce is not his best work.

**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" is Lawrence Gough's best work in a while. Canadian police pursue a clever bank robber targeting female tellers. The slow, well-paced tension and the portrayal of the intelligent, troubled robber make this a standout detective novel.

Text: 'I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He wonders why he and others his age decide to take this step. This summer, I quit my job, decided to rent out my apartment, and travel in Southeast Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old, and I'm nervous. It's not like I haven't traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking around North and South America, and when I returned, I was determined to do it again someday. But you know how it is... I fell in love, started a career, bought an apartment, and got used to earning a salary. But I gradually realized I had been sacrificing my own sense of worth for my salary. When I handed in my resignation letter, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. I now have no ties. Many of my friends are married with children, and while they wouldn't trade places with me, they envy my lack of responsibilities. I'm no longer in a relationship, and I have no strong career ambitions. I feel almost obliged to make the most of that freedom - if only for my friends' sake! Why am I so nervous? First, it's about making the necessary arrangements. How could I bear to have someone else living in my home? And how would I organize the letting? And apart from anything else, I had to decide where to go. I'm a terrible procrastinator and am already several weeks behind my intended schedule. 'Might as well enjoy the summer in England,' I told myself. Then, 'Why not stay for the start of the football season?' Cutting emotional ties makes it even more difficult. I'm putting it off because, deep down, I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a more basic way of life? Will I feel out of place among a community of backpackers fresh out of school and university? Perhaps not. I've discovered it's increasingly common for Britons in their late twenties and thirties to want to break free from the lives they've built and head off to foreign places. Jennifer Cox, from Lonely Planet guidebook publishers, notes a growing awareness that adventure is there for the taking: 'People are realizing they can have the opportunity anytime they want. They just have to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.' For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, it's a chance to have a final adventure before settling down. They have bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. 'I'm prepared to sacrifice job security for the trip,' says Danny. 'There's always a thought at the back of your mind that, "OK, I'm not moving up the career ladder, I'll be in the same position when I come back," but I think it's a risk you have to take. When I left the office, I threw my calculator into the river as a ceremonial act of defiance!' For Matt, who'd just left the Army, the year he spent traveling was a period of transformation. 'In the military, there's a set way of doing things, a pattern to how you approach problems. I went away because I needed to change this, and get rid of this approach in some cases, to have a reasonable life as a civilian.' While there are as many reasons to go traveling at my age as there are travelers, there seem to be common factors. 'We have a much more flexible workforce today,' says Angela Baron of the Institute of Personnel Development. 'There are more people working on short-term contracts, so if your contract's just ended, you've got nothing to lose.' Larger companies are even adopting career-break policies. 'If you've spent a lot of time and money training someone, it's nice to know they're coming back at some point rather than going to work for a competitor.' For Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, a publishing company that specializes in the stories of 'ordinary' travelers, more thirty-somethings are reassessing their lives. 'If you're not happy doing what you're doing - and many people aren't - it's no longer about just sticking it out. Now people know that opportunities exist and that a job isn't "for life" anymore. Travel offers a chance to reassess, to step back and think about your life.' Is giving in to wanderlust just another example of my generation's inability to accept adulthood? Jennifer Cox thinks not. 'It's a sign of a better-educated, more stable society when we're less concerned with paying the bills than wanting to live a balanced life. We're actually taking the time to ask "Is this what I want?" Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher heading off to Central America for a year, doesn't believe he's running away. 'It's more about running towards something. It's trying to grab some things that I want for myself.' But he does feel some fear. 'It's the thought of what I'm leaving behind, that comfortable routine - just the act of going into the office every day, saying "hi" to everyone, and sitting down with a cup of coffee.' I share Ben's concerns about leaving behind an ordered life with few challenges, and I'm not sure I'd be making this journey if I hadn't found my boss so intolerable. As Jennifer Cox points out: 'This is fairly typical. There's often a catalyst, like the break-up of a relationship or the loss of a job. Such an event can push people to go and do it.' It may have taken a helpful push to get me moving, but I'm now approaching the next 12 months with growing excitement. Whatever the outcome, I'll be able to take satisfaction in having seized life by the horns. And in that, I'm sure I speak for all of us older backpackers.'

Text: 'Plugging in the Home Georgina McGuiness had taken a long break from journalism and felt disconnected from the technological changes. She shares how she turned her family home into an efficient workplace. The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to revive my journalism career, which seemed lost in the technological age. My resume showed I was stuck in the 1980s, when typewriters were the norm. It seemed unlikely anyone would hire me to work on a computer in a newsroom. Many job ads required desktop publishing experience, which I lacked. I felt more capable of hosting a seminar on nuclear physics than designing a page on a computer. I was the family technophobe; even pocket calculators confused me, and I couldn't use the video timer. Clearly, my career had a big gap, and I needed to act fast. Leaving home before the children did seemed difficult until I entered a local newspaper competition. Like a success story that happens to others, my family and I won a computer package. We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family, diving into a new world where terms like cyberspace, Internet, and surfing became common. We started chatting online with strangers worldwide. The children abandoned TV, and I set up a mini-office in the kitchen with a phone-answering machine, fax, CD-ROM, and modem connecting me to the Internet. I had everything needed to work from home and still take the children to school. They were confident with computers, having learned at school. I was hesitant, fearing I would lose all my work with one wrong button. I was wrong. Though not skilled, I learned the basics—it was logical, easy, and foolproof. With perseverance, I learned more each day. I recently started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I feel I have the best of both worlds. How has the computer helped me? Since school, my desk was always a chaotic mess, and I often lost important notes. The computer made me organized, especially with office tasks. Spreadsheets help track income and expenses, and pre-formatted invoices and letterheads save time. For a journalist, being online means I can research stories, ask for more information in journalism forums, and discuss working from home with people worldwide. If this sounds too good to be true, there is a downside to working from home. You can feel isolated from human contact. There are distractions like household chores, and when the children are home, we argue over computer time. However, more people are buying multimedia PCs, not just for education and entertainment. In my street, a new type of home-based industry is emerging, avoiding the daily commute to the city. So, what defines home workers as we enter the next century? A report called PC Usage in UK Homes describes the typical computer user as 38 and well-educated; 93% own a personal computer, 32% have a CD-ROM, 38% have a laser printer, and 50% have a modem. Considering this, I seem ahead of the curve. Who knows, one day I might email a column to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publish my own magazine from home. It seems the sky, or rather cyberspace, is the limit.'

**The Tartan Museum**

The modern, cheese-wedge buildings of Scotland's national museum stand out in historic Edinburgh. But are its contents as striking? Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened.

You can't miss it. The Museum of Scotland is unmissable, located on the corner of Chambers Street in Edinburgh, with its large, yellow sandstone tower and cheese-wedge buildings, topped by a hanging garden. Last winter, the building received mixed reactions: some praised it as a modernist masterpiece, others were cautious, and some were hostile. This winter, as the inside is nearly ready for opening, the exhibitions might receive similar reactions.

Forget the debate about whether it tells a nation's story or is chronological. The answer is yes; it presents a rich tapestry of stories, each centered around a historic object, with a timeline to guide visitors without restricting the displays. It doesn't let national treasures, like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and the Holyrood chapel silver, get overshadowed by national pride.

The real question is whether people will find the museum interesting enough to return. Dr. David Clarke, the head of exhibitions, insists that a visit should be a pleasurable, visual experience, designed for those with little prior knowledge. Despite this, Clarke is a purist about what is shown. He avoids mock-ups and imaginative scenes from the past, believing they give a false sense of certainty about history. He says, "The public deserves the truth." So, at this museum, what you see is what experts know.

The question for visitors is whether the objects' stories can be told vividly enough with explanation panels, captions, and multimedia, using only about 30 computers throughout the museum. Less than three days before opening, it's still hard to be sure. Some impressions are clear, though, and it's not just the panoramic views of Edinburgh Castle that are impressive.

Inside, the sequence of spaces is striking. Galleries open into one another, with different sizes and shapes, pale wood-paneled walls resembling large stone blocks, and deep display cases. Daylight streams through narrow windows and roof lights. There's room to appreciate every item on display.

Thanks to a 12-member Junior Board, set up three years ago with 9- to 12-year-olds from across Scotland, the museum has a Discovery Centre. The group wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a dedicated children's hands-on center in what was meant to be the temporary exhibition gallery. As a result, the Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition. It will change after three years and is a mix of objects chosen by Scottish people and other personalities as items that impacted life in Scotland in the twentieth century. The Prime Minister suggested an electric guitar, while others chose televisions, Thermos flasks, and favorite toys. Although the idea is fun, it feels like a lightweight solution, not a serious attempt to address important issues. It may seem more substantial when the computerized bank of personal reasons and recollections goes live next week.

Overall, Dr. Clarke seems right when he suggests that "objects open windows on the past more vividly than anything else." As for the modernist architecture: it works brilliantly from the inside and the top, but whether it fits the location is another question.

Text: 'The end of print may take some time Peter Preston Transition is a comforting idea. Change can be scary for some and challenging for others. But transition suggests a smooth move from the present to the future. However, when it comes to newspapers moving online, this transition is uncertain and uncomfortable. Many believe it will happen eventually, as print newspaper sales are dropping while visits to their websites are increasing. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have seen print sales fall by 8% to 10% year-on-year, but their websites are gaining more visitors. This trend depends on factors like timing, demographics, and geography. Experts from both the web and print industries agree on this shift. Yet, there are some inconsistencies. Global newspaper circulation actually rose by 1.1% last year, with Asia compensating for declines in the West. News magazines, expected to suffer in the digital age, reported a 5.4% increase. Similarly, e-readers like Kindle are popular, but physical book sales only dropped by 0.4%. It seems both digital and print formats are thriving. Claims that young people are abandoning newspapers are exaggerated. Nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read national dailies. Different countries show different trends. In Britain, print sales fell by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline was only 7%, and in France, just 3.1%. These variations suggest a more complex situation than expected. In the US, online advertising was once thought to support the shift to digital, but digital ad revenues are now declining. As a result, 360 US newspapers have introduced paywalls. The most successful strategy seems to be offering print and digital access together. Print remains important for selling online subscriptions and generates much higher advertising revenue than online. This situation is challenging for newspaper companies, as maintaining both print and digital editions is costly. However, print still plays a key role in maintaining a newspaper's visibility, which is harder to achieve online.'

**Photographing People**

People are the most fascinating subjects to photograph. A picture with a person in it is usually more engaging than one without. However, capturing people well in photos is challenging. Beyond technical and artistic aspects, photographers must be aware of actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, the camera's presence can negatively affect these.

**A. GROUPING PEOPLE**

Avoid straight lines in group photos. Have people stand at different angles and distances, or on different levels. You can also have some people sit or kneel in front so all faces are visible, or raise your viewpoint.

**B. POSING FOR PICTURES**

People often act unnaturally in front of a camera, becoming stiff. Help your subject relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding hands or putting them in pockets.

**C. THE RIGHT APPROACH**

Don't pretend you're not taking a picture when you clearly are, as this creates tension. Most people will agree to be photographed, though they might protest initially. They may become self-conscious, so you might need to guide them. A photo can be ruined if the subject looks aimlessly away, drawing interest elsewhere.

**D. EYE CONTACT**

A photo has more impact if the subject looks at the viewer. Ask them to look into the lens, but not necessarily smile. They might not maintain this for long, so remind them before you take the shot. You can also say something funny or unexpected for a genuine reaction.

**E. CANDID CONCENTRATION**

Instead of direct eye contact, have the subject focus on something within the picture. This might be easier for them, and the viewer can follow their gaze. Candid shots are intriguing, and the subject's expression is crucial.

**F. EXPRESSIONS AND GESTURES**

Expressions and gestures reveal much about the subject. A laughing child, even if poorly dressed, can make the viewer smile, while a sad face can evoke sympathy. Look for familiar expressions like shrugs, winks, or thumbs-up. They are a universal visual language.

**G. SITUATION INTEREST**

While close-up shots of faces are impactful, including the subject's environment can add interest. When using a background, exclude irrelevant details or blur them. Ensure the subject isn't overshadowed by the background; a wide-angle lens can help balance the subject and background.

**H. INTERACTION**

When people are interacting—talking, arguing, or working together—there are opportunities for great photos. Couples, mothers and babies, or teams can make appealing shots. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a hand on an arm, or wait for an expressive gesture.

**I. PEOPLE AND PLACES**

Many photos of people are taken on holidays to show the places visited. To improve these pictures, use a standard or wide-angle lens and step back to include the whole scene. Ask subjects to come close to the camera, forming a foreground without blocking the background. An elevated camera position can help balance the subjects and the place.

**J. TO POSE OR NOT TO POSE?**

Decide why you want the picture. If it's to remember someone you met briefly, ask them to pose against a good background. Family photos can be dull if they are just formal poses. Candid shots of events are more lively, especially when you know the subject well. A spontaneous picture can evoke memories better than a posed one.

Text: 'Under Sarah's Spell Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist, which means her paintings create an illusion of reality to trick the eye. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her. Unlike most artists, Sarah Janson doesn't sign her work unless asked. She believes the art is more important than the artist. Janson is very modest, almost as if her paintings create themselves. This attitude makes her a challenging interview subject. She admits, "I just don't like to talk about myself," and is uncomfortable being photographed. However, once she relaxes, the interview becomes engaging and humorous. Janson has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, earned a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But illustration didn't fulfill her, so she joined a decorator named Jim Smart, who introduced her to trompe-l'oeil. This sparked her passion, and she started her own business, feeling she was on the right path. Her skills in observation and detail, honed through illustration, are crucial for trompe-l'oeil. Janson believes trompe-l'oeil can't be taught; it's about observing life. She insists she's still learning and is honest about her limitations, like struggling to paint bread. When working on a large project for a chapel ceiling, she doubted herself, thinking, "You're not Michelangelo." This self-questioning leads her to speak about her work in the third person, as if someone else created it. Janson's work stands out in the trompe-l'oeil revival, with many corporate and private commissions. Her art often draws inspiration from architecture, like a dining room based on a Venetian palace or a painting that creates the illusion of extra rooms. Trompe-l'oeil must first trick the viewer and then engage their imagination. Janson believes it should also be personal to the client, and she enjoys collaborating with them. Many clients become friends, as she often works closely with them. Janson appreciates her clients, especially those who give her creative freedom. Despite her modesty, she is always busy, as clients are pleased with her work. She repeats, "I really don't like to talk about myself," preferring her work to speak quietly. While she may not seek attention, her art deserves recognition, and I am happy to praise her talent.'

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

Daniel Goleman explores the 'people skills' crucial for professional success.

**A**

The rules at work are changing. We are now judged not only by our intelligence or expertise but also by how we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new standard helps decide who gets hired or promoted. It predicts who will excel and who might not. These skills are vital for future job opportunities, regardless of our current field. Unlike what we learned in school, doing well in exams is not enough. This new measure assumes we have the necessary intellectual and technical skills. It focuses on social skills and personal qualities like initiative, empathy, adaptability, and persuasiveness—collectively known as emotional intelligence.

**B**

In a world where job security is uncertain, personal qualities are increasingly important. These have been called 'character', 'personality', or 'soft skills' in the past. Now, they are better understood as 'emotional intelligence', which is the ability to manage our own and others' emotions and use them to guide actions. In work, it includes self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy, and social skills. Emotional intelligence is not just about 'being nice'. Sometimes it requires confronting uncomfortable truths. It also doesn't mean expressing all feelings freely. Instead, it involves managing emotions so they are expressed effectively, helping people work together towards common goals.

**C**

Many businesses now see emotional intelligence as essential to management. The more complex the job, the more important these skills become. Lack of emotional intelligence can hinder the use of technical skills or intellect. While some people succeed despite flaws in emotional intelligence, as work becomes more collaborative, companies that foster these skills gain a competitive advantage. In today's workplace, with its focus on teamwork and customer service, emotional intelligence is crucial for success in any job worldwide.

**D**

Unlike IQ, which changes little, emotional intelligence can grow throughout life as we learn from experiences. Studies show that people generally improve in managing emotions, motivating themselves, and developing empathy and social skills. This growth is often called maturity. Emotional intelligence can be learned and added to our skills for survival, especially when job stability is uncertain. While it is not a magic solution for struggling organizations, ignoring the human element can hinder overall success.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to capture important events, but social media has changed citizen photography even more. News often breaks on social networks, and some journalists use them to find images during fast-moving events. Unfortunately, some reporters have used user-generated content (UGC) without asking for permission. Official guidelines say images from social media can be used without permission in exceptional cases or if there is strong public interest, but there is still debate about whether this is ethical. Research shows that about one in ten people would film or photograph a news event, indicating that UGC is important for the future of the media. However, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media must ensure people are properly rewarded for their work and always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

**Acupuncture's Origins and Uses**

Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old, originating from traditional Chinese medicine. This system also includes herbal remedies, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat various conditions, but its effectiveness in pain relief has gained the most attention in Western medicine. Some general practitioners, midwives, and physiotherapists use it regularly for this purpose.

**Understanding Traditional Chinese Medicine**

In traditional Chinese medicine, health is seen as a balance of energy in the mind, body, and spirit. This energy, known as Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an internal organ, and many smaller ones that distribute Qi throughout the body. If the flow of Qi is disrupted, it can lead to imbalance and illness. During an acupuncture session, the practitioner identifies where these imbalances occur by checking your pulse, examining your tongue, and assessing your overall appearance. They will also ask about your medical history, current health, and lifestyle habits. Acupuncture involves inserting fine needles into the skin, sometimes with added warmth or pressure, to stimulate the flow of Qi.

**Acupuncture Points and Sensations**

The points used in acupuncture are linked to meridians and may not be near the area of pain. Patients often report a dull ache or tingling when the needle is manipulated, either by hand or with an electro-acupuncture machine. This sensation indicates that the needle has reached the Qi in a meridian. There are over three hundred main acupuncture points, with many more used less frequently.

**Scientific Explanations**

While Western doctors may not fully accept traditional Chinese principles, they acknowledge acupuncture's effectiveness in pain relief. Scientific explanations suggest that acupuncture may work by stimulating nerves to block pain signals or by releasing natural pain-relieving substances called endorphins.

**Types of Pain Treated**

Acupuncture is often sought by those with chronic pain, such as back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, migraines, and post-operative pain. It is also claimed to help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.

**Modern Applications**

Although acupuncture has been practiced in China for over 2,000 years, its use as an alternative to anesthesia in surgery began in the 1950s. This development helped convince some Western doctors of its potential beyond psychological effects. In China, acupuncture is used in various surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs, to reduce pain without the side effects of conventional anesthetics.

**Effectiveness and Trials**

Clinical trials for acupuncture are challenging to conduct, but those that exist show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it effective for chronic pain. Acupuncturists acknowledge that it may not work for everyone and that responses vary. For chronic pain, noticeable relief usually occurs after six or seven sessions, with some improvement after two or three.

**Holistic Approach to Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine approach pain differently. Acupuncturists view patients holistically, considering not just symptoms but also underlying weaknesses in Qi and external factors like weather conditions. This comprehensive approach is less common in conventional Western medicine.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals have traditional acupuncture training, while others rely on scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that only by following Chinese medicine principles can deep, lasting changes be achieved. When choosing an acupuncturist, ensure they are qualified and willing to refer you to a medical doctor if necessary.

Text: P.D. James, whose full name is Phyllis Dorothy James, is a famous crime writer known for her complex and imaginative stories. Despite her quiet and authoritative presence, she is actually quite shy. She admits that her detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is somewhat based on herself, imagining how she might have been if she were a man. Like Dalgliesh, she prefers to work alone, especially when writing, needing complete privacy to focus.

Although she is considered one of Britain's most famous crime writers, with 12 major detective novels read by millions worldwide, she remains humble. She admires the works of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. Her reading preferences include books by women authors like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also appreciates male authors such as Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.

P.D. James found success later in life. Now in her seventies, she published her first crime novel, "Cover Her Face," at the age of 42. Born in Oxford and raised in Cambridge, she met her husband, Connor Bantry White, there. Life was challenging after her husband returned from World War II very ill, and she had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters. Her husband's parents helped care for the children during these tough times.

While working full-time in administration for the National Health Service and later at the Home Office, she used her organizational skills effectively. Her work in forensic science exposed her to the realities of crime, but it was the structure of writing crime novels that attracted her. She always wanted to be a writer and saw detective stories as a way to bring order to chaos. Writing these stories allowed her to explore human nature within the framework of a classic detective story, without drawing directly from her own life's hardships. She believes that solving a crime in a story affirms the value of life, even if the life in question is not particularly lovable.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**

The study of handwriting to reveal a person's character is gaining support. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you might be asked for a sample of your handwriting. This sample could play a significant role in determining your suitability for the position. Handwriting analysis, or graphology, is considered a legitimate science in many places. Researchers claim it can help identify certain illnesses, like heart disease and cancer, and reveal psychological states and emotional issues. Handwriting analysis is increasingly used for career guidance and as a supplement to interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to analyze the handwriting of potential candidates for important jobs. However, most doctors and psychiatrists remain skeptical about the value of graphology.

Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, argues that they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can indicate psychological traits and certain medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting is a powerful indicator of social class and intelligence. But more than that, it can be used to assess mental ability and potential, whether a person should focus on arts or sciences, and whether they have a devious or open character."

According to Ms. Marne, graphology can be particularly useful in assessing possible criminal tendencies: "Criminals all have disturbed handwriting, mostly illiterate and poorly-shaped. Most criminals come from deprived backgrounds and have arrested emotional development. This often shows up in unusually childish handwriting and in going over letters several times. I can tell whether people are honest, manipulators, or reliable employees."

"Young male offenders frequently have very high ascenders, indicating that they live in a world of fantasy and dream of making it big. Graphologists can tell whether violence is about to erupt, whether the writer is under unbearable pressure, and whether there are psychopathic tendencies. Handwriting can be used to predict would-be suicides." Heart and lung problems can also show up, she says. "You can't make a diagnosis from one sample, unless the writing is obviously shaky or disturbed. But if over a period of time it changes or becomes disjointed, if there's a break in the signature which did not exist previously, that could be a sign that something quite serious has occurred." A severe emotional upset can also show up in a temporarily altered signature, she maintains.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can be used to reveal other psychological characteristics. People with writing in which letters form "threads" instead of being individually formed are, apparently, devious and clever. Those who write mainly in capitals are trying to conceal their true selves from others. Very light pressure indicates sensitivity and lack of vitality. Originality in handwriting—how far the writer has deviated from copybook script—indicates confidence and artistic ability. Disconnected writing is the cardinal sign of the loner. Very small signatures indicate inhibition and an inferiority complex; circles over the 'i' are a bid for attention, and crossing the 't' heavily over the whole word is a sign of intolerance and a patronizing attitude.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting accurately, and this must be combined with empathy and intuition. She feels more research is needed to put graphology on a proper scientific footing. This will happen soon, she believes. "It's actually far more accurate than psychoanalysis, as you can tell the whole history of the person, including all their emotional crises, without asking them questions to which they may give wrong answers."

Interesting as all this may sound, there is little hard evidence to support such claims. Some psychiatrists are highly critical of them. Handwriting, they say, is a product of education, artistic ability, and the type of writing taught—and has no other significance.

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and the right chairs are essential for a happy, healthy workforce, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to assess their health and happiness as work environments. Our expert panel included a building health consultant, an ergonomist, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their findings.

Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple; no central heating, no mechanical ventilation, and windows open directly to the street. Despite this, the small, dynamic team seems content. They adapt to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric radiators, much like at home. This homely environment, free from external bureaucracy, might be the key to their happiness.
Ergonomist: The furniture is mismatched and often leads to poor working postures. Chairs are old, mostly non-adjustable, and many are broken. However, the varied work schedule, which includes office tasks, client meetings, and presentations, helps reduce fatigue and boredom.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff enjoy the variety of work and the flexible office space. They find the office 'just the right size'—small enough to know what colleagues are doing, yet large enough for personal focus. The office is both attractive and fun, promoting efficiency and creativity.

Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is comfortable and not disliked by staff. Air quality and maintenance are good, supported by a No Smoking policy.
Ergonomist: The company has used an ergonomist before. Chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are excellent. Space is adequate, though layout could improve. The environment is impersonal with grey, bare walls.
Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for planners and a maternity rights poster. Staff relationships are satisfactory, with most employees there for over five years. Desk arrangement could improve information sharing. Success stories or project information could be displayed.

Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: The office gets mixed reactions. It feels like being in a glass case, viewing and being viewed by similar setups. Despite smokers and non-smokers sharing a small space, the air is not stale. Even near a smoker, cigarette smell is minimal.
Ergonomist: The office is standard and uninspiring. Desks are barely adequate. Not all chairs meet requirements, but this is user choice. Computer screens are on small desks with lowered keyboard shelves, which is outdated.
Occupational Psychologist: Staff are supportive and well-served by technology. Communication awards are displayed. The wood paneling and brown carpet create a sombre effect, but the office is busy.

Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: It's hard to say anything positive. The air-conditioning is crude, causing temperature variations. The space is cluttered with inadequate desk space. The office is dusty, with dust collecting on the shed-type roof, which can fall on those below.
Ergonomist: The furniture is more suited to a workshop than a high-tech office. Most chairs are unsuitable for keyboard users, especially those shorter than 1.75 m. Many chairs are old, lack adjustment, and have armrests that prevent getting close to the desk.
Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust, and dirt everywhere. There's much room for improvement—tidying up, recognizing individual success, and improving air conditioning are needed, especially with many smokers. Few conversations were happening; everyone seemed stressed and deadline-driven. The company should adopt team-working policies.'

Chewing Gum Culture

Chewing gum is popular and classless, with Americans consuming 12 million sticks daily. Learn how this ancient practice became a major industry. Each stick of gum has fewer than ten calories, but it is considered a food and must meet the American Food and Drug Administration's standards. Modern gum is mostly synthetic, with added pine resins and softeners to maintain flavor and texture. However, this wasn't always the case. The ancient Greeks chewed a resin from the mastic tree, found mainly in Greece and Turkey, to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Amero-Indians of New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, spruce lumps were sold in the eastern United States, marking the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum began in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in the Central American rainforest. This gum was smoother, more satisfying, and more elastic, leading to the birth of a new industry. However, attempts to cultivate sapodilla commercially have failed, and as the market grew, synthetic alternatives were developed. Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, known as chicleros, live a difficult and dangerous life, traveling long distances to tap scattered sapodilla trees in nearly 100% humidity. They face many dangers, including poisonous snakes and insects. The chicle fly, which lays eggs in the tappers' ears and nose, is particularly troublesome. Despite these hazards, chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap, which is then boiled into bricks at forest camps. Life at these camps is tough, with a monotonous maize-based diet and local alcohol made from sugar cane.

Despite the harsh conditions, chicleros worry about their future. The United States once imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle annually from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were tapped in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetics to cut costs and meet demand. Meanwhile, gum producers are finding creative ways to market their products. Gum is said to help you relax, boost energy, and reduce tension. It was even supplied to soldiers during both world wars.
