After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, especially the trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you’ll get soaked, but you don’t. Toy Land is great for younger children. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but were too small, which was a relief for us! The park is well-designed, so even queuing isn’t too boring. It’s very clean, and the staff are excellent. On one ride, a staff member offered to accompany one of my daughters when I couldn’t sit with both.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at one o'clock and were disappointed that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides aren’t too scary. I’m usually afraid, but I enjoyed myself. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts calmly and then becomes exciting. We queued for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn’t try the Big Leap, but it looked fun for those brave enough. If the children were older, they might have found it tame, but they were the right age and loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park advertises 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe’s tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is the most terrifying ride according to Ben, although Jennie found the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, which the older children rode several times. Sarah was too small for some, but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff attitudes varied; some were great with younger children, but not all were welcoming. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have dared to leave early.

Text: 'Running a business in the countryside Five women share their experiences of starting a business in rural areas. A. 'My customers are friends,' says CHRISTINE HOGAN, who runs a computer-aided design business with a yearly turnover of over £200,000 and four full-time employees. 'My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were young, and I wanted a job I could do from home. I had experience with computers before marriage, so my husband suggested starting a computer-aided design business. It required a lot of money, and the beginning was tough. But I was careful, always informing the bank manager if I might overspend. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evenings if needed. It remains a small business, and local clients usually pick up their work.' B. 'I enjoy being independent,' says MAGGY SASANOW, a greetings card designer working from home. 'I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But after marrying, we moved to the countryside, where such jobs weren't available. So, I started my own business, creating 50 different greetings cards that I sell to museums. I work in a large room upstairs. The downside of working from home is the constant chores, like mowing the lawn. My business grows through word of mouth—I don't advertise. People send work from London because I'm cheaper than other artists. Working alone means I miss exchanging ideas with others, but overall, the benefits outweigh the drawbacks.' C. 'It has been hard at times,' says DELIA TURNER, who runs a curtain-making business that has faced ups and downs. 'I started my business eight years ago. Back then, this type of business was growing, and my turnover increased from £24,000 to £80,000 in two years. I used to manage six full-time curtain-makers. But I had to let them go due to the economic downturn, which was tough because jobs are scarce here. I'm almost back to where I started, making curtains at home with my husband's help and using women who work from their homes. I have to be ready to lower my prices when needed and explore new opportunities.' D. TESSA STRICKLAND manages the editorial and production side of her children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. 'I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons: financial, as London was too expensive, and because I love the countryside. I enjoy working whenever I want. Eighty percent of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I take calls at odd hours. The downside is needing discipline to close the office door. I publish children's books from various cultures, collaborating with authors and artists. All my professional experience was in London, so I initially felt very isolated.' E. MEG RIVERS runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop with a yearly turnover of £250,000, employing six people, some part-time. 'I started ten years ago at home. I'm very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with high-quality flour and eggs. Then friends and relatives started requesting them, and soon I was sending cakes nationwide. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where everything is made—we have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I no longer bake, as I handle the business side. My biggest challenge has been the financial aspect, as we didn't have a lot of money to start with.'

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is unique in the music world. Not only are the sons, Paul and Huw, talented composers and musicians, but their father, John, also makes musical instruments. When Paul was ten, his parents, John and Hetty, wanted to buy him a cello to match his growing skills. However, they found the cost too high. John, a schoolteacher in South Wales, decided to try making one himself. He discovered the Welsh School of Instrument Making nearby and attended evening classes for about three years. After practicing with violins and violas, he successfully made his first cello for Paul. Paul used this cello until recently, as John improved his skills and made another one for him.

John eventually retired from teaching to become a full-time craftsman, making up to twelve violins a year. Selling a violin to the famous American musician Jaime Laredo was a highlight for him. Both Paul and Huw were encouraged to play music from a young age. Paul started with the piano but soon switched to the cello, inspired by a cellist in his father's music group. Although his parents wanted him to play the violin, Paul preferred the cello. Huw, on the other hand, chose the piano and composition, finding inspiration in Paul's success.

Paul's talent with the cello, made by his father, led him to win the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, a position he held until last year. He now plays a Francesco Rugeri cello, on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. John acknowledges that while his cello is excellent, it lacks the projection power of the 304-year-old Rugeri, which will improve with age.

Paul will soon perform Elgar's Cello Concerto on television with the Rugeri, but he won't be able to watch it as he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw will also be busy, with his String Quartet premiering in London at the Wigmore Hall. John and Hetty will need to be both diplomatic and energetic to keep up with their sons' busy musical schedules in the coming weeks.

Text: 'Caring for the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is an organization that aims to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden employed by the Trust to care for the beautiful areas it owns. According to Gareth, a National Trust Warden needs common sense. 'You also need to be good with people because you're always dealing with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building firms.' Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. About 80 people applied for the position of National Trust Warden for the Lleyn Peninsula. In the end, Gareth's local knowledge and farming experience got him the job, even though he didn't have formal training. 'It's helpful that I still farm with my parents and can relate to farmers and understand their problems. Also, they can't fool me about anything!' he says. His farming background also helps him handle the physical work of the job - putting up fences, planting trees, building walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. 'When I was young,' he remembers, 'I used to pick and press flowers, collect butterfly larvae, and old birds' nests. I recently thought, where would I find all those flowers, birds' nests, and grasshoppers now? It's clear to me that farming has changed the countryside. It's not the farmers' fault - they were just following government advice.' Gareth says that when he started, farmers and conservationists were against each other. Both wanted things done their way. Now they are talking and understanding each other's views. 'We're at a crossroads and just need a small step to bring them together,' says Gareth. Conservation is a key part of Gareth's work, along with public access to the Trust's land, tree planting and maintenance, and meeting the Trust's tenant farmers. 'My role is to ensure jobs are completed with minimal fuss and cost. What I enjoy most is seeing projects finished, although about half my time is spent on reports, signing bills, and so on.' Gareth is passionate about his job and, despite never being off duty, he enjoys every minute of it, especially talking to the public. Most of them, anyway. 'It's the attitude of some people I dislike,' he admits. 'They just come into the area, demand everything, then leave as if it's their right. Having to be nice to those people is annoying!' But as Gareth says, it's all about common sense. So if you have plenty of that and like the idea of an outdoor job, you might consider applying to become a warden like Gareth - but don't expect a job to be available on the Lleyn Peninsula for many years!'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is preparing for the upcoming World Championships. Her days are busy: she teaches at a local school and then trains in a supermarket car park. When asked if people stare, she says she's too focused on her training to notice much, though she might see cars slowing down.

Kendra is dedicated to being in top shape for the Championships. This will be her fourth time competing, and it's set to be the largest ever, with 27 countries participating. She feels the support from the home crowd will be special and hopes it will boost netball's reputation in England. However, this also means more pressure to perform well from the start. Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Although England has always beaten them, Kendra expects an exciting game because Barbados has talented players.

England is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be challenging. Unlike a series, there's no rest between games, and there's only one chance to win. Over her 15-year career, netball has become faster and more competitive. Kendra says, "You train to win, but after the game, we're all friends."

Netball now uses a scientific approach to fitness. Kendra believes it's crucial to think and train like world-class athletes. As captain, she aims to lead by example and support her team. Her netball career has been carefully planned, and she decided this competition will be her last as a player. She may coach young players in the future, but for now, she's focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might even shed a tear.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**

How should parents handle a child with exceptional musical talent? It's not always obvious how to nurture and support their gift. Some parents might not even notice their child's needs until frustration leads to difficult behavior. While most schools can support academically gifted children, musically talented ones need special attention that regular schools might not provide, especially if music is seen as a secondary subject. These children, along with those encouraged by parents or teachers, might benefit from attending a specialist music school.

In Britain, there are five specialist music schools, a relatively new concept. These schools offer a supportive environment for gifted children aged seven to eighteen to fully develop their skills with guidance from professional musicians. Students spend one-third to half of their day on musical activities, such as individual lessons (up to three hours a week on their main and secondary instruments), orchestras, chamber groups, voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice for several hours daily in well-equipped private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is dedicated to a limited academic program focusing on essential subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages, though students can study more subjects if they wish.

All five British specialist schools are independent, with small classes and a high teacher-to-student ratio. Most students are boarders, living full-time at the school, which means they spend their formative years with peers who share similar goals and interests.

What are the downsides? The main issue is the cost; boarding fees range from £12,000 to £17,000 a year. However, schools try to help parents of exceptionally gifted children with scholarships and financial aid. Additionally, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many school directors question the wisdom of admitting children as young as seven into such a demanding environment. They emphasize their goal is to develop 'rounded and well-balanced individuals.'

Separating musically gifted children from an early age can be stressful. Early musical talent might fade during teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to a sense of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help and advice if needed. While many former students feel they greatly benefited from the high-quality music education, some question the limited academic program, which is secondary to music activities. Many musically talented young people are also very intelligent and can handle academic challenges, feeling frustrated if their intellectual needs aren't met.

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is old enough to decide for themselves before considering specialist education. Those who are also academically gifted might thrive in a less specialized environment, such as a school with an excellent music department or by combining regular schooling with musical training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers and orchestral and chamber music experience. However, this option may not be feasible for families living far from London or other major cities.

Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her house is surrounded by a large garden, which provides many of her painting subjects. The garden is filled with her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread throughout the garden. The garden has a harmonious mix of colors, shapes, and structures, especially in the two long flower borders along the path that runs from east to west. This harmony is partly due to the previous owners, who were passionate gardeners and left behind plants that Susan liked. She also inherited the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden. We got along well. At first, he would say, 'Oh, it's not worth it' about some things I wanted to plant, but when I explained I wanted to paint them, he understood my vision."

Susan prefers to paint detailed studies of individual plants rather than the entire garden. Sometimes she paints groups of plants where they grow, but more often, she picks them and takes them to her studio. "I don't set up everything at once," she explains. "I paint one flower, which might take a few days, then I add another, building the painting gradually. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish." Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. "They all bloom together, and you're so busy," she says. She is also fascinated by the way flowers change as they decay. For example, with tulips, "you put them in water, leave them for a day, and they form different shapes. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring in a vase, but they constantly change with twists and turns."

Susan has always been interested in plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she recalls. "I wasn't interested in gardening then; I didn't like garden flowers because they looked like fake ones sold in some shops. To me, only wildflowers were real. I was fascinated by how they could grow in difficult places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs." Today, her garden includes many plants from distant lands, which seem as comfortable there as in their native China or the Himalayas. She has a relaxed approach to gardening, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don't cause serious harm. With two upcoming exhibitions and plenty of subjects right outside her door, she finds it hard to spend time gardening. She now employs an extra gardener, but despite her need to paint, she believes that to stay connected with her subjects, "you have to get your hands dirty."

Text: 'Keeping the holiday-makers happy A chalet girl's work is never done, Sarah Sutherland-Pilch tells Veronica Lee - in between making beds and delicious dinners. This is the second year as a chalet girl for Sarah Sutherland-Pilch, a 24-year-old from West Sussex. Known by her nickname, Pilch, Sarah works for a company in Val d'Isère, France, cooking and cleaning for visitors who come to ski and stay in the wooden houses, known as chalets, that are characteristic of the area. Sarah graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Being a chalet girl isn't a career, she says, but an enjoyable way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to make contacts. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not 'live in'. She gets up at 7 a.m. to walk the mile or so to the chalet, which sleeps up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before preparing that of the guests. 'They get the works - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' When the last of the guests has had breakfast, by about 9:30 a.m., Sarah clears up and either makes the afternoon tea, which is left for the guests to help themselves to, or cleans the rooms - 'the worst part of the job,' she says. By about 11 a.m. she is ready to go on the slopes herself. She skis as much as possible. 'On a good day we can be up there until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah returns to the chalet in time to prepare dinner and takes a shower before doing so, but does not sleep. 'It's fatal if you do,' she says. Dinner, a three-course affair, is served at 8 p.m. and coffee is usually on the table by 10 p.m. Sarah clears away the dinner things and fills the dishwasher. 'There's nothing worse than coming in to a messy kitchen the next morning.' Sometimes she will stay and chat with the guests, other times they are content to be left alone. 'Good guests can make a week brilliant - breakfast this morning was great fun - but some weeks, for whatever reason, don't go quite so well.' Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives - and they go out at about 11 p.m. 'We usually start off in Bananas, might go to G Jay's and perhaps Dick's T-Bar at the end of the evening,' she says. But Sarah never stays out too late on Saturday night as Sunday is her busiest time of the week. 'A frightful day,' she says, 'when you certainly don't want to be cooking breakfast feeling exhausted.' Work begins earlier than usual on Sunday, since breakfast for guests who are leaving has to be on the table by 7 a.m. As soon as the guests are gone, Sarah starts cleaning madly. 'We just blitz the place - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, get everything ready.' If she hasn't already done the week's shop on Saturday, Sarah does it now. At around 3 p.m., the cleaning work done, Sarah then prepares tea for the new guests. 'They get here at around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are disorientated and full of questions. I'm sure it's the mountain air that does something to them.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes any guests needing boots or skis down to the ski shop and then gets a lift back to the chalet from one of the ski shop staff. It is soon time for dinner duty again and perhaps a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I just have an early night,' she says.'

Text: 'Changing Lives with a Stranger'

Mandie Currie, a zoo-keeper, spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. 'Choosing what to wear was difficult because I usually wear a uniform. First, I visited a still-life photo studio, then went to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and peaceful, and here I was rushing around instead of sitting quietly with an animal. Some of the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job isn't usually pressured. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed thinking I'd normally be cleaning cages or handling rats. I'm interested in how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I'll stay there.'

Alice Cutler, a fashion assistant at Marie Claire, spent a day at London Zoo. 'I arrived in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. As I stroked an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a brilliant day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa.'

Karen Hodson, a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital, joined the TV gardening programme Ground Force. 'I was excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was really nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Depending on my shifts, I sometimes don't see daylight. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. My romantic idea of landscape gardening didn't include hard work or careful planning. I was more enthusiastic than effective, so I won't give up my other job.'

Charlie Dimmock, a landscape gardener with Ground Force, worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. 'I made beds and handed out tablets. I thought I might faint doing some jobs, but I was surprised that it didn't bother me. The friendship among the nurses is great, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual male environment. I feel my job is a waste of time compared to nursing. My day at the hospital wasn't exactly pleasant, but it left me with a great sense of satisfaction.'

Lucy Harvey, a personal trainer, spent the day with Ryanair as cabin crew. 'I changed into the uniform, and immediately felt different—people suddenly respected me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack, which I knew from my fitness training. When passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt self-conscious. On the return journey, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult.'

Sonia McDermott, an air hostess with Ryanair, spent the day as a personal trainer in a gym. 'I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was amazed at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, you meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch to see some trainers didn't eat ultra-healthily, but they all drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. However, it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier.'

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Journeys**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to return as often as I can. There's a local train from Cannes along the coast that crosses into Italy. It offers some of the most stunning sea views. No matter the weather or season, it's always enchanting. From the other window, you can see some of the finest gardens and homes in France, making you feel like you're peeking into the lives of the rich and famous. The travelers are always lively, a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the breathtaking journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I've enjoyed many rail journeys over the years, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. Growing up in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to the Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn't traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real station I saw, and its great glass dome amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I owe a lot to one train in particular: the Blue Train, which took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone mentioned that pink is good for the brain, and I've worn the color ever since. What I remember most about the journey is how lovely it was to travel through France and then by boat up the Nile to Luxor. It was the perfect way to relax after the wedding preparations.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were working on a series of articles about a round-the-world trip and had to cross a desert in an African country. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express. The timetable was unreliable—we were just given a day. We heard that the driver would often wait for days to depart if he knew people were still on their way. When it appeared, there was a rush of people climbing into and onto the carriages—some even traveled on the roof for free. During the night, the train crossed some of the most beautiful landscapes I've ever seen. It was like a dream, like traveling across the moon.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people form their favorite impressions of trains when they are young, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn't until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film featuring a railway in Yorkshire. Most filming took place on an old, disused line maintained by volunteers. That's where my passion for steam trains began. When we weren't filming, we rode the train whenever we could. When I returned last year, it was as if time had stood still. Everything was still in place, even the gas lights on the station platform!

Text: 'Trying to get published? If you're wondering where to send your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has the advice you need. Readers often ask, 'I have written this story/book. Who should I send it to?' The first thing to know is that you should research your markets and learn about publishers while improving your writing skills. Turning words into something sellable requires knowledge about the 'writing game'. Whatever you write, you need to understand the markets you're targeting. The best way to do this is by reading everything relevant. Use your local library and visit bookshops and newsagents. Reading widely will guide you on what kinds of writing publishers are accepting at any time. This knowledge must be updated regularly as new publications appear, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. New titles come and go constantly. Publishers are always looking for new talent; as writers, we must give them what they want. Initially, you might not be sure what you want to write. If you think you might like to write short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them, as it's a limited market, and get recent copies. Familiarize yourself with the stories they buy, noting who the readers are. These readers expect different things from their magazine, and the editor focuses on meeting their needs. Writers often send me their stories saying, 'This has been rejected three times - am I wasting my time? Do I stand a chance?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But it's unlikely the work is publishable; I try to give an honest opinion, always positively. Most new writers are too eager to send their work out, often before they're ready. If you've only written one story or article, it's unlikely to be published. That almost never happens. When you hear about 'success', the person usually has years of experience in publishing or journalism. When you send off your work for the first time, start on more work while waiting for a reply; write ten more stories, even twenty. Each one will be better, and you'll start to see yourself as a writer, with growing fluency and confidence. Don't throw any of them away—improve them instead. Also, I advise not showing your work to others, especially early on. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before succeeding. Do everything you can to advance your writing career. See if there's a creative writing course nearby. If not, join a local writers' group to gain ideas and confidence from other aspiring writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing—every day if possible.'

Title: 'A Favor at the Station'

On the last day of a difficult year, I was at the Baltimore railway station, waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. The station was more crowded than I expected. Usually, it felt airy and clean, but now elderly couples with matching luggage filled the benches, and college students sat on the floor with their bags. 

A well-dressed, grey-haired man was moving around, talking to strangers. He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her something. Then he came to a girl near me with long blond hair. I had thought about talking to her myself. The man asked, "Are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

She replied, "Well, northbound, yes." 

"But to Philadelphia?" he insisted. 

"No, New York, but I'll be..." 

"Thanks, anyway," he said, moving on. Now, he had my full attention. 

"Ma'am," I heard him ask an older lady, "are you traveling to Philadelphia?" 

When she said, "Wilmington," he moved on to another couple. I straightened up and moved closer, pretending to focus on the train. I was going to Philadelphia, and he could have asked me. But I understood why he didn't; I probably seemed unreliable. He glanced at me briefly and then moved to another bench, looking stressed. 

"Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" 

She lowered her book. She seemed about thirty-five, older than me, and looked like a schoolteacher. 

"Philadelphia?" she said. "Why, yes, I am." 

"Then could I ask you a favor?" 

I stopped a few feet away, pretending to check my watch, though I didn't have one. I sensed she was cautious. The man must have noticed too, because he added, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" 

They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, dragging their wheeled bags. I heard the man explaining, "My daughter's flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, then went for groceries, and when I got home, my wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the Philadelphia station, unsure what to do." 

The woman clucked sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet, waiting to see where this was going. 

"So I told her to stay put. I said I'd find someone here to take her passport." 

A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so urgent? 

"Why don't you go yourself?" the woman asked. 

"I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair." 

This seemed like a weak excuse, in my opinion. It was too much bad luck for one family. I glanced at them. The man held a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one, the size of a paperback book. Aha! Padded, so you couldn't feel the contents! And it looked stapled shut. Watch yourself, lady, I thought silently.

Text: 'Gary and Me The restaurant owner John Moore writes about his relationship with his son Gary, the famous TV chef. I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very poor condition, but it was perfect for my plans. Starting this business reminded me of my childhood. I remember my mother working in a factory and feeling upset because I was left alone. With that in mind, I thought, 'We need time for family life.' My wife focused on taking care of the children and managed all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant back then, and we always made sure to have meals together. This has been very beneficial for our children, Gary and Joe. They're both very confident. From a young age, they would come down and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life. Gary was quite energetic as a child. We had a corner bath, and when he was about seven, he tried to jump into it like a swimming pool and knocked himself out. As he grew older, he had to work for pocket money. He started with odd jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had plenty of money at school. He was disciplined. He would wake up even before me in the morning. If you run a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping out. Gary wasn't very academic, but he excelled in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as any of the men working there, and sometimes he was even in charge. He would prepare over a hundred meals, and from then I knew he'd go into catering because he had that talent. So when he came to me and said, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for my school course,' I sent him to a friend of mine who owns a restaurant. Gary recently started playing the drums and now he has his own band. Who knows what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary would be: if you try to do too many things at once, you might not succeed in any, so focus on what you know you can achieve. He understood when I told him: 'Gary, if you want to succeed in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. If you haven't done it by then, it's too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students - usually complete beginners - were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had chopped all his vegetables and sliced all his meats. He'd prepared everything. That's my son for you! In the end, he was helping others. None of us can believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become. I'm extremely proud of him. I've always tried to tell him that if you want something, you have to work very hard for it, because no one gives you anything. He's seen the opportunity he was given and seized it. You know, you talk to your children as they grow up, and if they only remember ten percent of what you've told them, you should be happy with that. The things Gary says and does make me think he must have listened sometimes.'

Finding an affordable flat in Dublin was as difficult as finding gold during a gold rush. The best way to find a place was through personal connections: if you knew someone who knew someone leaving a flat, that often worked. But for someone like Jo, who had just arrived in Dublin, there were no personal contacts to rely on. She had no one to inform her about a soon-to-be-vacant bedsit. So, she stayed in a hostel and searched for a place. To Jo, Dublin was an unknown territory. She felt like she was stepping into the unknown when she boarded the train to work there. She never questioned why she was going; it was assumed by everyone at her school that she would leave. Who would want to stay in a small, remote town? That's all she had heard for years. Everyone planned to leave, to experience life, to truly live. Some of her classmates had moved to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where they had family to help them settle. But none from Jo's year were heading to Dublin. She was going alone. Jo's mother thought it would be great if she stayed permanently in the hostel, as it was run by nuns and safe. Her father hoped the hostel was warm, as they were known to be cold. Jo's sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying a whole week in a hostel. But Jo was unaware of their thoughts as she responded to an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It offered an 'Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked and seemed too good to be true. She hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn't be too expensive. There wasn't a queue because it was more 'Third Girl Wanted' than 'Flat to Let.' The mention of 'own television' made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked ordinary. It was a red-brick terraced house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A cheerful girl with a college scarf, clearly a failed applicant, was coming down the stairs. 'Desperate place,' she said to Jo. 'They're both awful. Common as dirt.' 'Oh,' said Jo and continued climbing. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'Do? She didn't have to do anything. She just looked around, made a face, giggled, and said, "Is this all there is? Oh dear, oh dear," in a posh accent. We wouldn't have her here, would we, Pauline?' Pauline wore a psychedelic shirt, almost as bright as her hair. Jo noted with amazement that Pauline was a punk. She had seen punks on O'Connell Street but hadn't spoken to one before. 'I'm Jo, I work in the post office and I called about the flat.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She brought out three mugs; one said 'Nessa,' one said 'Pauline,' and the other said 'Other.' 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said generously.

Text: 'Behind the Dolphin's Smile People love dolphins. We eagerly watch them in marinas, films, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society warns that dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds discusses the decline of these species. Dolphins are special to us. They are among the most intelligent animals, sensitive to human emotions, and they inspire dreams of freedom in the wild seas. TV has fueled this affection, with shows like Flipper and Seaquest's Darwin. Yet, these cheerful images hide the harsh reality dolphins face in polluted and overfished seas today. The North Sea harbour porpoise population, a type of dolphin, has decreased by up to 89,000. Despite their popularity, dolphins are not adequately protected by law or marine reserves. This neglect could lead to a major wildlife crisis. There are forty types of dolphins worldwide. In northern Europe, the most common are the striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The first two live far out at sea, usually seen in small groups, and we know little about them. The larger bottlenoses and harbour porpoises were once common near European coasts. Bottlenoses, very social, were found along the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in Scotland's Moray Firth and Wales' Cardigan Bay, and those remaining show signs of stress. Dolphins' complex habits make it hard to pinpoint why their numbers are falling. Overfishing, which reduces fish stocks and threatens local fishing industries, also endangers dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are overfished, they may not survive. They also risk getting caught in fishing nets, which they can't see. Modern fishing uses large nets that float or are dragged quickly through the sea. Recently, many dead dolphins have washed up on French and Cornish beaches, showing marks from nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can accumulate in dolphins. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, allowing dolphins to absorb them, which then build up in their bodies. Females produce milk rich in pesticides, passing the poison to their young. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Perhaps the most debated threat is human disturbance. Dolphins live in groups and rely on sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise pollution from ships and oil wells travels four times more efficiently than in air, potentially disturbing dolphins in unknown ways.'

Text: 'GETTING FIT Exercise is crucial for your mind, body, and spirit. It's one of the best ways to keep balance in your life, especially when everything around you feels chaotic. You might be tired of hearing about fitness, but there's a reason it's so often discussed: it's genuinely beneficial. There are many reasons to exercise and very few reasons not to, for most people. Exercise enhances muscle tone and quickly changes body shape. It boosts muscle strength and encourages good posture, which is how you hold your body when sitting or standing. It helps prevent muscle imbalances that can lead to injuries. Exercise also quickly improves specific areas like thighs, stomach, and upper arms. It benefits the heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons many times, and perhaps you're bored of them. But here's something to consider: exercise can ease depression and tiredness, regulate sleep patterns, and control stress. It can also help with certain medical conditions. By now, these points should have some impact on you. If not, common sense should tell you that exercise is beneficial. There are many types of exercise you can try, such as aerobics, calisthenics, jogging, or weight training. However, be cautious: training too hard or with too much weight can cause injury, so start slowly and carefully. If unsure, consult your doctor about what's best for you. Good posture is essential for improving body shape. A stiff or sagging body not only looks unattractive but also lacks energy and is prone to minor health issues. If you tend to slouch, imagine a helium balloon pulling the top of your head upwards. This helps lift your chest for better breathing and makes your body look slimmer. When standing with a balanced chest, you should be able to see your ankles. Stretching improves flexibility and movement, helps maintain correct posture, and prevents muscle injuries. Doing it four or five times a week will ensure a more flexible, fitter body. Stretching should be a key part of your exercise routine, done slowly and precisely. The best exercise routine includes a good warm-up, stretching exercises, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.'

Text: 'IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT What motivates film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman to leave their home comforts for months? The quest for the perfect shot. Among the many creatures in the jungles and plains of East Africa, two of the hardest to find are producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. Currently, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has experienced six months of almost continuous rain, leading to unexpected challenges. Newman explained that they had to buy an expensive tool so that whenever their vehicle gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him out. Their partnership has produced some of TV's best wildlife films, like their acclaimed film on leopards. Even while this film about Africa's shyest cats was airing, they were back in the wild, this time following the equally elusive jackal. This is common in television partnerships. Travelling film-makers have been exploring the globe to capture exotic wildlife since television began. I spoke to Newman about their partnership during one of his rare visits to a safari lodge. 'We sometimes argue but resolve it quickly,' he says about his colleague. Neither sees themselves as the leader, and he believes they get along well because they view animals similarly. 'When we travel, we set up our tents each night. But now we have a more fixed camp, and since we start at 5 a.m., we make tea the night before and keep it warm in a flask.' Their daily diet includes pre-packed meals heated by whoever is available. 'We can be out for up to eight weeks, so food can be a concern,' says Newman. It can be tough, but being alone in remote areas allows them to get close to the animals. Newman recalls filming a lion family where a lioness would greet their car as part of her routine. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on 'The Great Rift', and two years later, they teamed up to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they spend four months on location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before starting, they must submit a script for approval. 'Amanda and I developed a good working relationship from the start,' says Newman, 'because we shared the same ideas and vision. We aim to create films rich in atmosphere, capturing the true spirit of the place and animals, and touching people's hearts. I believe evoking an emotional response is better than appealing only to the intellect.'

**The Netball Captain**

In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis interviewed England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra leads England's netball team and is preparing for next month's World Championships. Her routine includes teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. When asked if she gets odd looks while training there, she replied, "I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice anything else. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra is dedicated to being in top form for the Championships. This will be her fourth time competing, and it promises to be the largest event yet, with 27 countries participating. "Having home support is special," she says. "It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing at home means more pressure and expectations from the crowd. People expect us to start strong."

Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Historically, England has always beaten them, but Kendra finds them exciting to play against due to their skill. England is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra acknowledges the challenges of the World Championships. "You have to push yourself every day, with no rest between games. Unlike a series, there's only one chance to win."

In her 15 years at the top level, netball has become more intense and aggressive. "You train hard to win," Kendra says. "But after the final whistle, we're all friendlier." The sport now uses a more scientific approach to fitness. "We must think and train like world-class players," she adds. As captain, Kendra believes in having a strong mental attitude and leading by example, supporting and encouraging her team.

Kendra's netball career has been carefully planned from the start. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. While she may coach young players in the future, her focus is on this final event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye, with her loyal supporters cheering her on.

Text: 'In hot water Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, studying chemical processes in the sea. Rachel is a lecturer at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When not teaching, she dives three kilometres into the Atlantic Ocean in a small steel vehicle to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'space is so limited that I can touch the two pilots. We can't stand or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and three hours to return to the surface.' 'If there's a problem and we need to surface quickly, we can hit a panic button. The outside drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that shoots to the surface like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but I don't think it would be pleasant.' 'I didn't know how I would react the first time I entered the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck, and I got in with an instructor. He explained emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing my reaction to being in such a small space.' Rachel has now made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. 'We went to a site five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. On the ocean floor, there is a large area of underwater volcanoes, their chimneys releasing black smoke. It's where the Atlantic Ocean comes alive. The Russian team was placing scientific equipment there to study the effect of a multi-national program that would drill a 150-metre hole through a volcano.' When not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it to continue my research into the "black smokers". This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke, pouring out at one metre per second and at 350 degrees.' 'The only time I was frightened was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when there was an explosion. A huge bang hit our vehicle, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We stared at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!' 'Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is such an adventure. Every time I look out of the porthole and see those chimneys, I feel a sense of wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. Seeing them for real was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are crucial. Studies show that people form opinions about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice our clothing, eye contact, body language, speaking speed, volume, tone, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce, who studied to be a teacher, shares her experience: "I worked hard for my degree and felt confident when I graduated." She applied for a job at a local primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she recalls. "I could have changed, but I didn't want to be late, as punctuality is important to me." Mary didn't get the job. A friend at the school told her the Head Teacher commented, "If someone doesn't present their best image at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "Interviewees who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. People think inner qualities matter most, but in an interview, you should present yourself in the best way possible." Many overlook the importance of a professional image. For instance, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a large accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the position but wasn't even interviewed. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel," she says. "He told me I didn't fit the image of an office manager and suggested I improve my wardrobe before applying again. I was shocked. I do a good job, and my attire shouldn't matter."

Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our feelings and attitudes are communicated through words, 38% through voice, and 55% through facial expressions. If facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will trust the non-verbal message more. Ensure your words match your body language to avoid confusing the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, and her interview went so well that she was offered the job immediately. "I was delighted," she recalls. "But I showed too much enthusiasm. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't refuse. As a result, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have negotiated more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, consider what you say and how you say it during an interview. David Artesio, an employment agency manager, suggests researching the company beforehand. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company's activities. Mention an area that interests you during the interview. This will show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. As she says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators use short sentences and bullet points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London but now runs a sheep farm. "After 14 years in business, the City became less exciting and more of a grind. I hadn't planned to leave for another five or ten years, but I was made redundant unexpectedly. The pay-off wasn't great, but it was enough to start the farm. My big break came when I met the head chef of a top local hotel. By supplying them, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat by mail order. I'm glad I'm not in an office anymore, but surprisingly, I still work 80- to 90-hour weeks and sell a product."

**The Painter**  
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising but now earns a living as an artist. "Painting started as a hobby, but I found it more exciting than my job. Taking redundancy to become an artist seemed logical. A career counsellor helped me, though he was surprised because most people in their mid-forties need to work for money. We married young, and our children didn't need our support. Moving to the north of England was a leap into the unknown, leaving friends behind. Fortunately, our friendships have survived, and many visit us now."

**The Hatmaker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a company lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. "Being a lawyer was fun and well-paid, but the hours were terrible. I didn't want to become a senior partner with even more hours, so I left. People said I'd get bored, but that never happened. The secret is having deadlines. In fashion, there's always something to do, so I keep a strict schedule. I'm happier and less stressed now. I miss social interaction with colleagues, but I love being responsible for my product. If I do a bad job, it's on me. You care more when your name is on the promotional material."

**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. "I started in financial markets at 22, setting up deals. I liked the adrenaline but didn't find the work rewarding. I almost got made redundant in 1989 but resigned and traveled for a year to figure out what I wanted. I was interested in health, so I visited top gymnasiums and talked to owners. To change careers, I needed qualifications, so I took massage courses. Then I got part-time work at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my destiny."

Text: 'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I've always been into sports. I tried many, but I was best at football and athletics. At 14, I had a trial with a professional football club, but I chose athletics instead. My proudest moment was competing for my country in the youth team and winning a medal. Unfortunately, it didn't attract much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped for sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun there with great facilities and nightlife. However, discipline is crucial. If friends invite me out before training, I have to decline. I wish I didn't have to, but dedication is key in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you often meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn, so late-night parties are out of the question. I don't mind that much, but I do miss sleeping in. It's worth it, though, as my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I make sure to celebrate, especially if there's prize money involved. The sacrifices pay off because winning the championship led to me hosting a surfing series on TV. I guess I'm a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We're traditional and always celebrate a win in style. Some say we act childishly, but we don't seek media attention. Reporters often care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home, hang out with friends, and do normal things. You can't focus on the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I've rarely been recognized on the street, which suits me. I get many requests for signed pictures, and I reply to each one. It takes time, but it's worth it. D Tomas (tennis player) It's great to feel the crowd's support when I walk on court. At the last tournament, it got a bit overwhelming with people crowding around. Still, I enjoy being recognized by fans when I'm out. It has downsides, though. My last girlfriend didn't like the attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up, I think. It was tough, but sacrifices are part of any sport; you must be serious and professional. It doesn't bother me much now. I'm focused on my game and will catch up on other things after I retire, which happens early in this sport.'

Text: 'Young Shoppers Shopping with children can be very challenging for parents. One mother describes it as "absolute murder" because her children want everything they see, from sugary cereals to Disney videos and comics. She feels guilty if she gives in to their demands, but also feels bad for saying no all the time. She tries to avoid taking them shopping but worries they won't learn to make their own choices. Research shows that children ask for something every two minutes during a supermarket trip. Over £150 million is spent each year on advertising aimed directly at children, mostly on TV. This amount is expected to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising is most effective. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy everything they want, and health arguments about sugar don't compete well with appealing ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says parents care about what their children eat, but their ideas about healthy food aren't always correct. It's important for parents and children to talk about food, as relying only on TV ads gives a biased view. Parents feel frustrated competing with advertisers and having to disappoint their children. The Independent Television Commission bans ads from telling kids to ask their parents to buy things, but the goal of ads is still to persuade. Deciding which requests to accept or refuse is stressful for parents. One mother says her son is critical of ads because they discuss products and labels together, reducing conflict in the supermarket. Parents admit they are inconsistent in their responses. Mike, a father, says they refuse sweets for their son while buying treats for themselves. He finds it hard to be consistent, as his decisions depend on his mood. Supermarkets could help by removing sweets from checkout areas or offering play areas for children. Although parents might spend less without their children, the idea of shopping without their demands could attract more customers.'

**Five-star luxury meets modern technology**

The five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It took nearly two years to convert four large 18th-century houses into this luxury hotel. This transformation allowed the installation of the latest technology for both staff and guests. General Manager Peter MacCann expects his staff to know guests by name, but for specific preferences, he uses the hotel's computer system. This system, which cost £250,000, helps treat returning guests in a special way, as expected in a five-star hotel. For instance, if a guest requests certain music CDs during their first stay, those CDs will be ready for them on their next visit. This is possible due to the guest-history feature that records preferences.

Room temperature is a common complaint among hotel guests worldwide. At the Merrion, a high-tech system allows guests to adjust the temperature within a range of three degrees from the standard 18°C. Additionally, the front desk can adjust each room's temperature between 14°C and 25°C. Business travelers, who are expected to make up 65% of the hotel's clientele, will appreciate the technology in the rooms. Each room includes three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing facility. To keep up with rapid technological changes, extra cables have been installed for future upgrades. Televisions are rented, allowing for easy replacement with newer models, and DVD recorders can be updated as needed.

Despite the advanced technology, the hotel aims to make guests feel comfortable and not overwhelmed. The 145 large, well-furnished bedrooms are designed to be both comfortable and welcoming. The hotel also features a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. As with all luxury hotels, excellent food is a must. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, whose Dublin restaurant already had two Michelin stars, moved his business to the Merrion. This move benefits both him and the hotel, as he could design a modern kitchen and enjoy better parking facilities. The hotel gains a popular dining venue without financial risk. With advanced technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion is set for success.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women who live life to the fullest to share their secrets.

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:**  
"I think excitement gives me energy. I need to be doing something challenging. Learning new things energizes me. Anything with rhythm, like flamenco dancing, also boosts my energy. Dance is expressive and invigorating. Feeling bored or that life is pointless can drain you. Being effective, even in small ways, gives you energy."

**B. Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:**  
"I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it, so it doesn't feel like a chore. Enjoying what you do keeps you from feeling low, even if you're tired. I need a good amount of sleep to feel great. When I only get six hours, I feel sluggish. Exercise gives me energy, but finding the energy to start is hard! I do yoga once a week and try workout tapes at home. Exercise lifts my spirits. I feel low in the office between 3 and 5 PM, so I think it's good to eat something then."

**C. Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:**  
"I don't eat healthily for energy; it's my natural enthusiasm and positivity. I dislike negative attitudes. I believe in enjoying life and seizing the moment. Enjoyment is key. Achieving goals is important. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. Being around lively young people is energizing. I enjoy a busy life and am very sociable. I like taking photos and writing imaginary song lyrics for fun. It's a good mental release when traveling."

**D. Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
"My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and family life, and being positive helps. I love working with kids; they are resilient and give a lot. Energy is like a natural chemical, triggered by interacting with others. Smiling at people and getting a smile back is thrilling. It's better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise plan. My most energetic moments are playing with kids."

**E. Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:**  
"I love turning wasteland into a garden. I once transformed a concrete area by breaking it up and adding soil. It was better than any workout. Knowing someone wants to read my writing gives me energy; writing in a void is hard. I enjoy sneaking into private land, pretending I didn't know it was private. It's childlike and fun."

**F. Katherine Monblot, Therapist:**  
"You must respect and be interested in what you do. I like taking risks and get bored quickly, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you dislike drains you. I used to be on committees and resented the time they took. You have limited energy, so focus it on what's most important to you."

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron was introduced in Scandinavia around 200 AD. In Scandinavia, the upper classes considered skating an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was elegant and reserved. However, at the 1924 Winter Olympics, 11-year-old Sonja Henie brought a more athletic style, making skating more popular. Today, skating combines art and athletics, making it both graceful and physically challenging.

For beginners, balance and control are crucial, and speed comes with practice. Your body position is key to maintaining balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees flexed to center your body weight, leaning slightly forward. Relaxation is essential in skating, more so than in other sports. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot while making a small movement with the other foot. It seems simple, right? As you practice, you can gradually increase the length of your movements.

Learning how to fall is one of the first skills a skater should acquire. Even top professionals fall. To avoid injury, try to stay relaxed when falling, which reduces the impact. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you feel confident moving on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. The best approach is to start with figure skating and then learn basic freestyle. Most ice rinks offer guidance, so you can quickly learn basic figures and then move on to turns, jumps, and spins.

If you watch skilled or professional skaters, you'll notice how relaxed and smooth they are. To achieve this, you should regularly practice exercises. Skating with a stiff body can be dangerous, so warm-up exercises should include those for the legs, back, and shoulders, focusing on the ankles and knees. After a long or intense session, do the same exercises to prevent stiffness.

Skating improves balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It enhances heart and lung function and strengthens the body. When combined with swimming or jogging, it offers a great program for overall health and fitness.

**Trills and Triumphs**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can be very moving. Julia Gregson spoke with three young achievers and their mothers about the joys and challenges they face.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15,** won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She dreams of becoming a physiotherapist and competing in the next Olympics. "The work is tough right now. There's no time for TV, hanging out with friends, or much else besides gymnastics and school. I try to take each training day as it comes. When I'm extremely tired, my coach might give me a day off, but usually, I just keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you'll get stiff."

**B. Annika's mother** says, "Annika showed great potential from a young age. I've seen parents push their kids, but it doesn't work. To perform at Annika's level, you have to want it yourself. People often say we've sacrificed a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it's done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she's met people worldwide and gained confidence from her success."

**C. Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at ten and has since won the British National Championship. "It's good my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love the excitement and fun. Even without my parents, I'd do it because I'm determined. I'm glad they're happy when I win, but I'm not doing it for them. My goal this year is to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win an Olympic gold medal."

**D. Sarah's mother** recalls, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, she was hooked. At 5, she'd get up before us to exercise her pony. To qualify for major shows, you have to compete all over England. To save money, we sleep in our horse box's living quarters. Sarah is well-organized and completely happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is unbeatable."

**E. Jane McShane, 10,** is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about getting a big head; I don't talk about my success at school. I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's mother** shares, "Jane played her first game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. Of course, I'm pleased when she wins, but if she wanted to quit tomorrow, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down for being exceptional. If she has this gift, let her reach her potential."

Text: 'It's true - we're all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. 'What do you want to be?' asked the teacher. 'The flagpole on a ship?' The teacher had a point - because Chris, though only fourteen, was already almost two metres tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is Britain's tallest man. Every decade, the average height of people in Europe increases by another centimetre. Each year, more truly tall people are born. Interestingly, this doesn't mean we're creating a new super race. Instead, we're returning to our ancient size. We're losing the effects of generations of poor diet - with dramatic results. 'We are only now beginning to reach our true potential,' says palaeontologist Professor Chris Stringer. 'We are becoming like the Cro-Magnons again - the people who lived on this planet 40,000 years ago.' For most of human history, our ancestors got their food from many sources: women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men added occasional animal kills (a lifestyle still followed by the world's few remaining hunter-gatherer tribes). One study found they based their diet on 85 different wild plants. Then about 9,000 years ago, agriculture was invented - with serious consequences. Most of the planet's green areas have been taken over by farmers, so just three carbohydrate-rich plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories consumed by humans today. This poor diet has had a negative effect on human health and physique. Over the centuries, we have lived on soups, porridges, and breads that have left us underfed and underdeveloped. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when they began to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly, underweight farmers. Tooth decay increased, as did diseases. Far from being a blessing of the New World, corn was a public health disaster, according to some anthropologists. Nevertheless, agriculture spread because a piece of farmed land could support ten times the number of people who had previously lived off it as hunter-gatherers. The fact that most people relying on this system are poorly nourished and stunted has only recently been addressed, even by the world's wealthier nations. Only in Europe, the US, and Japan are diets again reflecting the richness of our ancestors' diets. As a result, the average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. It is a positive trend, though not without its own problems. Heights may have increased, but the world has not adapted. A standard bed-length has remained at 190 cm since 1860. Even worse, leg-room in planes and trains seems to have decreased, while clothes manufacturers are constantly revising their product ranges. The question is: where will it all end? We cannot grow forever. We must have some programmed upper limit. But what is it? According to Robert Fogel, of University, it could be as much as 193 cm - and we are likely to reach it this century. However, scientists add one note of caution. Individuals may be growing taller because of improved nutrition, but as a species, we are actually shrinking. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were slightly rounder and taller - an evolutionary response to the cold. (Large, round bodies are best at keeping in heat.) Since the climate warmed, we appear to have become slightly thinner and smaller, even when properly fed. And as the planet continues to heat up, we may shrink even further. In other words, the growth of human beings could be offset by global warming.'

Text: 'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being filmed? Cosmo Landesman explored this. Like technical difficulties, studio audiences are a common part of television, yet they remain a mystery to many. Watching them get excited on game shows, we often wonder - who are these people? Among all live entertainment audiences, studio audiences are often seen as the least prestigious. I've heard that even people in the TV industry look down on them, treating them, as one cameraman said, 'like cattle'. I used to think studio audiences were just people eager for a brief moment of fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all walks of life. TV shows try to attract different people for different programs. Those of us who prefer watching TV at home can't understand why anyone would go to a studio. Why apply for tickets, travel far, and endure hours of boredom in an uncomfortable studio to watch something you can see at home? One idea is that people hope to appear on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for the chance to be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious about what happens behind the scenes. But the most common reason I heard was simply, 'a friend gave me a ticket'. Few of us have been in a studio audience, yet we think we know what it's like. You sit there, crowded among strangers, while someone holds up signs saying APPLAUD or LAUGH - and you clap or laugh as instructed. This might be true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager says, 'We always hope a show will be good enough not to need these signs.' But is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is 'more exciting', while Charlotte enjoyed feeling involved with live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. Watching him on TV at home, you miss a lot.' What I missed was seeing live actors - from my seat, I could only see the back of someone's head. The opening scenes were filmed so far away that I ended up watching on a studio monitor. Going to a studio might be a bad way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most of the audience, it was simply fun and a free night of entertainment.'

**Favourite Places**

**Bruce**  
I prefer landscapes that have a human touch. When I travel, I am drawn to charming villages with old temples rather than empty deserts. At eight, I went to school in England and would cycle to the village of Lastingham on Saturdays. Cycling was my escape from school. I enjoyed exploring the bleak hilltops, sheltered valleys, and old villages. Being from Scotland, the landscape felt both familiar and different, and I still visit today. I used to write about my adventures in a private diary, which was my first step into travel writing, a field where I later became well-known.

**Sophia**  
There is a miniature railway from Hythe to Dungeness, run by enthusiasts. I always travel first class as it’s only slightly more expensive. The scenery isn’t spectacular; the train crosses Romney Marsh with its sheep and runs alongside a canal. However, I always look forward to the part where the train passes through back gardens. For a few moments, we glimpse people in their daily routines, like making tea or unfolding a deckchair. I see myself through their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, peering into their homes. It’s the ordinariness of the landscape that attracts me, just fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. This simplicity makes me look closer, searching for something that opens my eyes.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a remote and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and rocky, so there are few crowds. Some brave surfers visit, but most people come to admire the sea's majesty. The coast faces the Atlantic and is known for shipwrecks. There are coastal walks you can combine with trips inland through beautiful, damp valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in modest self-catering accommodation with a family who owns property in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a landscape of wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. There are few residents and visitors. It’s an unknown, empty, and remote corner, and I love the feeling of space. I discovered it by chance as a student and have visited annually since, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has changed little since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. It saddens me that he’s growing up in an urban environment.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain, to find pure peace and reconnect with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka but went to school in Devon at twelve. I used to cycle around the moors and village backstreets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you’d never return. That place was Glenthorne. It’s the house of my dreams, a magical, secluded, romantic place where you can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

Title: A Day of Animal Chaos

We are a family that loves animals and often finds ourselves in amusing situations with them. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work, excited about finding a pine snake. She asked if we could keep it, and I agreed, but only for one night. We had a special tank ready for temporary animal guests, giving us time to admire them and learn more from our natural history book.
