Text: 'CARTOON FILMS Cartoon films have very few limits. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. With new ideas and advanced computer programs, cartoons are becoming exciting again for people of all ages. By the late 1970s, the cinema industry thought cartoons were only for children. But soon after, a few directors had some original ideas. They showed that it was possible to make films that both adults and children could enjoy. However, not every cartoon film was successful. The Black Cauldron, for example, failed because it was too scary for children and too childish for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.'

Text: 'New TV Star Caroline Benson discusses her first TV role. "I never expected to spend part of my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted in school plays, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I imagined playing her. I took a year off to travel before university. While in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV drama. I knew I had to try for the role. She was surprised but sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week into the term, so I got permission from the university to be away for three weeks. Once back, I woke up at 6:00 am to catch up on essays. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience, and I'm so lucky. After university, I want to pursue acting as a career. I'm not from an acting family, though my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't received offers yet. I don't know how I managed everything, as I had a full social life too. When filming ended, I hardly knew what to do. I've since been in two college plays. Unfortunately, I haven't been home much, and now that my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends."'

Text: 'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, my main goal was to earn enough to support my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is an international company growing quickly worldwide. Over the years, I have learned a lot, and much of this knowledge is in this book. I believe our company has valuable insights on running a successful business while staying true to our beliefs. This isn't a typical business book, nor is it just about my life. The key message is that to succeed in business, you need to be different. Business can be enjoyable, it can be run with love, and it can have a positive impact. In business, as in life, I need to have fun, feel a sense of family, and be excited by the unexpected. I have always wanted the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares these ideas with the world, making them public. I like to think there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can achieve. I find that thought exciting, and I hope you do, too.'

Text: 'A JOURNEY ALONG THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER VOYAGES JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' experience on the Douro River in Portugal. The MV Lady Ivy May accommodates 160 guests in double cabins, each with an outside view, private shower, and WC. The ship is air-conditioned and features a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library. Itinerary Day 1 Depart from London Heathrow to Oporto in the early evening. Upon arrival, your guide will take you to the Lady Ivy May for an overnight stay. Day 2 Enjoy a morning tour of Oporto, then return to the ship to sail to Entre-os-Rios, a four-hour journey. Day 3 Continue upriver, stopping in the early evening at Peso da Regua, known for port wine. Dinner will feature local food and drink. Day 4 After breakfast, travel by bus to Lamego to visit the cathedral, several churches, and a museum, which was once a palace and now houses paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. Return to the ship and sail to Tua. Day 5 The Douro narrows here. Depending on the river's depth, you might continue by smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. The return to Tua is by coach, with many sights along the way. Day 6 In the morning, drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for stunning views of the Douro valley. Return to the ship for lunch, then take the Douro valley railway to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May awaits. Day 7 Visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch, then sail back to Oporto. Overnight on the Lady Ivy May. Day 8 Arrive in Oporto with time for independent sightseeing and shopping before your flight back to London Heathrow.'

HONEY

Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees, containing water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and flavor of honey depend on the type of flower the bees visit. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Generally, lighter-colored honey has a milder flavor than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweetener because sugar was very rare. It was highly valued by the ancient Egyptians, who even used it as a form of payment. Today, honey is produced and consumed worldwide. Research suggests that honey can help prevent tiredness and improve athletic performance. Besides being a food, honey is also used for sore throats and in many skin and hair-care products.

Norwich, the capital of East Anglia in Britain, has been inhabited for over two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By the time of the Norman invasion in 1066, it had grown into one of England's largest towns. Norwich is known for its religious diversity, with two cathedrals and a mosque. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated the 800th anniversary of receiving a Royal Charter, which allowed it to be called a city and govern itself independently.

Today, Norwich is relatively small compared to cities like London or Manchester, with a population of about 150,000. However, in the 16th century, it was England's second city. It continued to grow and became wealthy, known for having as many churches as weeks in the year and as many pubs as days in the year. Although there are fewer churches and pubs now, the University of East Anglia was established in Norwich in 1964. With a growing student population and success as a commercial center, Norwich offers a variety of entertainment options, including theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts and leisure centers. The city also has a football team called 'The Canaries,' known for their green and yellow colors, though the origin of the name is unclear.

A modern shopping center, 'The Castle Mall,' is one of the city's attractions. For over two years, residents lived with a large hole in the city center as builders excavated the main car park. Nearly a million tons of earth were moved to create a city center park on the Mall's roof, featuring water pools and trees. The local people are pleased that the old open market remains next to the new development. Both areas thrive, showing that Norwich successfully blends the old with the new.

The Albuquerque Balloon Festival

Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a desert city in the southwestern United States, fills with bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day annual event. The first festival took place in 1972 to celebrate the 50th birthday of a local radio station. It started with about a dozen hot-air balloons launching from a car park in the city center. Since then, the festival has grown significantly. This year, at least a thousand balloons from over a third of the world's countries are expected at its current location outside the city.

What to See

The pilots communicate via radio and light up their balloons' burners simultaneously. These events, called 'balloon glows,' are perfect for taking stunning photos. To see these 'glows,' you must arrive just after nightfall or before 5:30 am as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk among the balloons and talk to the pilots as they prepare for take-off. The balloons come in various sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, consider taking a balloon flight over the desert with one of the many companies offering rides. Alternatively, you can take the cable car from the desert floor to the top of the nearby mountains, the longest such ride in the world, for a bird's-eye view of the festival. There are many other attractions for all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the opening night and the last three nights of the festival.

The Albuquerque Box

This is a local wind pattern that creates ideal conditions for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains shield the balloons from strong winds and create gentler wind currents at different heights. This allows skilled pilots to control their balloons' direction by ascending or descending.

Practical Advice

Buy your tickets in advance online to avoid long waits at the festival entrance. Wear several layers of thin clothing. It can be quite cool at night and in the early morning, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are essential. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, your camera. If you're not using a digital camera, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night photos.

Text: 'The Eden Project Since it opened, the Eden Project in the south-west of England has become one of the UK's most popular tourist attractions. At first glance, the large 'biospheres' on this former industrial site resemble a scene from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate zone, showing visitors the crucial relationship between people and plants. It is fascinating to see how many products we use daily come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. Over 135,000 different types of plants are grown here. No matter how cold the weather is outside, computer-controlled electric heaters maintain the right temperature for the plants. In the Rainforest Zone, the atmosphere is always humid because of a large waterfall. Another zone replicates the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa, and there are plans to create a desert zone soon.'

Text: 'No Title Some people have criticized this year's collection, New Writing 3, but I don't understand why. Isn't 500 pages of original writing of this quality, for £6.99, quite impressive? Most of the book is fiction, including parts of novels and complete short stories. There are enjoyable pieces by well-known writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. Interestingly, the lesser-known authors seem to focus mainly on food. A word of caution about Jane Harris's Those Nails - it's best not to read it right after eating, as it has some very disturbing scenes! The collection also features excellent work from nineteen poets, including R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are excerpts from novels-in-progress by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a bit of non-fiction, featuring a humorous article by Alan Rusbridger about certain newspapers, and an extraordinary piece by Ursula Owen about herself. This is an outstanding collection, and I am eager to see what next year's selection will offer.'

Text: "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when you are discovering the world." Margaret, who lives in London, prefers to teach children aged three and four, but she often makes exceptions for enthusiastic five-year-olds. When she began teaching the violin in 1972, her first class was made up of her children's five-year-old school friends. Margaret's students have group lessons, with about twelve pupils in each group, and each lesson lasts an hour, once every two weeks. Additionally, each student has one individual lesson with her every week. Parents must also attend the classes, as it is important for them to be actively involved in the lessons. From the very first lessons, students learn to play by ear. They do not attempt to read music until they have been playing for several years, and for a long time, there is a noticeable difference between their playing and their music reading skills. Margaret explains that her method is not intended to produce great violinists, and she often advises students who excel to leave and study the violin using more traditional methods.

Text: 'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' follows their previous album 'The Waves'. There have been some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now on bass guitar, replacing Simon McVee who left the band last year, and Tom Simpson has joined as the drummer. From the first song, which is a dance tune, it's clear the band is moving away from slow songs. The second track is also a dance tune and is even louder and heavier. Most of the later tracks are in the band's usual slow style. These two tracks will surprise many fans, but they could easily become hit singles because they are excellent. Singer Rob Letchford shows his talent by hitting each note perfectly. Fans should be thankful he recorded the songs before he had throat problems, which led to the band canceling their next tour. (Anyone who bought tickets need not worry as all the concerts will be rescheduled once Rob recovers.) On this CD, Moonshine demonstrates they can create perfect music in various styles, from the slow ones we know to those that will keep you dancing. However, I felt they put their best songs at the beginning, and the last few tracks were not quite as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' is sure to be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

San Francisco San Francisco is located on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to discover the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola, who first saw it in 1769. Interestingly, although San Francisco Bay is an excellent natural harbor, it was discovered from land rather than by sea. In 1849, thousands of people came to San Francisco hoping to find gold. However, it was not the gold seekers who became wealthy. The richest people made their money by owning banks and law firms, and they built large houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the former prison.

Text: 'SAMUEL PEPYS The most famous diary in English was written by Samuel Pepys. It provides a detailed and engaging account of everyday life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about significant events of the time, such as disease outbreaks, an enemy navy sailing up the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, including his flaws—he often slept during church or admired the pretty girls. He describes his home life, like arguments with his wife and how they reconciled, and his concern about her illness. Besides books, he enjoyed music, the theatre, card games, and lively parties with good food. Pepys was a busy man with many important roles—he was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also remembered for his contributions to the British Navy.'

Text: 'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not designed for comfort or style. Early shoes were likely made from animal skins, which people wrapped around their ankles in cold weather. Today, we still use leather, but materials like silk, plastic, and cotton are also popular, depending on fashion trends. It was only 150 years ago that people started wearing different shoes on each foot. Before that, shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be handmade, but now, although some shoemakers still use traditional methods, most shoes are produced by machines in large factories. The invention of sewing machines allowed the shoe industry to make large quantities of cheaper shoes for more people.'

Text: 'No Title When I hurt my back, I had to pause my running career. I wanted to help more women discover the joy of running and build their confidence to start. So, I started a women's running club in my area. I was frustrated with race organizers who complained about the lack of women in the sport but didn't provide separate changing rooms. I put up posters, and 40 women joined, ranging from young to old, fit to unfit. They were interested in losing weight, but many hadn't considered running before. If they did, they imagined it as painful training. They didn't think about enjoying a run while chatting and smiling in beautiful places, like by a river. Initially, they could only run for a minute, but now they can run for thirty minutes. They've also learned about diet and fitness from other runners. I wanted to support women's running, and it's been a joy to see their progress—almost as much as they've enjoyed it themselves.'

**THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH**

In the 1880s, gold was found in Alaska, the northernmost state of the USA. Many people moved there, hoping to become rich. New towns were quickly established, including one called Iditarod, meaning 'far, distant place'. By 1909, Iditarod had grown so fast that it briefly became Alaska's largest city. During summer, essential supplies could reach these towns by boat, but in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, blocking access. So, in 1910, a winter trail was created for dog sled teams to deliver mail, food, and clothes to gold miners. This route became known as the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to cross Alaska, stopping at 'roadhouses' for rest and food for both drivers and dogs. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when airplanes replaced steam boats and dog teams as the main transport method.

However, in 1925, dog teams had one last moment of fame when a diphtheria outbreak struck Nome. The disease could be treated, but the nearest medicine was in Anchorage, across Alaska. Airplanes were still new, and it was uncertain if they could fly in such cold conditions. Also, Carl Eielson, the only pilot skilled enough for the flight, was away. So, it was decided to use dog teams to transport the medicine. The journey covered over 1,000 kilometers, mostly along the Iditarod Trail, and took twenty teams just six days. Leonhard Seppala, a Norwegian who came to Alaska for gold, traveled the first 400 kilometers, relying on his dog Togo to navigate through the blinding snow. Togo proved to be a dependable guide. The final part of the journey was completed by Gunnar Kaasen, an experienced dog team driver in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto, who at one point refused to move further, saving the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria outbreak was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Today, a dog sled race is held annually from Anchorage to Nome, retracing the route of the 1925 journey. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.

Text: 'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjärvi is in Swedish Lapland, where winter temperatures can drop to -40°C. Despite the cold, 6,000 tourists visit each year to experience one of Europe's most unique hotels. At this hotel, you can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made entirely of ice. You can even have a wedding there if you wish. The bar is also made of ice, so placing hot drinks on it is not a good idea! The bedrooms are kept at around -4°C, but guests receive special sleeping bags to stay warm. Suitable outdoor clothing is available if needed. The hotel is rebuilt every winter because it melts in the summer, using 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow.'

Text: In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football on an all-boys team in a local competition in Mozambique. "We won," she said. "At first, no one minded that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained." This story was reported in a local newspaper, and Jose Craveirinha, who supported African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and found her playing football outside the club. He quickly noticed her speed. "He talked to me about athletics. I didn't know what he meant. The only sport I knew was football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard work, and my legs really hurt." Jose visited her parents and convinced them that Maria could succeed in athletics and help lift them out of poverty. They agreed to let him take her to train. In 1991, she finally accepted an offer to train in the United States. She had refused before because she would miss her family. Her background was different from the girls she met in the US. She says, "They were good athletes, but while I worried about my parents having enough to eat, they worried about dresses and make-up. They knew little about me and even less about my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were excellent, and I learned a lot." Today, Maria still runs and lives happily in South Africa with her mother for most of the year.

Text: 'The Skywalk The Grand Canyon in the United States was formed by the Colorado River. Visitors come to the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and especially to enjoy the view. This view is even more impressive thanks to the Skywalk. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, allowing you to see the stunning canyon rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at once. It opened in 2007, and since then, thousands have visited it. Visitors must wear special shoe covers to prevent scratching the glass. Walking on the Skywalk feels like floating high in the air, like a bird.'

Text: 'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains stretch almost the entire length of North America. They begin in the northwest but are only a few hundred miles from the center in the more southern regions. Although the Rockies are smaller than the Alps, they are equally impressive. There are many roads through the Rockies, but the best way to experience them is by train. You start in Vancouver, one of Canada's most beautiful large cities. This city is uniquely positioned, with the ocean at its feet and mountains at its head, allowing residents to ski on slopes just 15 minutes by car from downtown. In the past, thirty passenger trains departed daily from Vancouver on the cross-continent railway. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the journey remains a thrilling adventure. You sleep on the train, which is enjoyable, but some of the most stunning scenery is passed during the night.'

Text: 'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago, when Chinese rulers created a large zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many early zoos, animals were trained to perform for visitors. This practice has stopped, and now zoos aim to show animals behaving naturally. Today, most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. However, not everyone agrees with the idea of zoos. Supporters argue that zoos allow us to learn about nature and see wild animals up close, which wouldn't be possible otherwise. Critics, however, believe it is wrong to keep animals in cages and say that poorly managed zoos can have dirty conditions and provide unsuitable food for the animals.'

Text: 'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different costumes, from black school uniforms like ours to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were all used to performing in competitions, so the quality of playing was impressive, especially since everyone was so young. Players from each band even created new tunes right on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to join gets in—only about half do. However, anyone eager to play attends jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning its language. There are also trips to jazz summer camps across the country—I’ve been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people are interested in jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't challenging enough for serious music students like me. I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old—you can create your own music, but you also feel part of its history, playing on stage like the great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and supportive parents. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!'

Text: 'Watering the Desert In Marrakesh, Morocco, it can rain anytime from November to March. However, rain is rare, and when it does occur, the city's water pipes struggle with sudden floods, turning streets into rivers. Despite many dry winters recently, the rain is welcomed by locals when it comes. Marrakesh's parks and gardens thrive not because of rain, but due to an underground channel system, built in the 11th century, that brings water from the mountains all year. These dry areas that get water this way are called oases. Traveling further south from Marrakesh, you reach Skoura. Here, every piece of land is divided into small squares by water channels and used for growing food. The Atlas Mountains, covered in snow during winter, provide a beautiful backdrop.'

Gareth Ellis, 13, is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. His older brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth has always wanted to be a clown. Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined a circus. "People laugh when we tell them," says Kath. "But it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since we took him to the circus when he was three." When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to look for full-time circus jobs. They both found jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to become a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus during the summer and return home for the winter. Gareth's brothers are old enough to take care of the house while they are away. "I can't say it was easy," says Kath. "There was a lot to think about and organize. We only had a car and a very small caravan to sleep in, and we were leaving behind our lovely house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths." "People ask about my education," says Gareth, "but from the beginning, wherever we go, someone has always come to teach me. I follow the same books as everyone back at school, and I've got a computer. I've never fallen behind my classmates." And the future? "It was a difficult decision," says Kath, "but there was no other way to teach Gareth about being a clown. I'm happy to say it's working, and we're enjoying it." And Gareth? "I'm going to be the main clown in a circus one day," he says, "perhaps Bippo's circus."

Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news agency for young people aged 8-18. We gather news and write reports, stories, and articles. These are sent to major national and local newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites for publication. Accepted stories can be read or listened to on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three centers nationwide where young people can meet and join projects, and we plan to open more. Since starting in 1994 as 'Young News', over 2,500 young people have joined. Sophie, a former member, says: 'I learned about Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me for an article on young people's views on hip hop. I was impressed by the opportunities given to young journalists. Age didn't matter; they were trusted to handle stories independently. I joined the Eight-eighteen center in my city, received training, and stayed until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me achieve more than I imagined. With the skills I gained, I got a job at 19 and am now the youngest employee at a major news website, reviewing articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you'll receive training and attend monthly meetings to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen promotes skill-sharing among members. 'Peer trainers' are experienced members aged 12 and over who train new members in basic journalism skills. As they gain experience, some present sessions to young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. These young trainers are supported by older staff on these trips. Eight-eighteen News holds training sessions for new members three times a year. Our next training is in February. If you or someone you know is interested in joining, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen program is suitable for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free, and there is no test to join.

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**

Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, Antarctica Sightseeing Flights offers tours in a full-size passenger plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica, and back. Flight dates for next year are not confirmed yet, but if you book now, your deposit can be transferred if we need to change the date.

**Frequently Asked Questions**

**How long is the flight?**

The flight lasts about 12 hours. After around four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours flying over Antarctica and the rest of the time returning. During the flight, experts who have lived at research stations in Antarctica give talks on the environment and history and answer questions. A camera near the pilot, connected to the onboard video system, provides a pilot's view from take-off to landing.

**Will I get a seat next to a window?**

All passengers receive two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, passengers switch to the seat on their second pass. Business and first-class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window or next-to-window seat for half the flight and an aisle seat for the other half. Over Antarctica, passengers are encouraged to move around the plane to share the views. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' over points of interest so both sides of the plane can see well.

**What happens if the weather is bad?**

We have 17 approved flight plans. On the morning of the flight, the captain checks the satellite cloud images and chooses the route with the clearest views.

**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**

Most Antarctic wildlife lives at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them in detail. We do not land in Antarctica, mainly for environmental reasons. To see Antarctic wildlife, you would need to join a boat tour.

**Can I take photographs?**

Absolutely! All cameras are welcome. We also offer some fun onboard photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

Text: 'Little Chefs For a group of children aged ten to fifteen, Saturdays are for learning serious cooking. These weekly lessons in small classes are so popular that there is a waiting list of 30 children. Parents pay £280 for the course where their children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, aged ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking and now I can do it better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we sit down with them to share the food we've made.' Flora, who is twelve, is having trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they really enjoyed it. Then my mum suggested I take up a hobby instead of doing nothing at weekends. I was happy staying at home, so I wasn't too keen at first. I'm really glad I decided to come, though.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, although the kitchen isn't always tidy when they're cooking! As adults, we're always learning more about food. If parents interest their children in cooking while they are young, they'll have enough skill to make food for themselves when they leave home.''

Text: 'Winter Driving Winter driving is dangerous because it's hard to predict what will happen, and accidents can occur easily. Fog might appear suddenly as you go over a hill. Ice can be hidden under melting snow, ready to make you lose control. A car coming towards you might unexpectedly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make a car hard to control. So, whenever you turn the wheel, use the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee on the seat next to you. Drive in a way that you wouldn't spill it. Rule Number Two is to be aware of what might happen. The more ice there is, the further ahead you need to look. Test how long it takes to stop by gently braking. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Generally, allow double your normal stopping distance on wet roads, triple on snow, and even more on ice. Try to keep control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

Craigie Aitchison

The painter Craigie Aitchison was born in Scotland. He moved to London with plans to study law but chose to attend art school instead. He found traditional drawing classes challenging but continued to paint. In his late twenties, he received a grant from the Italian government to study art, which sparked his interest in early Italian artists. This influence is visible in some of his work. Aitchison admired the greens and browns of the Italian countryside and the clear light there, which he wanted to capture in his paintings. To achieve this, he painted colors in thin layers from light to dark, though he admits he never knows exactly how the final piece will look. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Like many talented people, Aitchison makes it sound simple. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' Unlike some artists, he never makes sketches before starting a painting, as he believes that if he did, he might lose interest and not complete the painting. Instead, Aitchison often changes his paintings many times before they are finished. This is why he prefers models who don't ask to see their portraits while he's working. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since moving to London, he has not felt connected to the Scottish painting scene. He says he is not interested in following any tradition but just paints in his own way. However, his work still influences young British painters.

Text: 'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a drum set for his birthday. At first, we were against the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben argued, 'and it'll keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbors when you play.' That was just the start. Since drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band began coming to our home with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house shakes with the sound of their instruments and their teenage singing. At least Ben's hobby has been good for our health: whenever the band starts practicing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must admit that, although their music may sound a bit strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot judge their musical skill - after all, I didn't expect my parents' generation to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play regularly in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their schoolwork because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

Atlantic College

Last week, I visited Atlantic College, a top private school in Wales. This college is unique because it offers students valuable life experiences outside the classroom, along with their academic studies. The students, aged 16 to 18, come from all over the world. They spend their mornings studying and their afternoons doing meaningful activities, like helping on a farm, assisting people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution.

One of the remarkable aspects of Atlantic College is its diverse student body, with students from various social backgrounds and countries. Since the fees are PS20,000 for two years, many students rely on grants. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them attend thanks to government support.

"I really admire the college for promoting international understanding among young people," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with and respect others, even those you don't get along with. During the summer holidays, my mother noticed I argued much less with my sister."

In conclusion, Atlantic College provides its students with an excellent education through effective methods.

Text: 'Being an Older Student At 32, I have just completed my first year at university. Besides attending lectures regularly, I have had to learn to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. As a secretary, even though I was earning a decent salary, I was bored with a job that required little thought. I felt increasingly trapped in the job and envied the students at the local university. They seemed happy, carefree, and hopeful, and I wanted to be part of that. However, now that I am a student, I find it difficult to connect with younger classmates. They often mistake me for a lecturer and ask questions I can't answer. I also feel distant from the lecturers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. Still, I am grateful for this chance to study because I know a qualification is necessary for a fulfilling job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I prefer spending weekends with my books rather than going out partying. There are also typical student perks like long holidays and discounts at theatres and cinemas. I often wonder what I will do after university, but I hope that continuing my education at this stage has been a wise decision.'

Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he didn't enjoy farming. At fifteen, he started working as a mechanic, and in 1893, he built his first car. After driving it for 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two larger cars. In 1903, he founded the Ford Motor Company. By using strong yet light steel, he created affordable cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he introduced the first Ford Model 'T', priced at $825. Soon, he was selling 100 cars daily. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was valued at $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and inexpensive, but this simplicity sometimes meant limited options. Henry Ford famously said about the Model T, "You can have any color you like, as long as it's black."

Text: 'Dear Sir, I saw your advertisement for English courses in the newspaper. I would like more information. How much does a course cost? Also, how long is each course and when does the next course start? Yours, Maria Gonzalez Dear Ms. Gonzalez, Thank you for your letter. Our next course begins in three weeks, on Monday, 9 May. This course lasts 6 weeks and costs £150. If you prefer to start in June, we offer another 10-week course for £200. I hope this answers your questions. Yours, David May '

Text: 'REBECCA STEVENS Rebecca Stevens was the first woman to climb Mount Everest. Before her climb, she worked as a journalist and lived in a small flat in south London. In 1993, Rebecca left her job and family to travel to Asia with other climbers. She discovered that life on Everest is tough. 'You have to carry everything on your back,' she said, 'so you can only bring what you really need. You can't wash on the mountain, and eventually, I didn't even bring a toothbrush. I'm usually a clean person, but there's no water, only snow. Water is very heavy, so you only take enough to drink!' When Rebecca reached the top of Mount Everest on May 17, 1993, it was the best moment of her life. She suddenly became famous. Now, she has written a book about the climb, and people often invite her to speak about it. She also has a new job on a science TV programme. Rebecca is well-known today and has more money, but she still lives in her small flat in south London, surrounded by her pictures and books about mountains!'

Dear Mike,

I'm sorry you couldn't come to my party yesterday. Jon told me you had a bad cold and decided to stay in bed. Are you feeling better now? It was a great party; the best I've ever had! Many of my friends were there, and they gave me some wonderful presents. I'll tell you more about it when you come to school on Monday.

Love,  
Lorenzo

Text: 'CANADA GEESE Canada Geese are large birds with blue and white feathers. When autumn comes, they need to fly south to warmer places. The winters in Canada are so cold that the birds would die if they stayed. Last spring, Bill Lishman discovered sixteen young Canada Geese on his farm. They had lost their parents. Bill thought, 'These young birds won't know what to do in the autumn.' Bill had a small plane and decided to teach the birds to follow him. Throughout the summer, he took short flights in his plane, and the young geese flew after him. When autumn's cold weather came, Bill flew to Virginia in the United States, 600 miles south of his home in Canada. The geese followed him all the way. Bill left the geese in Virginia and returned home. This spring, Bill was waiting for the birds to come back. They didn't arrive, so Bill flew to Virginia to find them. He searched for two weeks but couldn't locate them. When he got back home, Bill found the geese waiting for him. They had found their way home without him!'

Text: 'ESTHER'S STORY When Esther finished school at sixteen, her aunt Flory gave her £500 for her birthday. While most of her friends chose to go to college, Esther used the money from her aunt to start a business. She bought fruit, sugar, and glass jars to make her own jam. She sold each jar for £1 to her friends and quickly doubled the £500. Initially, her parents were not supportive of Esther spending her time making jam; they wanted her to study and hoped she would become a teacher or a doctor. However, Esther continued with her jam-making. After a few months, she began selling it at the local market. She then expanded to making orange juice, which she sold to a school where a friend worked. After two years, her business grew significantly, and her parents were proud of her. She produced various foods for shops and supermarkets and became so busy that she needed to hire employees.'

Text: 'Dear Jacqueline, Would you like to join me at the cinema after school today? We can watch Pocahontas at the ABC cinema. The film begins at 6 o'clock. Shall we meet outside the cinema? Love, Isabella Dear Isabella, I'm very sorry, but I can't go to the cinema this evening. My mother has work, and I need to cook dinner. Why don't you ask Karen to go with you? I hope you enjoy the film. You can tell me about it tomorrow. Love, Jacqueline '

Corryvale Farm is located in the west of England. Stephen and Jenny Blackler run the farm, where they keep cows and chickens, selling milk and eggs. However, most of their income comes from Jenny's sheep. She owns 50 sheep, and each one produces enough wool for six sweaters. Every six months, Stephen shears the sheep to prevent them from overheating. 

Five years ago, Jenny decided to make sweaters from the wool and sell them at country markets. Unfortunately, it was summer, and the hot weather meant people weren't interested in buying sweaters. So, she switched to making socks. These socks became popular because they were affordable, durable, and easy to wash. This marked the beginning of Jenny's business. Initially, she made the socks at home, but as her customer base grew to thousands, she had to send the wool to a factory, where machines now produce the socks.

Jenny's socks come in six colors, five sizes for all ages, and are designed for different activities like walking, sports, and skiing. The busiest time for Jenny is Christmas, as Corryvale socks are a popular gift. In Jenny's office, the walls are covered with letters from satisfied customers worldwide.

Text: '28 Long Road Brighton 22nd March Dear Pat, I arrived in Brighton three weeks ago. I'm studying at a language school here. The students are from many different countries, and I've made a lot of new friends. We have classes for five hours every day. I really like our teacher. His name is John, and he helps me if I make a mistake. I plan to visit London next weekend because I'm returning to my country on Monday. Can I meet you there? Please write back soon. Best wishes, Maria'

Text: 'BURGLARS PREFER THE AFTERNOON Most house burglaries occur between 2 p.m. and 6 p.m., according to the police. Inspector Ian Saunders informed our newspaper that house burglaries have increased by over 30% compared to last year. He mentioned that 67% of these burglaries happen when people leave without closing a door or window. He added that night-time burglaries are rare because families are usually home then. However, he noted that winter afternoons are ideal for burglars because it is dark, making it easier for them to go unnoticed. Additionally, many houses are empty during this time as people are often still at work. Inspector Saunders suggested leaving lights on in living rooms and bedrooms when you go on holiday to deter burglars. He also encouraged neighbors to watch over other houses on the street when people are away and to contact the police if they notice anything unusual. 'We can also advise you on how to secure your home,' Inspector Saunders said. 'This assistance is free of charge.''

Text: 'Dear Lynne and Tony, I'm writing to thank you for the two nights I spent at your lovely home. It was great to see you again. Here are the photos of your children that you requested. They're nice photos, aren't they? I hope you like them. I really enjoy using my new camera. I'm going to visit my sister in New York next week. I'll take many photos there, too. I haven't seen my sister for a long time. Thanks again. Love, Roy'

Text: 'The History of Farming Before agriculture, people foraged in forests for edible plants and fruits. This lifestyle required constant movement in search of food. However, around 12,000 years ago in the Middle East, people began cultivating crops. These early farmers were pioneers of agriculture. Farming allowed people to settle in one place, leading to the gradual expansion of their villages. As a result, some villagers could engage in other activities, such as making clothes, because farmers provided food for the community. However, farming was challenging during adverse weather conditions, leading to food shortages. Today, agricultural advancements enable farmers to produce more food, which can be transported over long distances to reach our homes.'

Text: 'WORKING FOR AN AIRLINE Nicola Peet finished school at eighteen, went to college, and then started working at a local airport. After nine months, she joined Saudi Arabian Airlines and later became an air hostess with British Airways. Four years after that, she got her current job as a manager. Here’s what she shared about her job: 'My office is at Heathrow Airport, but I spend 60% of my time flying. I train air hostesses and assist them with any issues. I also attend many meetings. My usual working hours are from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., but sometimes I work from 1 p.m. to 9 p.m. At work, the first thing I do is check flight schedules on my computer and then talk to some of the air hostesses. Occasionally, I go on long flights to see how the air hostesses are performing. That's my favorite part of the job, but I enjoy office work too. Traveling can be tiring. When I return from a long trip, all I can do is eat something and then go to bed! I don't earn a lot of money, but I'm happy with British Airways and want to stay there and keep traveling.''

Text: 'Dear Maria, It's nice to be back in my home country, but I often think about the friends I made in our English class, especially you. I cried when I left England because my stay was too short. I want to return to England, but next time I will stay in a different city. I have started English classes again here. I learned a lot in England, but I know I need to study even more. How about you? Are you still searching for a job? I hope you find one soon. Love, Sophie'

Text: 'Dear Sir, I lost my bag on a train last week. I was on the 8:30 a.m. train to Cambridge on 10th May. It is a large blue bag with my name on the outside. Have you found this bag? Yours faithfully, Mary Johnson Dear Ms. Johnson, I am happy to inform you that we have your bag here. If you come to this office, I can return it to you. The office is open from 9 a.m. to 6:30 p.m. every day. Yours sincerely, J Wilson'

Text: 'People are interested in the weather for many reasons, and it is important for various jobs. For instance, the weather greatly affects farmers. In the past, farmers would spend a lot of time observing the sky, animals, and plants to understand the weather better. Nowadays, there are many computer programs that help us learn about the weather, and people can even get weather updates on their mobile phones. Still, many people believe in traditional weather sayings. For example, they say that if there is a red sky in the evening, the next day will be sunny. Some also think that when cows lie down in the fields, it will soon rain.'

Frazer and Peter are two 14-year-old boys from a small Canadian town. They have been friends and classmates for a long time. Like their other friends, they enjoy fishing and swimming on weekends. However, for the past few months, they have spent every weekend in Peter's room working on his laptop. This isn't due to homework; they have created a new computer word game. The idea for the game came from Frazer's younger brother, Kevin, who struggles with reading. Kevin finds it easier to learn words through pictures and sounds rather than reading. To help him, Frazer and Peter collaborated for over 200 hours to develop a computer game, which is now ready to use. It is a speaking and picture game. For instance, when you see the word 'hat', there is a drawing of a hat next to it, and you can hear Peter saying 'Hat! Hat!' simultaneously. The boys have won several prizes for their game, and it will soon be available worldwide. Many schools are interested in purchasing it.

Text: 'HOW DO THE IRISH POP-GROUP 'BOYZONE' LIVE A HEALTHY LIFE? Sleeping well is very important. When I visit my mother's house, I sleep for ten hours. However, after a concert, it's hard to sleep because my mind is full of music. Sport is important too. Before my car accident, I spent two and a half hours a day, five days a week, at the sports centre. Now, I can't do that, so I do about 150 sit-ups a day. I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water because it's healthy. I should drink about eight glasses a day, but I don't always manage that. People shouldn't work all the time. I love my job, but I also enjoy other activities. In my free time, I listen to music or watch TV. It's good to relax sometimes. I don't feel tired anymore since the doctor advised me to eat better. Now, I eat lots of vegetables like carrots and spinach every day. But I still enjoy burgers sometimes!'

Bollywood, the film industry in Mumbai, India, produces nearly 1,000 films annually. Since its first film in 1913, Bollywood has created over 29,000 films, making it the largest film industry in the world, surpassing the USA. Watching films is the most popular leisure activity in India, with ten million people visiting cinemas daily. Bollywood films often feature romantic love stories, with singing and dancing as key elements. These films are also popular outside India, earning Bollywood over $500 million last year from international sales. Indian actors make more films each year than their Hollywood counterparts, but they earn less. Consequently, most Bollywood films have a production cost of about $2 million, whereas Hollywood films typically cost at least $5 million. Most Bollywood actors are young and work intensely for a few years. However, Amitabh Bachchan, considered by some as India's greatest actor, is an exception. He has starred in over 140 films during a career spanning nearly 40 years.

Text: 'Bill Bryson I was born in the United States, but I have written several travel books about England. I lived there with my wife and four children for 20 years. For the last three years, we have been living in the United States. Our children are now learning about life in the U.S. I believe they will be happier because they have experienced life in two countries. I like Britain and want to return, but my daughter, Felicity, will start college here soon, so it won't be for another four years. I recently spent six weeks in England to work on a radio programme about the English language and to discuss the book I've just written. Most writers don't enjoy this; they don't like travelling around the country to promote their book. I don't mind it. I enjoy visiting new places and meeting many people. It's very different from my life in the United States when I'm writing. In England, people drove me around in big cars, and I stayed in expensive hotels. It was nice because I didn't have to pay any bills. Everyone was kind to me, and it was fun.'

Text: 'Schnauzer Dogs There are three sizes of Schnauzer dogs. The two smaller sizes arrived in England over 50 years ago, but the Giant Schnauzer is a more recent arrival. The name "Giant" fits well because these dogs are 65 to 67.5 cm tall. All Schnauzers have long hair that needs regular trimming. Most smaller Schnauzers are grey, while the Giant Schnauzer is usually black. Schnauzers originate from Germany, where farmers use them to help with sheep, and they are also employed by the police due to their intelligence. A Schnauzer is a good family dog, as it is friendly and very good with young children.'

Text: 'The Ruwenzori Mountains Mary Daniels is a student in England. This year, she had a very interesting summer holiday. She traveled with fifteen other people to the Ruwenzori Mountains in Africa. They went there to help build a road through a forest between two large towns. 'It was very challenging because there was no water to drink and no shops where we could buy food,' said Mary. 'It was also very cold and wet in the mountains. It is one of the wettest places in the world.' Mary stayed in the mountains for six weeks. It was hard work, but she says it was the best thing she has ever done. She hopes to return next year to do more work there.'

Text: 'Dear Keira, Thank you for your letter. Today was my first day at my new school. A girl named Nicole helped me and showed me where the classrooms are. She is very nice, and I plan to visit her this weekend. My favorite lesson today was Maths, and I was pleased because I knew more than the other girls. I also played hockey for the first time and really enjoyed it. Most of the teachers seem friendly, but I'm a bit scared of the head teacher. No one likes him because he often shouts. I must go now because I have homework to do. Hester'

Text: 'New Books This Month The Long Night This is David Reilly's first book. David became a writer after teaching English for several years. Maha is a nurse in northern Australia, working in a small hospital. One day, a baby is very ill, and Maha must drive all night to the nearest big city. They face many challenges on the way and ... Hard Work This exciting story is Joanna Jones's twentieth book. Hard Work is about Sombat, who works with his father, a carpenter, in Thailand. They work long hours making tables and chairs, but they have no money. Then one day, a man dressed in black buys the most beautiful table in the shop ... Hospital or Cinema? Marcie Jacome, who studies English in London, wrote this story earlier this year. Tina is a young Brazilian woman who dreams of becoming a doctor. She goes to London to study English and medicine, but one day she meets a man who invites her to the USA to become a film star ... What will Tina do?'

Text: 'The history of horse racing Horse racing has been an important sport since ancient times. It began in Central Asia around 4,500 years ago and was popular in Greek and Roman times. Modern horse racing started when Arab horses came to Europe in the 12th century. Initially, races were long and involved only two horses. However, in the early 18th century, races became shorter and included several horses competing together. Today, horse racing is watched by more people than any other sport in the USA, except for baseball. It is also very popular worldwide.'

Text: Nick Barlow is a British actor who loves his job. He travels worldwide to make TV programmes. "People welcome me everywhere, and when I return home, I remember all the wonderful experiences from each country," he says. Nick has visited many places, but he still wants to travel to South America and return to Australia someday. On his trips, Nick is accompanied by a team who bring cameras and other filming equipment. He doesn't pack much for himself, just a few shirts and trousers, but he always includes some books in his suitcase. Nick's wife, Helen, doesn't mind his travels for work. She has many friends and stays busy. When he returns, she enjoys hearing all his travel stories. However, there are sometimes challenges. While in the Malaysian rainforest, Nick learned that Helen was ill in the hospital. "I felt terrible because I couldn't help, but she didn't want me to come home. I was so relieved when I heard she was better," he recalls.

Parrots You might have seen these stunning birds, with their vibrant colors and long tails, either in the wild or at the zoo. Parrots are native to countries such as Brazil, Australia, and India. They typically live in large flocks and, due to their fondness for fruit, can sometimes pose challenges for farmers. There are numerous species of parrots, but they all share strong beaks and feet, which they use for climbing and grasping food. The largest parrots can live up to 80 years. Although they are quite noisy, they are intelligent birds and can be easily taught to mimic human speech. Some zoos feature parrot shows, where you can watch these birds perform learned behaviors.

Text: 'HOWARD BONNIER Bray is a charming village about fifty kilometres west of London. A young Englishman named Howard Bonnier opened a restaurant called The Palace there about three and a half months ago. Not many people in Britain know Mr Bonnier's name yet, but he is already quite famous in France. This is because he has written for French magazines about almost all the best restaurants in that country. He is only 29 years old. When Howard was a teenager, he often went to restaurants with his parents. He enjoyed this so much that he decided not to spend money on clothes and CDs; instead, he used his money to visit France and dine in good restaurants. He also bought many French and English cookbooks - he says he has more than two hundred and fifty! So why did he decide to open a restaurant? Simply because he loves cooking. Has it been easy? He says it's expensive to start your own restaurant and much more difficult to cook for fifty people than for your family, but he is sure he has done the right thing.'

Text: In a park in a small town in central England, John Pickering takes care of the grass and flowers. However, last week he was in Tokyo, where millions of Japanese people watched him on television. John, a thirty-five-year-old gardener, is currently the top singer in Japan. He visited Japan a few months ago to perform in dance clubs in Osaka and Nagoya. A disc jockey heard his songs and played them on the radio. Many young people called the radio station, asking to hear the songs again. In Japan, John uses the stage name Jon Otis. Despite his success, he plans to continue working in the park in England because he is unsure how much money he will make from his music. "I must keep my job in the park," he says. "I still have to pay my bills!" The other gardeners are unaware of his fame in Japan and have never heard him sing. John's wife, Denise, who works in a hospital, says, "This will not change the way we live. I only know John Pickering, not Jon Otis!"

Text: 'Memo To: All staff Subject: Holidays From: D Brown Date: 22.2.02 I am organizing the holiday schedule for next year. Please let me know your preferred holiday dates. If possible, provide two options. Kindly respond by the end of the month. Thank you. D Brown Memo To: D Brown Subject: Holidays From: J Green Date: 23.2.02 May I take a two-week holiday in July? I prefer the first two weeks, but if that's not possible, the last two weeks are fine. Additionally, can I have three extra days off in the first week of December? John'

Text: 'Line dancing Thousands of people in Britain have taken up a new hobby: line dancing. In nearly every town, there are clubs and classes for this activity. 'Line dancing is simple to learn. If you can walk, you can do it!' says Fiona Lever, a teacher. 'You don't need a partner because you dance in groups. It's a great way to meet new people. In my classes, there are both young and old participants. The boys enjoy it because they can make a lot of noise with their feet during the dances!' When did line dancing start? Most people believe it began about fifteen years ago when American country music became popular in Britain.'

Text: 'The Rhino There are five types of rhinos in the world today. The Black and White Rhinos live in the open fields of Africa, while the others live in forests in Asia. All rhinos have large, heavy bodies. Their skin is very tough and they have very little hair. A rhino's large body stands on four short legs, and each foot has three toes. They usually walk slowly, but they can run at speeds of up to 50 kilometers per hour. Rhinos are generally quiet and calm animals, and they eat only grass and other plants. A baby rhino weighs 40 kilos at birth, after being inside its mother for about fifteen months. An adult rhino weighs over 200 kilos and can live up to 50 years.'

Text: 'THE HISTORY OF THE LONDON POLICE Today, policemen are everywhere, but in 1700, London had none. A few elderly men guarded the streets at night, earning little money. Around 300 years ago, London began to grow. The city was dirty, and many people were poor. There were so many thieves stealing money in the streets that people preferred to stay at home. In 1750, Henry Fielding started paying a group to catch thieves. They were like policemen and were called 'Bow Street Runners' because they worked near Bow Street. Fifty years later, there were 120 Bow Street Runners, but London had grown much larger and needed more police. So, in 1829, the first Metropolitan (or London) Police Force was established with 3000 officers. Most worked on foot, but some rode horses. Until 1920, all London police were men. Today, London police are well paid, and those who still ride horses earn even more.'

Text: 'TO ALL STUDENTS: Are you interested in joining a camping trip this weekend? We will travel to the forest by school bus and stay at a campsite from Friday to Sunday. The campsite offers hot showers, a small shop, and bicycle rentals. The trip costs £25. Nights are very cold, so bring warm clothes and sturdy shoes. If you want to join, let me know today. Ahmed, Student Secretary'

Text: 'Visit the Edinburgh Festival! Every year, thousands of people visit Edinburgh, the capital of Scotland, to experience the Edinburgh Festival. For three weeks in August and September, the city is filled with actors and artists from around the world. They come for the largest arts festival in Britain. During this time, the streets are vibrant with music and dance from early morning until late at night. You can even watch artists painting on the streets. One of the highlights of the Festival is the 'Fringe', where students perform comedy shows in small venues like halls and cafes. Tens of thousands of tourists attend the Festival to see new films and plays and listen to music by famous musicians. This year, there are over five hundred performances featuring actors from more than forty countries. Tickets for these performances are quite affordable, and it's often easier to see your favorite star in Edinburgh than in London. So, plan to visit Edinburgh next summer, but remember that finding accommodation can be challenging, so consider booking your hotel now!'

ICE-FISHING

If you drive north from Toronto for three hours, you will reach Lake Nipissing. In winter, the lake freezes, and thousands of Canadian fishermen visit each weekend. They build small wooden houses on the ice and paint them in bright colors. Inside these houses, they fish for the fish swimming under the ice.

Bob Marvisch has been coming here at this time of year for twenty-five years. "You need clothes that are light but warm: two pairs of socks and gloves, several thin sweaters, and a snow suit on top. Catching the fish is easy," he says. "First, you break the ice and make a small round hole in it. Next, you take a fishing line and put some bread on it. Then, you put the line through the hole and into the water. You pull the line up when the fish eat the bread. They are between ten and twenty centimeters long. Some people like to eat them, but when I have caught three or four fish, I prefer to have some chocolate or another snack! Today I have caught twenty-five! It's a great sport, and you can meet some nice people here!"

From: Greg  
To: Anna  

Hi Anna,

I'm not having a great week! Yesterday, my team played a volleyball match, but we lost. The other team was much better than us. Then, my friend Jeff, who lives in Australia, called with bad news. He can't visit us during the holidays because he has a summer job. So, we can't go camping together now. This morning, my sister woke up late and took my bike to school without telling me. I'm really upset with her. I hope you have some good news! Please write back today if you can.

Greg

Text: 'Madame Tussaud's A very famous tourist attraction in London is Madame Tussaud's museum. Visitors can see wax figures of well-known people there. Madame Tussaud was born in France in 1761. Her uncle, who was a doctor, created wax figures of people and opened a museum for them in Paris. Marie assisted him with his work. In 1789, during the French Revolution, Marie was imprisoned. While in prison, she had to make wax copies of the heads of famous deceased people, including Queen Marie Antoinette. In 1795, Marie married Francois Tussaud, and in 1802 she moved to London with her wax figures. She opened a museum there, and her figures are still on display today.'

Text: 'BICYCLES Bicycles are an affordable and environmentally friendly way to travel. The first bicycle was created around 150 years ago. Initially, bicycles were costly, so only wealthy individuals could afford them. These early bicycles looked quite different from the ones we see today. As bicycles became more affordable, many people started buying them. People began using bicycles for commuting and leisure. Nowadays, cars are used more often than bicycles because they are faster and keep you dry in the rain. However, some people still prefer cycling to work. They argue that there are too many cars in city centers, making parking difficult.'

Text: 'The Elephant Show by Daniel Allsop, age 14 Last summer, I visited Thailand for a beach holiday with my family. One day, we went to a park near our hotel. It had lovely flower gardens, but we were mainly interested in the elephant show. We went to a large square with seats on three sides. Three elephants entered with their keepers and stood in front of big white cards. Each elephant received a paintbrush and began painting on its card. Occasionally, the keepers gave them new brushes with fresh paint and took the old ones away. Gradually, following their keepers' guidance, the elephants created pictures on the cards. I was amazed! One picture showed a river, another a tree, and the third a bunch of flowers. When the keepers displayed the paintings, everyone wanted to buy one. We gave the elephants the bananas we had brought for our lunch. Twenty years ago, elephants worked in the forest. Now, they no longer work there, but the smartest of these animals live in special centers where visitors can watch them.'

Text: 'Big Cats There are many different types of big cats, each varying in size, appearance, and behavior. Tigers are the largest of the big cats, reaching up to 3.7 meters in length from head to tail. Unlike most cats, tigers enjoy water and often cool off in pools when it's hot. Lions are unique among big cats because they live in large family groups called prides. In these groups, several lions may work together to hunt for food. Lions typically inhabit flat, open areas where they have a clear view to track other animals. All big cats require excellent eyesight to hunt smaller animals for food. They also need to be fast and very strong.'

Text: 'Dear Mrs. Brian, I regret to inform you that I can no longer attend your class as I need to return to my home country. My sister is getting married next month, and I want to help her choose a dress. My parents are preparing a large meal for the guests, which will involve a lot of work in the kitchen. I am sorry to leave the English class. You are an excellent teacher. Please convey my goodbyes to the other students. Thank you once again. Best wishes, Soraya'

Text: '14 Sheffield Road Rotherham 20th May 2002 Dear Mary, I will be in London next Thursday morning. Would you like to have lunch with me? Please let me know when you are free and where I can meet you. Hope to see you then. Yours, Joan 20 Didsbury Drive London NW1 22 May 2002 Dear Joan, Thank you for your letter. I received it this morning. Yes, I'd love to see you. How about meeting outside my office at one o'clock? There's a good Italian restaurant nearby. Do you like Italian food? I need to be back at work by two o'clock, so please don't be late! Yours, Mary '

Text: 'Dear Lorna, How are you? I'm happy because I got a new job in the city centre last month. I work in a Tourist Information Office, and it's very interesting. I start work every morning at 7:30, so I have to get up very early! I love this job because I meet people from many different countries. I enjoy telling them about our city. Here is a photo of me in my new uniform. Do you like it? Love, Gloria'

Text: 'THE OSTRICH The ostrich is the largest bird in the world, with adults weighing over 90 kilos. Most wild ostriches are found in southern Africa, but their numbers are low. Although ostriches have wings like all birds, they cannot fly. Instead, they use their wings to help them change direction while running. Ostriches are very fast runners, reaching speeds of 65 to 90 kilometers per hour, making it hard for predators to catch them. Baby ostriches are about the size of chickens and take around 3 years to mature into adults. They eat plants and can survive for many days without water.'

Victoria Jamieson, a British snowboarder, began snowboarding at the age of 20. Now 23, she has won numerous competitions in the sport. We interviewed her last week during a snowboarding competition in Switzerland and asked why she took up snowboarding. She said, "I've always enjoyed various sports, especially skiing, so snowboarding felt like a natural progression. It's quick to learn, and you can become quite skilled in just a few months." 

When asked about her practice routine, she explained, "In winter, I snowboard in the mountains daily from 8:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. I also run and bike. I love all of it! I enjoy the competitions and being in the mountains because it's so beautiful. But free-riding, which is snowboarding outside of competitions, is my favorite thing in the world."

We also inquired about what is important when learning to snowboard. She advised, "You can learn quickly, but lessons are necessary. It's also crucial to have the right clothing to stay dry, as beginners spend a lot of time falling!"

Text: '23 Oak Avenue Manchester Dear Sir or Madam, I would like to book a room at your hotel for three nights, from September 15th to 17th. I prefer a single room with a shower and a telephone. Could you please provide a quiet room on the ground floor? I will be driving to the hotel. Is there a car park available? I expect to arrive around 10:30 p.m. Could you tell me what time the restaurant closes in the evening? If possible, I would like to have a meal upon my arrival. Thank you for your assistance. Yours faithfully, Mark Jones'

Mount Kilimanjaro is the tallest mountain in Africa. People of all ages have climbed it, from a seven-year-old boy to an 87-year-old man. There are different routes to reach the summit. The Marangu route, which is five kilometers long, is considered the easiest and takes about five days to complete. It is very popular with tourists. However, only half of the climbers manage to reach the top. This is often due to sudden weather changes. At the start, it can be hot and wet, but at the summit, there is ice and snow, and temperatures can drop below 20 degrees Celsius. Climbers need to bring both sunglasses and warm clothing.

Text: 'Otters Not many people have seen an otter. These animals live near rivers and build their homes from small pieces of wood. They are mostly active at night. Otters are excellent swimmers and can move through water at speeds over 10 kilometres per hour. They have thick brown fur that keeps them warm in the water. An otter can close its ears and nose, allowing it to stay underwater for several minutes. Twenty years ago, otters were rare in Great Britain. The rivers were polluted, causing many fish and insects to die, leaving otters with little to eat. Today, the rivers are clean again, providing plenty of food for otters.'

Text: 'Dear Deshini, I'm thrilled to have you as my new penfriend. My name is Tom, and I'm fifteen years old. I was born in Canada, but now I live in England. Please write and tell me about your life in India. I would love to visit there someday. Do you live in a small village or a big town? What is your school like? Do you have any pictures of your school you could share with me? I'm sending you a few photos of my family and will send more next time. I hope to hear from you soon. Tom'

Text: '17 Green Street Camden London 29th August 2002 Dear John, Thank you for helping me with my English. You are an excellent teacher. I enjoyed my time in Cambridge. Now, I am staying at my brother's apartment. He is studying medicine. I will stay with him for two weeks and then return home to Greece. I like London a lot. Yesterday, we took a bus to Regents Park. It was very sunny, and we had a great time. Tonight, I am going to watch a film with my brother and some of his friends. I'll write again from Greece. Best wishes, Kostas'

Text: 'Dear David, I will visit your country next month with two friends. We are unsure about where to stay. Are there any affordable hotels in your town? We prefer to stay in the city centre. Can you assist us? Carlos Dear Carlos, Hotels in the city centre are costly, but I have good news. I talked to my aunt Gloria about you, and she says you can all stay at her house. It has more bedrooms than mine! Is that okay with you? David'

Text: 'Buildings People have always constructed buildings. We need houses to keep us warm and dry, and we build stadiums to watch football matches and pop concerts. We use other buildings, like museums, to store beautiful things. Many people collaborate on a building project. The architect designs the building's appearance and creates drawings to communicate their ideas. Engineers ensure the building will be strong and safe. Then, the workers carefully construct it. The Sydney Opera House is a renowned modern building with an elegant roof. However, the building is beautiful from every angle, not just from above. The Olympic Stadium in Munich also has a famous roof. This intriguing building resembles a tent made of glass.'

Text: 'Indre, I have a problem and need your help. Can you come shopping with me tomorrow? My grandmother is turning 80 next month and is having a party on Saturday. The problem is I don't have anything to wear. I've grown so much that all my trousers are too short now! I want to buy some new ones and maybe a pair of boots. I don't have a lot of money to spend, but I think it will be enough. Would you like to meet in the morning or the afternoon? Let me know. Sarika'

Text: 'The Cerne Giant Sherborne and Dorchester are two towns in the south of England, close to each other. Between them, there are many green hills and fields. On one of these hills, there is a large figure of a man. This figure is called the Cerne Giant because it is near the village of Cerne. The exact time when the Cerne Giant was created is unknown, but it is believed to be very old. You can walk from Cerne to get closer to the figure. If you visit on the first of May at sunrise, you will see villagers dancing around the giant on the hill.'

Gail Rollins is one of the top runners in Edinburgh. This summer, she aims to compete in the 10,000 meters—and possibly the 5,000 meters—at the European Championships. In the past, Gail was famous for finishing second in major competitions. However, she always maintained a cheerful attitude, which endeared her to the people in her hometown. Everything changed in 2004 when she participated in her first half-marathon, a long road race. She won with an impressive time, the fastest of the year for any British woman. Gail's manager and husband, Mike Rollins, was also a runner in his youth but had to stop competing due to an injury to his right leg. He can still run a bit and sometimes trains with Gail, although it's challenging for him when she overtakes him. Gail trains diligently, doing a long run in the morning and fast runs in the afternoon, but she always takes Sundays off from running. "I am with her all the time," says Mike. "Sometimes I ask, 'Are you sure you should be eating that?' It's usually about cakes, but she can eat almost anything."

Text: 'Young Piano Players Ivan Petrov Ivan was born on a farm in Russia. From age twelve to eighteen, he studied in Poland. His first music teacher couldn't play the piano but taught him and his sister opera songs. His mother started teaching him piano when he was six.
