By ten, he wanted to write music and soon composed his first song. Oleg Gagarin Oleg was the youngest of five children. At four, his father, who enjoyed playing the piano, taught him traditional Russian music. At six, he began lessons with a piano teacher in his city. Oleg quickly started winning piano prizes. At fourteen, he attended a music college in Austria for two years, then returned to Russia. Josef Heptmann Josef's father was German and taught music in Poland, where Josef was born. The family moved to Germany when Josef was two, and he began playing piano a year later. He gave his first concert at six. At ten, he performed fifty-two concerts in two months in England! Josef always loved music but was also interested in physics and languages. He is very busy now but hopes to write his own music someday.'

Bill Prince-Smith was a farmer, teacher, and dentist before he started writing children's books at 60. Now, thirteen years later, he has written over 80 books. Every day, he writes in his office and in the evening, he gives his work to his wife to read. 'She tells me when she doesn't like something,' Bill says. His ten grandchildren, who don't live nearby, also read his stories and give their opinions. This feedback helps Bill understand what young children enjoy reading. Bill writes about life in his village and the nearby farms. His favorite book is his fifth one, The Sheepdog, which is about a farmer and his helpful dog. 'I have always liked animals,' Bill says, 'and dogs are so clever, they learn very quickly.' Last year, the book was turned into a film using real animals and actors. The filmmakers used the latest computer technology to make it seem like the animals are speaking. Bill was very happy with the film. 'Sometimes filmmakers change books, but they didn't change mine and I love the film,' he says.

Text: 'POSTCARDS Today, people enjoy sending postcards to friends and family. These postcards usually feature images of beaches, mountains, or castles, and you can write a message on the back. Many people send postcards while on holiday because they are inexpensive, and the images are often better than their own photos. The first postcard was sent at the end of the nineteenth century, featuring a picture of a seaside town. Later, postcards showed images of current news events, like accidents or important visits, as newspapers did not include pictures at that time.'

Text: 'Dinosaurs No one has ever seen a dinosaur alive. The last dinosaurs died about 60 million years ago, long before humans existed on Earth. The exact reason for their extinction is still unknown. Birds are the closest living relatives to dinosaurs. Dinosaurs varied greatly in appearance. There were over 5000 different species. Some were very small, while others were enormous. The largest dinosaurs were bigger than any other land animals that have ever lived. For instance, the Brontosaurus was twenty meters long and was a plant-eater. The Tyrannosaurus Rex was not as large, but it was more powerful. It had sharp teeth for eating meat and could run fast due to its long back legs.'

Text: 'BEARS Bears can be dangerous animals. Adult bears are very strong and can kill a person. They are good at climbing trees and can run very fast. However, they do not see well and, like most animals, they use their noses to find food. There are seven types of bears: The largest is the white polar bear, which can be almost three meters tall. There are two types of black bears: One lives in the forests of North America, and the other lives in Southeast Asia. Not all black bears are actually black; they can be dark brown or reddish brown. Everyone loves the black and white panda bear, which is from China. Today, not many pandas live in the forest because it is hard for them to find food.'

CROCODILES

Crocodiles live in tropical regions around the world, such as Africa, South America, and Northern Australia. They usually stay in slow-moving water but can move quickly both in water and on land. Crocodiles are often seen in large groups. They eat a variety of prey, including fish, birds, and small animals. Occasionally, they may attack larger animals or even humans. There are over ten different species of crocodiles, all of which have very sharp teeth. These teeth frequently fall out but are quickly replaced. Most crocodiles are about 3.5 meters long, though some can be much larger. Crocodiles have a long lifespan; the oldest one recorded in a zoo lived to be 66 years old.

Text: 'A HISTORY OF AIR TRAVEL In 1783, two French brothers created the first balloon that could carry people into the air. One hundred and twenty years later, in 1903, the Wright brothers constructed the first powered airplane and flew it in the United States. In 1918, the US Post Office started the first airmail service. Over the next thirty years, airplanes underwent significant changes. In the 1950s, they became much faster due to the introduction of jet engines. In 1976, Concorde was developed in the UK and France. It is the fastest passenger plane in the world, capable of flying at 2500 kilometers per hour, making the journey from London to New York only four hours long. Today, millions of people travel by airplane, and it is hard to imagine a world without them.'

Text: 'The Globe Theatre Visiting the theatre in London 400 years ago was quite different from visiting a modern theatre. The building was circular, had no roof, and people could get cold and wet if the weather was bad. The queen enjoyed going to the Globe Theatre, by the River Thames, to watch plays by William Shakespeare. At that time, all the actors were men. Visitors would eat, chat with friends, move around during the performance, and some even threw things at the actors! Today, you can still visit the Globe Theatre. A new theatre is in the same location near the river. You can watch a Shakespeare play there or learn about life in the seventeenth century.'

Dear Jeff,

I'm having a great holiday in Australia. When we arrived two weeks ago, the weather was bad and it was cold. Now the weather is better, and we go to the beach every day. This week we are staying in Sydney, but next week we will go to the Great Barrier Reef. The water there is so warm, and I love swimming. The fish are all different here: red, yellow, purple! Australia is very beautiful. We don't want to come home!

See you at the end of September.

Sue
